is the generator of the rescaled semigroup given by $\mathbf{S}_{0}(\tau):=\mathrm{e}^{-s \tau} \mathbf{S} \upharpoonright(\tau)$ which exhibits the asserted growth estimate. This operator coincides on $C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$ with the map from Definition 2.3.

The potential which arises from the linearization around the self-similar blowup solution is realized as a compact linear operator in radial Sobolev spaces.
Lemma 3.1. Let $d, k \in \mathbb{N}$ with $\frac{d}{2}-s>1$ and $R>0$. Then, the linear map $\mathbf{L}_{V}^{\prime}: C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2} \rightarrow$ $C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$ given in Definition 2.4 has a unique extension to a bounded linear operator $\mathbf{L}_{V}^{\prime} \in$ $\mathfrak{L}\left(\mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)\right)$ and this operator is compact.

Proof. The map $\mathbf{L}_{V}^{\prime}$ from Definition 2.4 represents a densely defined bounded linear operator on $\mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$. Hence, there is a unique extension $\mathbf{L}_{V}^{\prime} \in \mathfrak{L}\left(\mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)\right)$. Compactness of the extended operator follows from compactness of the embedding $H_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \hookrightarrow H_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$, see e.g. [98, proof of Lemma 3.1] for more details.

The generator of the linearized dynamics is implemented in this functional analytic setting as follows.

Definition 3.2. Let $d, k \in \mathbb{N}$ with $\frac{d}{2}-s>1$ and $R \geq R_{0}$. We define the linear operator $\mathbf{L}: \mathfrak{D}(\mathbf{L}) \subset \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \rightarrow \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ by

$$
\mathbf{L}=\mathbf{L}_{0}+\mathbf{L}_{V}^{\prime}, \quad \mathfrak{D}(\mathbf{L})=\mathfrak{D}\left(\mathbf{L}_{0}\right)
$$

This setup allows for a short proof of the existence of the linearized flow in similarity coordinates.

Proposition 3.2. Let $d, k \in \mathbb{N}$ with $\frac{d}{2}-s>1$ and $R \geq R_{0}$. Then, the operator $\mathbf{L}: \mathfrak{D}(\mathbf{L}) \subset$ $\mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \rightarrow \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ is the generator of a strongly continuous semigroup $\mathbf{S}:[0, \infty) \rightarrow$ $\mathfrak{L}\left(\mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)\right)$ with the following properties.
(1) For any $0<\varepsilon<\frac{1}{2}$ and for the constants $M_{d, k, R, h, \varepsilon} \geq 1$ and $\omega_{d, k, s, \varepsilon}$ from Proposition 3.1, the estimate

$$
\left\|\mathbf{S}(\tau) \mathbf{f}\right\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \leq M_{d, k, R, h, \varepsilon} \mathrm{e}^{\left(\omega_{d, k, s, \varepsilon}+M_{d, k, R, h, \varepsilon}\left\|\mathbf{L}_{V}^{\prime}\right\|_{\mathfrak{L}\left(\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}\right)} \tau\right\| \mathbf{f} \|_{R^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}
$$

holds for all $\mathbf{f} \in \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ and all $\tau \geq 0$.
(2) For any $0<\varepsilon<\frac{1}{2}$, the set $\sigma(\mathbf{L}) \cap \overline{\mathbb{H}}_{\omega_{d, k, s, \varepsilon}}$ consists of finitely many isolated eigenvalues of $\mathbf{L}$ with finite algebraic multiplicity.

Proof. By Lemma 3.1, the operator $\mathbf{L}=\mathbf{L}_{0}+\mathbf{L}_{V}^{\prime}$ is a bounded perturbation of the generator of the semigroup from Proposition 3.1. Hence, the Bounded Perturbation Theorem [43, p. 158] yields the first item. Since $\mathbf{L}_{V}^{\prime}$ is compact, we can apply the spectral mapping theorem [55, Theorem B.1] and infer the second item of the proposition.
3.2. Spectral analysis of the generator. The growth estimate in Proposition 3.2 contains no information about the stable and unstable dynamics in the linearized evolution. Together with the spectral mapping theorem [55, Theorem B.1], however, the second item states that any growth additional to the one described in Proposition 3.1 is caused by finitely many eigenvalues in a right half-plane. So the next goal is to characterize this part of the spectrum of the generator. For this, we prepare some technical lemmas for which we recall from Definition B. 1 graphical similarity coordinates

$$
\chi: \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{1, d}, \quad \chi(\tau, \xi)=\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\tau} h(\xi), \mathrm{e}^{-\tau} \xi\right)
$$

and from Definition B. 6 the Laplace-Beltrami operator

$$
\left(\square_{\chi} v\right)(\tau, \xi)=\mathrm{e}^{2 \tau}\left(c^{00}(\xi) \partial_{\tau}^{2}+c^{i 0}(\xi) \partial_{\xi^{i}} \partial_{\tau}+c^{i j}(\xi) \partial_{\xi^{j}} \partial_{\xi^{j}}+c^{0}(\xi) \partial_{\tau}+c^{i}(\xi) \partial_{\xi^{i}}\right) v(\tau, \xi)
$$

The next lemma links the generator of the linearized flow to the wave equation with self-similar potential

$$
\mathcal{V}(t, x):=\mathcal{V}_{0}(t, x)=F^{\prime}\left(x, \psi^{*}(-t, x)\right)
$$

via a convenient transition relation.
Lemma 3.2. Let $v \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)$ be radial and define $\mathbf{u} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$ with components

$$
u_{1}(\tau, \xi)=\mathrm{e}^{-s \tau} v(\tau, \xi), \quad u_{2}(\tau, \xi)=\mathrm{e}^{-s \tau} \frac{1}{c(\xi)}\left(\partial_{\tau}+\xi^{i} \partial_{\xi^{i}}\right) v(\tau, \xi)
$$

Then

$$
\partial_{\tau} \mathbf{u}(\tau, \cdot)=\mathbf{L u}(\tau, \cdot)-\left[\begin{array}{c}
0 \\
\mathrm{e}^{-(s+2) \tau} \frac{c}{w}\left(\left(\square_{\chi}+\mathcal{V} \circ \chi\right) v\right)(\tau, \cdot)
\end{array}\right]
$$

Proof. By the scaling property (F2) of the nonlinearity, we have

$$
\mathrm{e}^{-(s+2) \tau}(\mathcal{V} \circ \chi)(\tau, \xi)=\mathrm{e}^{-s \tau} V(\xi)
$$

Now, the transition relation follows from Lemma B.1.
We give a criterion for the existence of spectral points in a right half-plane in terms of smooth mode solutions to the wave equation with self-similar potential in similarity coordinates.
Proposition 3.3. Let $d, k \in \mathbb{N}$ with $1<\frac{d}{2}-s<k$ and $R \geq R_{0}$. Let $\mathbf{L}: \mathfrak{D}(\mathbf{L}) \subset \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right) \rightarrow$ $\mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ be the operator from Definition 3.2. Then, for any fixed $0>\omega>\max \left\{\frac{d}{2}-s-k,-s\right\}$ we have $\lambda \in \sigma(\mathbf{L}) \cap \overline{\mathbb{H}}_{\omega}$ if and only if there exists an $f_{\lambda} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)$ such that

$$
\begin{cases}\left(\square_{\chi}+\mathcal{V} \circ \chi\right) v_{\lambda}=0 & \text { in } \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d} \\ v_{\lambda}(\tau, \xi)=\mathrm{e}^{(\lambda+s) \tau} f_{\lambda}(\xi) . & \end{cases}
$$

Moreover, every $\lambda \in \sigma(\mathbf{L}) \cap \overline{\mathbb{H}}_{\omega}$ is an isolated eigenvalue of $\mathbf{L}$ with finite algebraic multiplicity and with geometric eigenspace

$$
\operatorname{ker}(\lambda \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{L})=\left\langle\mathbf{f}_{\lambda}\right\rangle \quad \text { spanned by } \quad \mathbf{f}_{\lambda}=\left[\begin{array}{c}
f_{\lambda} \\
\frac{\lambda+s}{c} f_{\lambda}+\frac{1}{c} \xi^{i} \partial_{i} f_{\lambda}
\end{array}\right] \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}
$$

Proof. If $\lambda \in \sigma(\mathbf{L}) \cap \overline{\mathbb{H}}_{\omega}$ then according to Proposition 3.2, there exists $\mathbf{f}_{\lambda} \in \mathfrak{D}(\mathbf{L}) \backslash\{\mathbf{0}\}$ such that

$$
(\lambda \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{L}) \mathbf{f}_{\lambda}=\mathbf{0}
$$

In a first step, we reduce this spectral equation to a differential equation. By definition of $\mathbf{L}$, there is a sequence of functions $\mathbf{f}_{\lambda, n} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$ for $n \in \mathbb{N}$ such that

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\mathbf{f}_{\lambda, n}-\mathbf{f}_{\lambda}\right\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}=0 \quad \text { and } \quad \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left\|(\lambda \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{L}) \mathbf{f}_{\lambda, n}\right\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}=0
$$

Now, we put $\mathbf{F}_{\lambda, n}:=(\lambda \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{L}) \mathbf{f}_{\lambda, n} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$ and

$$
f_{\lambda, n, 1}:=\left[\mathbf{f}_{\lambda, n}\right]_{1}, \quad F_{\lambda, n, 1}:=\left[\mathbf{F}_{\lambda, n}\right]_{1}, \quad F_{\lambda, n, 2}:=\left[\mathbf{F}_{\lambda, n}\right]_{2}
$$

Then

$$
\mathbf{f}_{\lambda, n}=\left[\begin{array}{c}
f_{\lambda, n, 1} \\
\frac{\lambda+s}{c} f_{\lambda, n, 1}+\frac{1}{c} \xi^{i} \partial_{i} f_{\lambda, n, 1}-\frac{1}{c} F_{\lambda, n, 1}
\end{array}\right]
$$

and we infer from Lemma B. 6 the identity

$$
\left(\square_{\chi}+\mathcal{V} \circ \chi\right) v_{\lambda, n}=G_{\lambda, n} \quad \text { in } \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}
$$

where

$$
v_{\lambda, n}(\tau, \xi)=\mathrm{e}^{(\lambda+s) \tau} f_{\lambda, n, 1}(\xi), \quad G_{\lambda, n}(\tau, \xi)=\mathrm{e}^{(\lambda+s+2) \tau} F_{\lambda, n}(\xi)
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
F_{\lambda, n}(\xi)= & -\left((\lambda+s+1) \frac{w(\xi)}{c(\xi)^{2}}+\left(\delta^{i j}-\frac{w(\xi)}{c(\xi)^{2}} \xi^{i} \xi^{j}-2 \frac{\left(\partial^{i} h\right)(\xi) \xi^{j}}{c(\xi)}\right) \frac{\left(\partial_{i} \partial_{j} h\right)(\xi)}{c(\xi)}\right) F_{\lambda, n, 1}(\xi) \\
& -\left(\frac{w(\xi)}{c(\xi)^{2}} \xi^{i}+2 \frac{\left(\partial^{i} h\right)(\xi)}{c(\xi)}\right)\left(\partial_{i} F_{\lambda, n, 1}\right)(\xi)-\frac{w(\xi)}{c(\xi)} F_{\lambda, n, 2}(\xi)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In terms of the radial profile $\widetilde{f}_{\lambda, n, 1} \in C_{\mathrm{ev}}^{\infty}([0, R])$ of $f_{\lambda, n, 1} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)$, Eq. (3.4) reads

$$
a_{2}(\rho) \widetilde{f}_{\lambda, n, 1}^{0}(\rho)+a_{1}(\rho ; \lambda+s, d) \widetilde{f}_{\lambda, n, 1}^{1}(\rho)+\underset{22}{\left(a_{0}(\rho ; \lambda+s, d)+\widetilde{V}(\rho)\right)} \widetilde{f}_{\lambda, n, 1}(\rho)=\widetilde{F}_{\lambda, n}(\rho)
$$

in $(0, R)$, where the coefficients $a_{2}, a_{1}, a_{0}$ are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
a_{2}(\rho) & =-\frac{\rho^{2}-\widetilde{h}(\rho)^{2}}{\left(\rho \widetilde{h}^{\prime}(\rho)-\widetilde{h}(\rho)\right)^{2}} \\
a_{1}(\rho ; \lambda, d) & =2\left(\frac{d-3}{2}-\lambda\right) \frac{\rho-\widetilde{h}(\rho) \widetilde{h}^{\prime}(\rho)}{\left(\rho \widetilde{h}^{\prime}(\rho)-\widetilde{h}(\rho)\right)^{2}}+\left(\frac{d-1}{\rho}-\frac{\rho \widetilde{h}^{\prime \prime}(\rho)}{\rho \widetilde{h}^{\prime}(\rho)-\widetilde{h}(\rho)}\right) a_{2}(\rho) \\
a_{0}(\rho ; \lambda, d) & =-\frac{\lambda(\lambda+1)\left(1-\widetilde{h}^{\prime}(\rho)^{2}\right)}{\left(\rho \widetilde{h}^{\prime}(\rho)-\widetilde{h}(\rho)\right)^{2}}-\frac{\lambda(d-1)}{\rho \widetilde{h}^{\prime}(\rho)-\widetilde{h}(\rho)} \frac{\widetilde{h}^{\prime}(\rho)}{\rho}-\frac{\lambda \widetilde{h}^{\prime \prime}(\rho)}{\rho \widetilde{h}^{\prime}(\rho)-\widetilde{h}(\rho)} a_{2}(\rho)
\end{aligned}
$$

the radial profile $\widetilde{F}_{\lambda, n} \in C_{\mathrm{ev}}^{\infty}([0, R])$ of the inhomogeneity $F_{\lambda, n} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)$ is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widetilde{F}_{\lambda, n}(\rho)= & -\left((\lambda+s+1) \frac{\widetilde{w}(\rho)}{\widetilde{c}(\rho)^{2}}+\frac{d-1}{\widetilde{c}(\rho)} \frac{\widetilde{h}^{\prime}(\rho)}{\rho}+\frac{\widetilde{h}\left(\rho^{2}-\rho^{2}\right.}{\widetilde{c}(\rho)^{3}} \widetilde{h}^{\prime \prime}(\rho)\right) \widetilde{F}_{\lambda, n, 1}(\rho) \\
& -\left(2 \frac{\rho-\widetilde{h}(\rho) \widetilde{h}^{\prime}(\rho)}{\widetilde{c}(\rho)^{2}}-\frac{\widetilde{w}(\rho)}{\widetilde{c}(\rho)^{2}} \rho\right) \widetilde{F}_{\lambda, n, 1}^{\prime}(\rho)-\frac{\widetilde{w}(\rho)}{\widetilde{c}(\rho)} \widetilde{F}_{\lambda, n, 2}(\rho)
\end{aligned}
$$

and $\widetilde{V} \in C_{\mathrm{ev}}^{\infty}([0, R])$ is the radial profile of the potential $V \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)$ from Definition 2.4. We use radial Sobolev embedding to get a nonzero function $\widetilde{f}_{\lambda}:(0, R] \rightarrow \mathbb{C}$ with

$$
\widetilde{f}_{\lambda} \in C^{k-1}([\delta, R]), \quad \widetilde{f}_{\lambda}^{(k-1)} \text { is absolutely continuous on }[\delta, R], \quad \widetilde{f}_{\lambda}^{(k)} \in L^{2}(\delta, R)
$$

for any $0<\delta<R$, such that

$$
f_{\lambda}:=\left[\mathbf{f}_{\lambda}\right]_{1}=\widetilde{f}_{\lambda}(\mid . \mid)
$$

Moreover, (3.2) and (3.9) imply that $\widetilde{f}_{\lambda, n, 1}, \widetilde{f}_{\lambda, n, 1}^{\prime}$ and $\widetilde{F}_{\lambda, n}$ converge uniformly on $[\delta, R]$ to $\widetilde{f}_{\lambda}, \widetilde{f}_{\lambda}^{\prime}$ and 0 , respectively. So we conclude from the weak formulation of Eq. (3.5) that

$$
a_{2}(\rho) \widetilde{f}_{\lambda}^{\prime \prime}(\rho)+a_{1}(\rho ; \lambda+s, d) \widetilde{f}_{\lambda}^{\prime}(\rho)+\left(a_{0}(\rho ; \lambda+s, d)+\widetilde{V}(\rho)\right) \widetilde{f}_{\lambda}(\rho)=0
$$

a.e. in $(0, R)$. In a second step, we investigate the regularity of this solution and show that $f_{\lambda}$ belongs to $C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)$. The coefficients in the differential equation (3.11) are smooth in $(0, R)$ but introduce the regular singular points $\left\{0, R_{0}\right\}$, where $R_{0}>0$ is from Lemma A.5. Thus, $\widetilde{f}_{\lambda} \in C^{\infty}\left(\left(0, R_{0}\right) \cup\left(R_{0}, R\right]\right)$. To conclude that the radial profile $\widetilde{f}_{\lambda}$ belongs to $C_{\mathrm{ev}}^{\infty}([0, R])$, we apply the Frobenius method [132, p. 119 f., Theorem 4.5]. Note, however, that the coefficients in Eq. (3.11) are not necessarily analytic. Therefore, we consider graphical similarity coordinates $\bar{\chi}: \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{1, d}$ with a height function $\bar{h} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ satisfying $\bar{h} \equiv-1$ in $\overline{\mathbb{B}_{1}^{d}}$, see Lemma A.9, and a transition diffeomorphism

$$
\chi^{-1} \circ \bar{\chi}: \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}, \quad(\bar{\tau}, \bar{\xi}) \mapsto\left(\bar{\tau}-\log h_{+}(\bar{\xi}), h_{+}(\bar{\xi})^{-1} \bar{\xi}\right)
$$

as in Lemma A.7. Then

$$
\bar{g}_{\lambda}(\bar{\rho})=\frac{1}{\widetilde{h}_{+}(\bar{\rho})^{\lambda+s}} \widetilde{f}_{\lambda}\left(\frac{\bar{\rho}}{\widetilde{h}_{+}(\bar{\rho})}\right)
$$

defines a function $\bar{g}_{\lambda} \in C^{\infty}((0,1) \cup(1, \bar{R}))$ and since all derivatives of the transition diffeomorphism are bounded on compact domains, we infer from (3.9) that

$$
\bar{g}_{\lambda} \in C^{k-1}([\bar{\delta}, \bar{R}]), \quad \bar{g}_{\lambda}^{(k-1)} \text { is absolutely continuous on }[\bar{\delta}, \bar{R}], \quad \bar{g}_{\lambda}^{(k)} \in L^{2}(\bar{\delta}, \bar{R})
$$

for any $0<\bar{\delta}<\bar{R}$. It follows from Eq. (3.11) and Lemma B. 7 that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(1-\bar{\rho}^{2}\right) \bar{g}_{\lambda}^{\prime \prime}(\bar{\rho})+\left(2\left(\frac{d-3}{2}-\lambda-s\right) \bar{\rho}\right. & \left.+(d-1) \frac{1-\bar{\rho}^{2}}{\bar{\rho}}\right) \bar{g}_{\lambda}^{\prime}(\bar{\rho}) \\
& +\left(\bar{V}(\bar{\rho})-(\lambda+s)(\lambda+s+1)\right) \bar{g}_{\lambda}(\bar{\rho})=0
\end{aligned}
$$

in $(0,1)$, where $\bar{V} \in C_{\mathrm{ev}}^{\infty}([0,1])$ is the radial representative of the potential in Definition 2.4 defined for the height function $\bar{h} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$. Furthermore, set

$$
w_{\lambda}\left(\bar{\rho}^{2}\right)=\bar{g}_{\lambda}(\bar{\rho})
$$

Eq. (3.13) implies for $w_{\lambda}$ the differential equation

$$
z(1-z) w_{\lambda}^{\prime \prime}(z)+(c-(a+b+1) z) w_{\lambda}^{\prime}(z)-(a b-W(z)) w_{\lambda}(z)=0
$$

in $(0,1)$, where

$$
a=\frac{\lambda+s}{2}, \quad b=\frac{\lambda+s+1}{2}, \quad c=\frac{d}{2}
$$

and $W \in C^{\infty}([0,1])$ is determined by $W\left(\bar{\rho}^{2}\right)=\bar{V}(\bar{\rho})$. Eq. (3.15) is a hypergeometric differential equation with a smooth potential and has Frobenius indices

$$
\left\{0,-\frac{d-2}{2}\right\} \quad \text { at } z=0 \quad \text { and } \quad\left\{0, \frac{d}{2}-s-\frac{1}{2}-\lambda\right\} \quad \text { at } z=1
$$

With this, we analyse the regularity of the solution $w_{\lambda}$ at $z=1$ first and distinguish three cases, where each time $\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}$ denote generic analytic functions near $z=1$ with $\varphi_{1}(1)=\varphi_{2}(1)=1$.

- Case $m:=\frac{d}{2}-s-\frac{1}{2}-\lambda \in \mathbb{N}_{0}$. A fundamental system of solutions near $z=1$ is given by

$$
\phi_{1}(z)=(1-z)^{m} \varphi_{1}(z), \quad \phi_{2}(z)=\varphi_{2}(z)+C \log (1-z) \phi_{1}(z)
$$

- If $C \neq 0$, then $\phi_{2}^{(k)}(z)$ is not square integrable near $z=1$ since

$$
\operatorname{Re}(m-k)=\frac{d}{2}-s-k-\operatorname{Re}(\lambda)-\frac{1}{2}<-\frac{1}{2}
$$

But since $\bar{g}_{\lambda}^{(k)}$ is square integrable near $z=1$, also $w_{\lambda}^{(k)}$ is square integrable near $z=1$. Therefore, $w_{\lambda}$ is a multiple of $\phi_{1}$ and analytic near $z=1$.

- If $C=0$, then any linear combination of $\phi_{1}, \phi_{2}$ is analytic near $z=1$ and hence also $w_{\lambda}$.
- Case $m:=\frac{d}{2}-s-\frac{1}{2}-\lambda \in-\mathbb{N}$. A fundamental system of solutions is given by

$$
\phi_{1}(z)=\varphi_{1}(z), \quad \phi_{2}(z)=(1-z)^{m} \varphi_{2}(z)+C \log (1-z) \phi_{1}(z)
$$

In this case, $\phi_{2}$ fails to be continuous at $z=1$ and hence $w_{\lambda}$ is a multiple of the analytic solution $\phi_{1}$ near $z=1$.

- Case $m:=\frac{d}{2}-s-\frac{1}{2}-\lambda \notin \mathbb{Z}$. A fundamental system of solutions is given by

$$
\phi_{1}(z)=(1-z)^{m} \varphi_{1}(z), \quad \phi_{2}(z)=\varphi_{2}(z)
$$

Then $\phi_{1}^{(k)}(z)$ is not square integrable near $z=1$ and thus $w_{\lambda}$ is a multiple of the analytic solution $\phi_{2}$ near $z=1$.

This proves that $w_{\lambda}$ is analytic near $z=1$. Near $z=0$, a fundamental system of solutions is given by

$$
\phi_{1}(z)=\varphi_{1}(z), \quad \phi_{2}(z)=z^{-\frac{d-2}{2}} \varphi_{2}(z)+C \log (z) \phi_{1}(z)
$$

for some $C \in \mathbb{C}$ and functions $\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}$ which are analytic near $z=0$ with $\varphi_{1}(0)=\varphi_{2}(0)=1$. Now, $\frac{d}{2}-s-1>0$ and so $\phi_{2}$ is not square integrable near $z=0$. But $f_{\lambda} \in L^{2}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ and

$$
\left\|f_{\lambda}\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R_{0}}^{d}\right)} \simeq\left\|(\cdot)^{\frac{d-1}{2}} \widetilde{f}_{\lambda}\right\|_{L^{2}\left(0, R_{0}\right)} \simeq\left\|(\cdot)^{\frac{d-1}{2}} \bar{g}_{\lambda}\right\|_{L^{2}(0,1)} \simeq\left\|(\cdot)^{\frac{d-2}{4}} w_{\lambda}\right\|_{L^{2}(0,1)}
$$

so $w_{\lambda}$ is a multiple of the analytic fundamental solution near $z=0$. In particular, the solution $w_{\lambda}$ is analytic in a neighbourhood of $[0,1]$ and any further analytic solution of Eq. (3.15) in $[0,1]$ is a multiple of this solution. We conclude from this and the transformations (3.10), (3.12), (3.14) that $f_{\lambda} \in C_{\text {rad }}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)$ and get from Eq. (3.1) and Lemma B. 6 as above

$$
\left(\square_{\chi}+\mathcal{V} \circ \chi\right) v_{\lambda}=0 \quad \text { in } \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}
$$

where

$$
v_{\lambda}(\tau, \xi)=\mathrm{e}^{(\lambda+s) \tau} f_{\lambda}(\xi)
$$

Conversely, if $f_{\lambda} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)$ defines a mode solution $v_{\lambda} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)$ as in the proposition, put

$$
\begin{aligned}
& u_{\lambda, 1}(\tau, \xi)=\mathrm{e}^{-s \tau} v_{\lambda}(\tau, \xi)=\mathrm{e}^{\lambda \tau} f_{\lambda}(\xi) \\
& u_{\lambda, 2}(\tau, \xi)=\mathrm{e}^{-s \tau} \frac{1}{c(\xi)}\left(\partial_{\tau}+\xi^{i} \partial_{\xi^{i}}\right) v_{\lambda}(\tau, \xi)=\mathrm{e}^{\lambda \tau}\left(\frac{\lambda+s}{c(\xi)} f_{\lambda}(\xi)+\frac{1}{c(\xi)} \xi^{i} \partial_{i} f_{\lambda}(\xi)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, Lemma 3.2 implies for $\mathbf{u}_{\lambda}=\left(u_{\lambda, 1}, u_{\lambda, 2}\right) \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$ the equation $\partial_{\tau} \mathbf{u}_{\lambda}(\tau,)=$ $\mathbf{L u}_{\lambda}(\tau, \ldots)$, which is equivalent to $(\lambda \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{L}) \mathbf{f}_{\lambda}=\mathbf{0}$.

Time translation invariance of Eq. (2.1) induces an unstable eigenvalue of the generator.
Lemma 3.3. Let $\psi^{*}$ be the blowup profile given in Eq. (2.3). Let $f_{1}^{*} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)$ and $\mathbf{f}_{1}^{*} \in$ $C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$ be given by

$$
f_{1}^{*}(\xi)=\left(\partial_{0} \psi^{*}\right)(-h(\xi), \xi) \quad \text { and } \quad \mathbf{f}_{1}^{*}(\xi)=\left[\begin{array}{c}
f_{1}^{*}(\xi) \\
\frac{s+1}{c(\xi)} f_{1}^{*}(\xi)+\frac{1}{c(\xi)} \xi^{i} \partial_{\xi^{i}} f_{1}^{*}(\xi)
\end{array}\right]
$$

respectively. Then

$$
(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{L}) \mathbf{f}_{1}^{*}=\mathbf{0}
$$

Proof. By (F3), for any $T^{\prime} \in \mathbb{R}$ and $(t, x) \in \mathbb{R}^{1, d} \backslash\left\{\left(T^{\prime}, 0\right)\right\}$, the blowup solution $\psi_{T^{\prime}}^{*}(t, x)=$ $\psi^{*}\left(T^{\prime}-t, x\right)$ solves

$$
\left(-\partial_{t}^{2}+\Delta_{x}\right) \psi_{T^{\prime}}^{*}(t, x)+F\left(x, \psi_{T^{\prime}}^{*}(t, x)\right)=0
$$

Differentiating this equation with respect to the parameter yields

$$
\left(-\partial_{t}^{2}+\Delta_{x}+\mathcal{V}_{T^{\prime}}(t, x)\right) \partial_{T^{\prime}} \psi_{T^{\prime}}^{*}(t, x)=0
$$

After evaluating this equation at $T^{\prime}=0$ and transforming it to graphical similarity coordinates, we find that

$$
v_{1}(\tau, \xi) \vDash\left(\left.\left(\partial_{T^{\prime}} \psi_{T^{\prime}}^{*}\right)\right|_{T^{\prime}=0} \circ \chi\right)(\tau, \xi)=\mathrm{e}^{(s+1) \tau} f_{1}^{*}(\xi)
$$

solves

$$
\left(\square_{\chi}+\mathcal{V} \circ \chi\right) v_{1}=0
$$

Now the assertion of the lemma follows from Proposition 3.3.
3.3. Characterization of the unstable spectrum. So far, the analysis of the linearized wave equation has only relied on general theory within our functional analytic framework, without taking the explicit form of the self-similar potential

$$
\mathcal{V}(t, x)= \begin{cases}\frac{8(d-3)(d-4) t^{2}}{\left((d-4) t^{2}+|x|^{2}\right)^{2}} & \text { for wave maps } \\ 3(d-4) \frac{2 \alpha_{d-2} t^{2}+\left(2 \beta_{d-2}-1\right)|x|^{2}}{\left(\alpha_{d-2} t^{2}+\beta_{d-2}|x|^{2}\right)^{2}} & \text { for Yang-Mills }\end{cases}
$$

into account, despite of it carrying sensible information about the precise location of unstable eigenvalues. This comes into play now, when we show that the symmetry-induced eigenvalue $\lambda=1$ from Lemma 3.3 is the only unstable eigenvalue of the generator. The core of this difficult nonself-adjoint spectral problem is reduced to the classical mode stability problem for the corotational wave maps and Yang-Mills equation. The mode stability problem is essentially detached from the functional setting and the choice of similarity coordinates and it has been solved in [21] for wave maps and in [22], [55] for Yang-Mills, also see the survey article [31] for a self-contained introduction.

Proposition 3.4. Consider the assumptions of Proposition 3.3. Then, there exists an $\omega<0$ such that

$$
\sigma(\mathbf{L}) \cap \mathbb{H}_{\omega}=\{1\}
$$

Proof. Assume that $\lambda \in \sigma(\mathbf{L})$ with $\operatorname{Re}(\lambda) \geq 0$. By Proposition 3.3, there exists a nonzero $\widetilde{f}_{\lambda} \in C_{\mathrm{ev}}^{\infty}([0, R])$ such that

$$
a_{2}(\rho) \widetilde{f}_{\lambda}^{\prime \prime}(\rho)+a_{1}(\rho ; \lambda+s, d) \widetilde{f}_{\lambda}^{\prime}(\rho)+\left(a_{0}(\rho ; \lambda+s, d)+\widetilde{V}(\rho)\right) \widetilde{f}_{\lambda}(\rho)=0
$$

in $(0, R)$ with coefficients given in Eqs. (3.6) to (3.8). To transform this differential equation, we employ the transition diffeomorphism

$$
\chi^{-1} \circ \bar{\chi}: \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{B}_{\bar{R}}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}, \quad(\bar{\tau}, \bar{\xi}) \mapsto\left(\bar{\tau}-\log h_{+}(\bar{\xi}), h_{+}(\bar{\xi})^{-1} \bar{\xi}\right)
$$

to similarity coordinates with a height function $\bar{h} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ satisfying $\bar{h} \equiv-1$ in $\overline{\mathbb{B}_{1}^{d}}$, see Lemmas A. 7 and A.9. We switch to the variable

$$
\bar{g}_{\lambda}(\bar{\rho})=\frac{\bar{\rho}^{*}}{h_{+}(\bar{\rho})^{\lambda+s}} \widetilde{f}_{\lambda}\left(\frac{\bar{\rho}}{h_{+}(\bar{\rho})}\right)
$$

and infer from Lemma B. 7 the generalized eigenvalue equation

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(1-\bar{\rho}^{2}\right) \bar{g}_{\lambda}^{\prime \prime}(\bar{\rho})+\left(\frac{d-2 s-1}{\bar{\rho}}-2(\lambda+1) \bar{\rho}\right) \bar{g}_{\lambda}^{\prime}(\bar{\rho}) & -\lambda(\lambda+1) \bar{g}_{\lambda}(\bar{\rho}) \\
& +\left(\bar{V}(\bar{\rho})-\frac{s(d-s-2)}{\bar{\rho}^{2}}\right) \bar{g}_{\lambda}(\bar{\rho})=0
\end{aligned}
$$

in $(0,1)$, where $\bar{V} \in C_{\mathrm{ev}}^{\infty}([0,1])$ given by

$$
\bar{V}(\bar{\rho})= \begin{cases}\frac{8(d-3)(d-4)}{\left((d-4)+\bar{\rho}^{2}\right)^{2}} & \text { for wave maps } \\ 3(d-4) \frac{2 \alpha_{d-2}+\left(2 \beta_{d-2}-1\right) \bar{\rho}^{2}}{\left(\alpha_{d-2}+\beta_{d-2} \bar{\rho}^{2}\right)^{2}} & \text { for Yang-Mills }\end{cases}
$$

is the radial representative of the potential $F^{\prime}\left(., \psi^{*}(1, .)\right) \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{1}^{d}}\right)$ in Eq. (3.16). That is, $\bar{g}_{\lambda} \in C^{\infty}([0,1])$ poses for $\operatorname{Re}(\lambda) \geq 0$ a smooth solution to [21, Eq. (2.7)] for wave maps and [55, Eq. (3.14)] for Yang-Mills, respectively. However, according to [21, Theorem 2.2] and [55, claim in the proof of Proposition 3.2], there exists no such smooth solution to Eq. (3.17) unless $\lambda=1$. Since $1 \in \sigma(\mathbf{L})$ is an eigenvalue by Lemma 3.3 and $\sigma(\mathbf{L}) \subseteq \mathbb{C}$ is a closed subset, the assertion of the proposition follows.

Next, we determine the roles of the unstable eigenvalue and symmetry mode in the linearized wave evolution. For this, we employ the Riesz projection from spectral theory.

Definition 3.3. Consider the assumptions of Proposition 3.3. We define the Riesz projection $\mathbf{P}_{1} \in \mathfrak{L}\left(\mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)\right)$ associated to the isolated eigenvalue $1 \in \sigma(\mathbf{L})$ by

$$
\mathbf{P}_{1}=\frac{1}{2 \pi \mathrm{i}} \int_{\partial \mathbb{D}(1)} \mathbf{R}_{\mathbf{L}}(z) \mathrm{d} z
$$

This operator is well-defined and a bounded linear projection that commutes with the generator. Hence, it yields a decomposition of the Hilbert space into two closed complementary invariant subspaces for the generator. We also mention that this decomposition separates the unstable eigenvalue from the spectrum, see [67, p. 178, Theorem 6.17] for the general theory. In our setting, this leads to the following explicit subspace.

Proposition 3.5. Consider the assumptions of Proposition 3.3. Then, $1 \in \sigma(\mathbf{L})$ is a simple eigenvalue whose geometric and algebraic eigenspaces are both spanned by the symmetry mode $\mathbf{f}_{1}^{*}$ from Lemma 3.3, that is

$$
\operatorname{ran}\left(\mathbf{P}_{1}\right)=\operatorname{ker}(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{L})=\left\langle\mathbf{f}_{1}^{*}\right\rangle
$$

Proof. We have shown in Lemma 3.3 and Proposition 3.3 that $\operatorname{ker}(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{L})=\left\langle\mathbf{f}_{1}^{*}\right\rangle$. Spectral theory of linear operators yields the inclusion $\operatorname{ker}(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{L}) \subseteq \operatorname{ran}\left(\mathbf{P}_{1}\right)$ as well that the operator $\mathbf{I}-\left.\mathbf{L}\right|_{\operatorname{ran}\left(\mathbf{P}_{1}\right)}$ is nilpotent, see e.g. [98, proof of Lemma 3.4] for details. If $\mathbf{I}-\left.\mathbf{L}\right|_{\operatorname{ran}\left(\mathbf{P}_{1}\right)}=\mathbf{0}$ then $(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{L}) \mathbf{P f}=\mathbf{0}$ for all $\mathbf{f} \in \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ and therefore the other inclusion $\operatorname{ran}\left(\mathbf{P}_{1}\right) \subseteq \operatorname{ker}(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{L})$ follows.

Now, let us assume that $\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{L} \upharpoonright_{\operatorname{ran}\left(\mathbf{P}_{1}\right)} \neq \mathbf{0}$. Then there exists an $\mathbf{f} \in \operatorname{ran}\left(\mathbf{P}_{1}\right) \subset \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ such that

$$
(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{L}) \mathbf{f}=\mathbf{f}_{1}^{*}
$$

Radial Sobolev embedding yields that there is a nonzero function $\widetilde{f}_{1}:(0, R] \rightarrow \mathbb{C}$ with

$$
\widetilde{f}_{1} \in C^{k-1}([\delta, R]), \quad \widetilde{f}_{1}^{(k-1)} \text { is absolutely continuous on }[\delta, R], \quad \widetilde{f}_{1}^{(k)} \in L^{2}(\delta, R)
$$

for any $0<\delta<R$, such that $\left.|\mathbf{f}|\right|_{1}=\widetilde{f}_{1}(|.|)$. As in the proof of Proposition 3.3, we conclude from this and Eq. (3.18) the differential equation

$$
a_{2}(\rho) \widetilde{f}_{1}^{\prime \prime}(\rho)+a_{1}(\rho ; s+1, d) \widetilde{f}_{1}^{\prime}(\rho)+\left(a_{0}(\rho ; s+1, d)+\widetilde{V}(\rho)\right) \widetilde{f}_{1}(\rho)=\widetilde{F}(\rho)
$$

a.e. in $(0, R)$, where the coefficients are given in Eqs. (3.6) to (3.8) and

$$
\widetilde{F}(\rho)=-\left((2 s+3) \frac{\widetilde{w}(\rho)}{\widetilde{c}(\rho)^{2}}+\frac{d-1}{\widetilde{c}(\rho)} \frac{\widetilde{h}^{\prime}(\rho)}{\rho}+\frac{\widetilde{h}(\rho)^{2}-\rho^{2}}{\widetilde{c}(\rho)^{3}} \widetilde{h}^{\prime \prime}(\rho)\right) \widetilde{f}_{1}^{*}(\rho)-2 \frac{\rho-\widetilde{h}(\rho) \widetilde{h}^{\prime}(\rho)}{\widetilde{c}(\rho)^{2}} \widetilde{f}_{1}^{* *}(\rho)
$$

and $\widetilde{f}_{1}^{*} \in C_{\mathrm{ex}}^{\infty}([0, R])$ is the radial representative of the symmetry mode $f_{1}^{*} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ from Lemma 3.3. As previously, we consider similarity coordinates $\bar{\chi}_{T}: \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{1, d}$ with height function $\bar{h} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ satisfying $\bar{h} \equiv-1$ in $\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{1}^{d}$ and the transition diffeomorphism

$$
\chi^{-1} \circ \bar{\chi}: \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}, \quad(\bar{\tau}, \bar{\xi}) \mapsto\left(\bar{\tau}-\log h_{+}(\bar{\xi}), h_{+}(\bar{\xi})^{-1} \bar{\xi}\right)
$$

see Lemmas A. 7 and A.9. For $\bar{\rho} \in(0,1)$, we set

$$
\bar{g}(\bar{\rho})=\frac{1}{\widetilde{h}_{+}(\bar{\rho})^{s+1}} \widetilde{f}_{1}\left(\frac{\bar{\rho}}{\widetilde{h}_{+}(\bar{\rho})}\right), \quad \bar{F}(\bar{\rho})=\frac{1}{\widetilde{h}_{+}(\bar{\rho})^{s+3}} \widetilde{F}\left(\frac{\bar{\rho}}{\widetilde{h}_{+}(\bar{\rho})}\right)
$$

It follows that $\bar{g} \in C^{\infty}((0,1)) \cap H^{k}\left(\left(\frac{1}{2}, 1\right)\right)$. To compute the inhomogeneity $\bar{F}$, we note the transformation

$$
\widetilde{h}\left(\widetilde{h}_{+}(\bar{\rho})^{-1} \bar{\rho}\right)=\frac{-1}{\widetilde{h}_{+}(\bar{\rho})}
$$

and derive the identities

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \widetilde{h}^{\prime}\left(\frac{\bar{\rho}}{\widetilde{h}_{+}(\bar{\rho})}\right)=-\frac{H(\bar{\rho})}{\bar{\rho} H(\bar{\rho})-1}, \quad \widetilde{h}^{\prime \prime}\left(\frac{\bar{\rho}}{\widetilde{h}_{+}(\bar{\rho})}\right)=-\widetilde{h}_{+}(\bar{\rho}) \frac{H^{\prime}(\bar{\rho})+H(\bar{\rho})^{2}}{(\bar{\rho} H(\bar{\rho})-1)^{3}}, \\
& \widetilde{c}\left(\frac{\bar{\rho}}{\widetilde{h}_{+}(\bar{\rho})}\right)=-\frac{1}{\widetilde{h}_{+}(\bar{\rho})} \frac{1}{\bar{\rho} H(\bar{\rho})-1}, \quad \widetilde{w}\left(\frac{\bar{\rho}}{\widetilde{h}_{+}(\bar{\rho})}\right)=\frac{-\left(1-\bar{\rho}^{2}\right) H(\bar{\rho})^{2}-2 \bar{\rho} H(\bar{\rho})+1}{(\bar{\rho} H(\bar{\rho})-1)^{2}},
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
H(\bar{\rho}):=\frac{\widetilde{h}_{+}^{\prime}(\bar{\rho})}{\widetilde{h}_{+}(\bar{\rho})}
$$

Furthermore, we recall that the symmetry mode from Lemma 3.3 is given in the respective similarity coordinates by

$$
f_{1}^{*}(\xi)=\mathrm{e}^{-(s+1) \tau}\left(\left.\left(\partial_{T^{\prime}} \psi_{T^{\prime}}^{*}\right)\right|_{T^{\prime}=0} \circ \chi\right)(\tau, \xi), \quad \widetilde{f}_{1}^{*}(\bar{\xi})=\mathrm{e}^{-(s+1) \bar{\tau}}\left(\left.\left(\partial_{T^{\prime}} \psi_{T^{\prime}}^{*}\right)\right|_{T^{\prime}=0} \circ \bar{\chi}\right)(\bar{\tau}, \bar{\xi})
$$

so the respective radial representatives $\widetilde{f}_{1}^{*}, \bar{g}_{1}^{*}$ are related via

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \widetilde{f}_{1}^{*}\left(\frac{\bar{\rho}}{\widetilde{h}_{+}(\bar{\rho})}\right)=\widetilde{h}_{+}(\bar{\rho})^{s+1} \bar{g}_{1}^{*}(\bar{\rho}) \\
& \widetilde{f}_{1}^{*}\left(\frac{\bar{\rho}}{\widetilde{h}_{+}(\bar{\rho})}\right)=-\frac{\widetilde{h}_{+}(\bar{\rho})^{s+2}}{\bar{\rho} H(\bar{\rho})-1}\left((s+1) H(\bar{\rho}) \bar{g}_{1}^{*}(\bar{\rho})+\bar{g}_{1}^{*^{\prime}}(\bar{\rho})\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

With this at hand, a computation yields $\bar{F}=\bar{F}^{*}+\bar{F}^{h}$ for $\bar{F}^{*}, \bar{F}^{h} \in C_{\mathrm{ev}}^{\infty}([0,1])$ given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{F}^{*}(\bar{\rho})= & -(2 s+3) \bar{g}_{1}^{*}(\bar{\rho})-2 \bar{\rho} \bar{g}_{1}^{*^{\prime}}(\bar{\rho}) \\
\bar{F}^{h}(\bar{\rho})= & -\frac{1-\bar{\rho}^{2}}{\bar{g}_{1}^{*}(\bar{\rho})} \frac{\left(1-\bar{\rho}^{2}\right)^{\frac{d-5-s}{2}-s}}{\bar{\rho}^{d-1}} \partial_{\bar{\rho}}\left(\frac{\bar{\rho}^{d-1}}{\left(1-\bar{\rho}^{2}\right)^{\frac{d-5-s}{2}-s}} H(\bar{\rho}) \bar{g}_{1}^{*}(\bar{\rho})^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

This implies together with Lemma B. 7 that $\bar{g}$ solves the inhomogeneous differential equation

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(1-\bar{\rho}^{2}\right) \bar{g}^{\prime \prime}(\bar{\rho})+\left(2\left(\frac{d-5}{2}-s\right) \bar{\rho}\right. & +(d-1) \frac{1-\bar{\rho}^{2}}{\bar{\rho}}\left) \bar{g}^{\prime}(\bar{\rho})\right. \\
& \left.+\left(\bar{V}(\bar{\rho})-(s+1)(s+2)\right) \bar{g}(\bar{\rho})=\bar{F}(\bar{\rho})\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

in $(0,1)$. By Lemma 3.3 and Proposition 3.3, the function $\bar{g}_{1}^{*} \in C_{\mathrm{ev}}^{\infty}([0,1])$ is a solution to the homogeneous version of Eq. (3.21) and therefore, a fundamental system of solutions is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \phi_{1}=\bar{g}_{1}^{*} \\
& \phi_{2}=\bar{g}_{1}^{*} I, \quad \text { where } \quad I^{\prime}(\bar{\rho})=\frac{\left(1-\bar{\rho}^{2}\right)^{\frac{d-5-s}{2}-s}}{\bar{\rho}^{d-1}} \frac{1}{\bar{g}_{1}^{*}(\bar{\rho})^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

with Wronski determinant

$$
W(\bar{\rho})=W\left(\phi_{1}, \phi_{2}\right)(\bar{\rho})=\bar{g}_{1}^{*}(\bar{\rho})^{2} I^{\prime}(\bar{\rho})=\frac{\left(1-\bar{\rho}^{2}\right)^{\frac{d-5-s}{2}-s}}{\bar{\rho}^{d-1}}
$$

The variations of constants formula yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{g}(\bar{\rho}) & =\alpha_{1} \phi_{1}(\bar{\rho})+\alpha_{2} \phi_{2}(\bar{\rho})-\phi_{1}(\bar{\rho}) \int_{0}^{\bar{\rho}} \frac{\phi_{2}(z)}{W(z)} \frac{\bar{F}(z)}{1-z^{2}} \mathrm{~d} z+\phi_{2}(\bar{\rho}) \int_{0}^{\bar{\rho}} \frac{\phi_{1}(z)}{W(z)} \frac{\bar{F}(z)}{1-z^{2}} \mathrm{~d} z \\
& =g(\bar{\rho})+\bar{g}^{h}(\bar{\rho})
\end{aligned}
$$

for $\bar{\rho} \in(0,1)$ and some constants $\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{2} \in \mathbb{C}$, where we have split the solution into a term given by

$$
g(\bar{\rho})=\alpha_{1} \phi_{1}(\bar{\rho})+\alpha_{2} \phi_{2}(\bar{\rho})-\phi_{1}(\bar{\rho}) \int_{0}^{\bar{\rho}} \frac{\phi_{2}(z)}{W(z)} \frac{\bar{F}^{*}(z)}{1-z^{2}} \mathrm{~d} z+\phi_{2}(\bar{\rho}) \int_{0}^{\bar{\rho}} \frac{\phi_{1}(z)}{W(z)} \frac{\bar{F}^{*}(z)}{1-z^{2}} \mathrm{~d} z
$$

and another term given by

$$
\bar{g}^{h}(\bar{\rho})=-\phi_{1}(\bar{\rho}) \int_{0}^{\bar{\rho}} \frac{\phi_{2}(z)}{W(z)} \frac{\bar{F}^{h}(z)}{1-z^{2}} \mathrm{~d} z+\phi_{2}(\bar{\rho}) \int_{0}^{\bar{\rho}} \frac{\phi_{1}(z)}{W(z)} \frac{\bar{F}^{h}(z)}{1-z^{2}} \mathrm{~d} z=-\bar{g}_{1}^{*}(\bar{\rho}) \log \frac{\bar{h}_{+}(\bar{\rho})}{\bar{h}_{+}(0)}
$$

as follows from integration by parts. Note that $\bar{g}^{h} \in C_{\mathrm{ev}}^{\infty}([0,1])$ and that $g \in C^{\infty}((0,1))$ is the general solution to the version of Eq. (3.19) in $(0,1)$ in standard similarity coordinates with $\bar{h} \equiv-1$. In particular, we conclude from [13, Proposition A.2], [54, proof of Proposition 6.1] for wave maps and [55, proof of Proposition 3.4] for Yang-Mills that $g^{(k)} \notin L^{2}\left(\left(\frac{1}{2}, 1\right)\right)$. However, this contradicts $f_{1} \in H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ via the relation (3.20) and so the assumption $\left.\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{L}\right|_{\operatorname{ran}\left(\mathbf{P}_{1}\right)} \neq \mathbf{0}$ does not hold.
3.4. Co-dimension one stable subspace for the linearized wave flow. As a consequence, we get that the linearized wave evolution in similarity coordinates grows exponentially on the one-dimensional subspace spanned by the symmetry mode, whereas on the complementary subspace it decays exponentially. This completely characterizes the global dynamics of the linearized flow.

Proposition 3.6. Let $d, k \in \mathbb{N}$ with $1<\frac{d}{2}-s<k$ and $R \geq R_{0}$. Let $\mathbf{S}:[0, \infty) \rightarrow \mathfrak{L}\left(\mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)\right)$ be the semigroup from Proposition 3.2 and $\mathbf{P}_{1} \in \mathfrak{L}\left(\mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)\right)$ be the spectral projection from Definition 3.3. Then

$$
\mathbf{S}(\tau) \mathbf{P}_{1}-\mathbf{P}_{1} \mathbf{S}(\tau)=\mathbf{0}, \quad \mathbf{S}(\tau) \mathbf{P}_{1}=\mathrm{e}^{\tau} \mathbf{P}_{1}
$$

and there exist constants $\omega>0$ and $M \geq 1$ such that

$$
\left\|\mathbf{S}(\tau)\left(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{P}_{1}\right) \mathbf{f}\right\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} \leq M \mathrm{e}^{-\omega \tau}\left\|\left(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{P}_{1}\right) \mathbf{f}\right\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}
$$

for all $\mathbf{f} \in \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ and all $\tau \geq 0$.
Proof. Since $\mathbf{S}(\tau)$ is a bounded linear operator which commutes with the generator $\mathbf{L}$, it also commutes with the spectral projection $\mathbf{P}_{1}$. Using this and Proposition 3.5, we find the differential equation $\partial_{\tau} \mathbf{S}(\tau) \mathbf{P}_{1} \mathbf{f}=\mathbf{S}(\tau) \mathbf{P}_{1} \mathbf{f}$ and obtain the unique solution $\mathbf{S}(\tau) \mathbf{P}_{1} \mathbf{f}=\mathrm{e}^{\tau} \mathbf{P}_{1} \mathbf{f}$. By Lemma 3.1, $\mathbf{L}=\mathbf{L}_{0}+\mathbf{L}_{Y}^{\prime}$ is a compact perturbation of the generator of the semigroup from Proposition 3.1 with $\sup \{\operatorname{Re}(\lambda) \in \mathbb{C} \mid \lambda \in \sigma(\mathbf{L}) \backslash\{1\}\}<0$ according to Proposition 3.4. Now, the stability estimate on the co-dimension one subspace follows directly from [55, Theorem B.1].

# 4. Nonlinear stability analysis 

In this section, we analyze the full nonlinear stability problem in similarity coordinates.
4.1. Estimates for the nonlinearity. We incorporate the nonlinear remainder from Definition 2.4 as a locally Lipschitz continuous map in the functional setting of the linear theory.
Lemma 4.1. Let $d, k \in \mathbb{N}$ and $R>0$ with

$$
k \geq \frac{d}{2}>2 \text { for wave maps } \quad \text { and } \quad k \geq \frac{d-1}{2}>\frac{5}{2} \text { for Yang-Mills. }
$$

Then, the map $\mathbf{N}: C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2} \rightarrow C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$ given in Definition 2.4 has a unique extension to a $\operatorname{map} \mathbf{N}: \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \rightarrow \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ with the property that for any $M>0$ the estimate

$$
\|\mathbf{N}(\mathbf{f})-\mathbf{N}(\mathbf{g})\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} \lesssim\left(\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\|\mathbf{g}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}\right)\|\mathbf{f}-\mathbf{g}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}
$$

holds for all $\mathbf{f}, \mathbf{g} \in \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ with $\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)},\|\mathbf{g}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} \leq M$.
Proof. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|\mathbf{N}(\mathbf{f})-\mathbf{N}(\mathbf{g})\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} & =\left\|\frac{c}{w}\left(N\left(f_{1}\right)-N\left(g_{1}\right)\right)\right\|_{H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \lesssim\left\|N\left(f_{1}\right)-N\left(g_{1}\right)\right\|_{H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $\mathbf{f}, \mathbf{g} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$. We proceed by splitting the proof into three cases by treating the Yang-Mills nonlinearity for $\frac{d-1}{2} \leq k_{d} \leq \frac{d}{2}$, the wave maps nonlinearity for $k_{d}=\frac{d}{2}$ and both nonlinearities for $k>\frac{d}{2}$.

- Yang-Mills in case $\frac{d-1}{2} \leq k_{d} \leq \frac{d}{2}$. The Yang-Mills nonlinearity reads explicitly

$$
N_{\mathrm{YM}}(f)(\xi)=(d-4)\left(3\left(1-|\xi|^{2} \psi^{*}(-h(\xi), \xi)\right) f(\xi)^{2}-|\xi|^{2} f(\xi)^{3}\right)
$$

So, it suffices to control the Sobolev norm of the product of three functions. The product rule and Hölder's inequality for exponents $\frac{1}{p_{1}}+\frac{1}{p_{2}}+\frac{1}{p_{3}} \leq \frac{1}{2}$ show that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|f_{1} f_{2} f_{3}\right\|_{H^{k_{d}-1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} & \lesssim \sum_{0 \leq\left|\alpha_{1}\right|+\left|\alpha_{2}\right|+\left|\alpha_{3}\right| \leq k_{d}-1}\left\|\left(\partial^{\alpha_{1}} f_{1}\right)\left(\partial^{\alpha_{2}} f_{2}\right)\left(\partial^{\alpha_{3}} f_{3}\right)\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \lesssim \sum_{0 \leq\left|\alpha_{1}\right|+\left|\alpha_{2}\right|+\left|\alpha_{3}\right| \leq k_{d}-1}\left\|\partial^{\alpha_{1}} f_{1}\right\|_{L^{p_{1}}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}\left\|\partial^{\alpha_{2}} f_{2}\right\|_{L^{p_{2}}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}\left\|\partial^{\alpha_{3}} f_{3}\right\|_{L^{p_{3}}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $f_{1}, f_{2}, f_{3} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)$. If $d \in \mathbb{N}$ is odd, then $k_{d}=\frac{d-1}{2}$ and we choose exponents

$$
p_{1}=\frac{2 d}{d-2\left(k_{d}-\left|\alpha_{1}\right|\right)}, \quad p_{2}=\frac{2 d}{d-2\left(k_{d}-\left|\alpha_{2}\right|\right)}, \quad p_{3}=\frac{2 d}{d-2\left(k_{d}-\left|\alpha_{3}\right|\right)}
$$

which ensures

$$
\frac{1}{p_{1}}+\frac{1}{p_{2}}+\frac{1}{p_{3}}=\frac{1+2\left|\alpha_{1}\right|}{2 d}+\frac{1+2\left|\alpha_{2}\right|}{2 d}+\frac{1+2\left|\alpha_{3}\right|}{2 d} \leq \frac{3+2\left(k_{d}-1\right)}{2 d}=\frac{1}{2}
$$

If $d \in \mathbb{N}$ is even, then $k_{d}=\frac{d}{2}$ and we choose the Hölder exponents as above if $\alpha_{i} \neq 0$. If $\alpha_{i}=0$, we set $p_{i}=p$ for a suitable $p>2$ such that $\frac{1}{p_{1}}+\frac{1}{p_{2}}+\frac{1}{p_{3}}=\frac{1}{2}$. In both cases, the Sobolev embeddings

$$
H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \hookrightarrow L^{q}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \quad \text { for } 2 \leq q \text { if } k=\frac{d}{2} \quad \text { and } \quad 2 \leq q \leq \frac{2 d}{d-2 k} \text { if } 0 \leq k<\frac{d}{2}
$$

give

$$
\left\|f_{1} f_{2} f_{3}\right\|_{H^{k_{d}-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \lesssim\left\|f_{1}\right\|_{H^{k_{d}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}\left\|f_{2}\right\|_{H^{k_{d}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}\left\|f_{3}\right\|_{H^{k_{d}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}
$$

for all $f_{1}, f_{2}, f_{3} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)$, which yields the desired local Lipschitz bound for the Yang-Mills nonlinearity.

- Wave maps in case $k_{d}=\frac{d}{2}$. By [98, Lemma 4.1], we have

$$
N_{\mathrm{WM}}(f)(\xi)-N_{\mathrm{WM}}(g)(\xi)=\int_{0}^{1} \int_{0}^{1} A(\xi) B(\xi ; s) F_{\mathrm{WM}}^{\prime \prime}(\xi, C(\xi ; s, t)) \mathrm{d} t \mathrm{~d} s
$$

where we denote

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl}
A(\xi) & :=f(\xi)-g(\xi), & C(\xi ; s, t) & :=\psi^{*}(-h(\xi), \xi)+t(s f(\xi)+(1-s) g(\xi)) \\
B(\xi ; s) & :=s f(\xi)+(1-s) g(\xi), & F_{\mathrm{WM}}^{\prime \prime}(x, z) & :=\partial_{z}^{2} F_{\mathrm{WM}}(x, z)=2(d-3) \frac{\sin (2|x| z)}{|x|}
\end{array}
$$

for $f, g \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)$. So,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|N_{\mathrm{WM}}(f)-N_{\mathrm{WM}}(g)\right\|_{H^{k_{d}-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \lesssim \int_{0}^{1} \int_{0}^{1}\left\|A B(. ; s) F_{\mathrm{WM}}^{\prime \prime}(., C(. ; s, t))\right\|_{H^{k_{d}-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \mathrm{d} t \mathrm{~d} s \\
& \quad \lesssim \int_{0}^{1} \int_{0}^{1} \sum_{0 \leq|\alpha|+|\beta|+|\gamma| \leq k_{d}-1}\left\|\left(\partial^{\alpha} A\right)\left(\partial^{\beta} B(. ; s)\right)\left(\partial^{\gamma} F_{\mathrm{WM}}^{\prime \prime}(., C(. ; s, t))\right)\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \mathrm{d} t \mathrm{~d} s
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $f, g \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)$. The chain rule yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\partial_{\xi}^{\gamma} F_{\mathrm{WM}}^{\prime \prime}(\xi, C(\xi ; s, t))\right| \lesssim\left|\left(\partial^{(\gamma, 0)} F_{\mathrm{WM}}^{\prime \prime}\right)(\xi, C(\xi ; s, t))\right| \\
& \quad+\sum_{\ell=1}^{|\gamma|} \sum_{0 \leq|\alpha| \leq|\gamma|-\ell}\left|\left(\partial^{(\alpha, \ell)} F_{\mathrm{WM}}^{\prime \prime}\right)(\xi, C(\xi ; s, t))\right| \sum_{\substack{|\gamma_{1}|+ \ldots+|\gamma_{\ell}|=|\gamma|-|\alpha| \\
\gamma_{1}, \ldots, \gamma_{\ell} \neq 0}} \prod_{\ell=1}^{\ell}\left|\partial_{\xi}^{\gamma_{1}} C(\xi ; s, t)\right|
\end{aligned}
$$

and so we continue with pointwise bounds on derivatives of the wave maps nonlinearity. We have for any multi-index $\alpha \in \mathbb{N}_{0}^{d}$ the bounds

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl}
\left|F_{\mathrm{WM}}(x, z)\right| & \lesssim \frac{|z|^{3}}{1+|x z|^{2}}, & \left|\partial_{x}^{\alpha} F_{\mathrm{WM}}(x, z)\right| \lesssim \frac{|z|^{3+|\alpha|}}{1+|x z|^{3}} \\
\left|\partial_{z} F_{\mathrm{WM}}(x, z)\right| \lesssim \frac{|z|^{2}}{1+|x z|^{2}}, & \left|\partial_{x}^{\alpha} \partial_{z} F_{\mathrm{WM}}(x, z)\right| \lesssim \frac{|z|^{2+|\alpha|}}{1+|x z|^{2}} \\
\left|\partial_{z}^{2} F_{\mathrm{WM}}(x, z)\right| \lesssim \frac{|z|}{1+|x z|}, & \left|\partial_{x}^{\alpha} \partial_{z}^{2} F_{\mathrm{WM}}(x, z)\right| \lesssim \frac{|z|^{1+|\alpha|}}{1+|x z|}
\end{array}
$$

for all $(x, z) \in \mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathbb{R}$. Furthermore,

$$
\partial_{z} F_{\mathrm{WM}}^{\prime \prime}(x, z)=4(d-3) \cos (|2 z x|)=: \varphi(z x)
$$

where $\varphi \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right) \cap C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ by [97, Lemma 2.3]. Thus, we have for any multi-index $\alpha \in \mathbb{N}_{0}^{d}$ and for any $\ell \in \mathbb{N}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\partial_{x}^{\alpha} \partial_{z} F_{\mathbf{W M}}^{\prime \prime}(x, z) & =z^{|\alpha|}\left(\partial^{\alpha} \varphi\right)(z x) \\
\partial_{z}^{\ell}\left(\partial^{\alpha} \varphi\right)(z x) & =\sum_{i_{1}, \ldots, i_{\ell}=1}^{d} x^{i_{1}} \ldots x^{i_{\ell}}\left(\partial_{i_{1}} \ldots \partial_{i_{\ell}} \partial^{\alpha} \varphi\right)(z x)
\end{aligned}
$$

which implies the pointwise bounds

$$
\left|\partial_{z}^{\ell} F_{\mathbf{W M}}^{\prime \prime}(x . z)\right| \lesssim|x|^{\ell-1}, \quad\left|\partial_{x}^{\alpha} \partial_{z}^{\ell} F_{\mathbf{W M}}^{\prime \prime}(x, z)\right| \lesssim \sum_{j=\max \{0,|\alpha|-\ell\}}^{|\alpha|}|x|^{j-|\alpha|+\ell-1}|z|^{j}
$$

for all $(x, z) \in \mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathbb{R}$. Hence, according to the estimates (4.4), (4.5), (4.6), it suffices to prove bounds for the terms

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\|\left|\partial^{\alpha} A\right|\left|\partial^{\beta} B(., ; s)\right||C(., ; s, t)\right|^{m} \prod_{i=1}^{\ell}\left|\partial^{\gamma_{i}} C(., ; s, t)\right|\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
\left\|\left|\partial^{\alpha} A\right|\left|\partial^{\beta} B(., ; s)\right||C(., ; s, t)\right|^{1+|\gamma|}\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}
\end{gathered}
$$

for any $\alpha, \beta, \gamma, \gamma_{i} \in \mathbb{N}_{0}^{d}$ with $\gamma_{i} \neq 0,1 \leq \ell \leq k_{d}-1,0 \leq m \leq k_{d}-1-\ell$, and

$$
\ell \leq|\alpha|+|\beta|+\sum_{i=1}^{\ell}\left|\gamma_{i}\right| \leq k_{d}-1 \quad \text { resp. } \quad 0 \leq|\alpha|+|\beta|+|\gamma| \leq k_{d}-1
$$

For the term in (4.7), we use Hölder's inequality with exponents

$$
\frac{1}{2}=\frac{1}{p_{\alpha}}+\frac{1}{p_{\beta}}+\frac{m}{p}+\sum_{i=1}^{\ell} \frac{1}{p_{\gamma_{i}}}
$$

and get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|\left|\partial^{\alpha} A\right|\left|\partial^{\beta} B(., ; s)\right||C(., ; s, t)\right|^{m} \prod_{i=1}^{\ell}\left|\partial^{\gamma_{i}} C(., ; s, t)\right|\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \quad \leq\left\|\partial^{\alpha} A\right\|_{L^{p_{\alpha}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}\left\|\partial^{\beta} B(., ; s)\right\|_{L^{p_{\beta}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}\|C(., ; s, t)\|_{L^{p}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}^{m} \prod_{i=1}^{\ell}\left\|\partial^{\gamma_{i}} C(., ; s, t)\right\|_{L^{p_{\gamma_{i}}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

As $\gamma_{i} \neq 0$, we choose

$$
p_{\gamma_{i}}=\frac{2 d}{d-2\left(k_{d}-\left|\gamma_{i}\right|\right)}=\frac{d}{\left|\gamma_{i}\right|}
$$

and if $\alpha, \beta \neq 0$

$$
p_{\alpha}=\frac{2 d}{d-2\left(k_{d}-|\alpha|\right)}=\frac{d}{|\alpha|}, \quad p_{\beta}=\frac{2 d}{d-2\left(k_{d}-|\beta|\right)}=\frac{d}{|\beta|}
$$

or else $p_{\alpha}=p$ resp. $p_{\beta}=p$. Thus, the conditions in (4.9) yield

$$
\frac{1}{p_{\alpha}}+\frac{1}{p_{\beta}}+\sum_{i=1}^{\ell} \frac{1}{p_{\gamma_{i}}} \leq \frac{1}{d}\left(|\alpha|+|\beta|+\sum_{i=1}^{d}\left|\gamma_{i}\right|\right) \leq \frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{d}
$$

and so we can choose $p>2$ such that Eq. (4.10) is satisfied. The exponents for the term in (4.8) are chosen similarly. Then, the Sobolev embeddings (4.2) applied in (4.11) and analogously in (4.8) imply the desired local Lipschitz bound.

- Wave maps and Yang-Mills in case $k>\frac{d}{2}$. In this case, the proof is based on

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|\mathbf{N}(\mathbf{f})-\mathbf{N}(\mathbf{g})\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} & \lesssim\|\mathbf{N}(\mathbf{f})-\mathbf{N}(\mathbf{g})\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k+1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \lesssim\left\|N\left(f_{1}\right)-N\left(g_{1}\right)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

and the algebra property of the Sobolev embedding $H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \hookrightarrow C\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)$. For wave maps, we use the representation (4.3) and Hölder and Sobolev estimates as in [101, p. 221 f.] to get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|N_{\mathrm{WM}}\left(f_{1}\right)-N_{\mathrm{WM}}\left(g_{1}\right)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \quad \lesssim\left\|f_{1}-g_{1}\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}\left(\left\|f_{1}\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\left\|g_{1}\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}\right) \int_{0}^{1} \int_{0}^{1}\left\|F_{\mathrm{WM}}^{\prime \prime}(\cdot, C(\cdot ; s, t))\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \mathrm{d} t \mathrm{~d} s \\
& \quad \lesssim\left\|f_{1}-g_{1}\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}\left(\left\|f_{1}\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\left\|g_{1}\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $\mathbf{f}, \mathbf{g} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$ with $\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)},\|\mathbf{g}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \leq M$. The local Lipschitz estimate for the Yang-Mills nonlinearity follows from

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|N_{\mathrm{YM}}\left(f_{1}\right)-N_{\mathrm{YM}}\left(g_{1}\right)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \lesssim\left\|f_{1}^{2}-g_{1}^{2}\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\left\|f_{1}^{3}-g_{1}^{3}\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \quad \lesssim\left\|f_{1}-g_{1}\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}\left(\left\|f_{1}\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\left\|g_{1}\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}\right) \\
& \quad+\left\|f_{1}-g_{1}\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}\left(\left\|f_{1}\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}^{2}+\left\|f_{1}\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}\left\|g_{1}\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\left\|g_{1}\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}^{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

The rest of the lemma is a continuous extension argument.
We also prove another estimate for the nonlinearity that allows to upgrade the regularity of solutions later.

Lemma 4.2. Let $R>0$ and $d, k_{d} \in \mathbb{N}$ with

$$
k_{d}=\frac{d}{2}>2 \text { for wave maps } \quad \text { and } \quad \frac{d}{2} \geq k_{d} \geq \frac{d-1}{2}>\frac{5}{2} \text { for Yang-Mills. }
$$

Then,

$$
\|\mathbf{N}(\mathbf{f})\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k_{d}+1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \lesssim\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\left(1+\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k_{d}}}^{k_{d}+1}\right. \\
\left.\left(\mathbf{f}\right\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k_{d}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}\right)\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k_{d}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k_{d}+1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \text { for wave maps, } \\
\left(1+\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k_{d}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}\right)\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k_{d}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k_{d}+1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \text { for Yang-Mills, }
\end{array}\right.
$$

for all $\mathbf{f} \in \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k_{d}+1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$. Moreover, if $k>\frac{d}{2}$, then $\mathbf{N}(\mathbf{f}) \in \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k+1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \subset \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ for all $\mathbf{f} \in \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$.
Proof. We have

$$
\|\mathbf{N}(\mathbf{f})\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k+1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}=\left\|\frac{c}{w} N\left(f_{1}\right)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \lesssim\left\|N\left(f_{1}\right)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}
$$

for all $\mathbf{f} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$. We distinguish between the cases $\frac{d-1}{2} \leq k_{d} \leq \frac{d}{2}$ for the Yang-Mills nonlinearity and $k_{d}=\frac{d}{2}$ for the wave maps nonlinearity.

- Yang-Mills in case $\frac{d-1}{2} \leq k_{d} \leq \frac{d}{2}$. First, suppose that $d \in \mathbb{N}$ is odd, so $k_{d}=\frac{d-1}{2}$. For the Yang-Mills nonlinearity (4.1), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|N_{\mathrm{YM}}(f)\right\|_{H^{k_{d}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \lesssim\left\|f^{2}\right\|_{H^{k_{d}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\left\|f^{3}\right\|_{H^{k_{d}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \quad \lesssim \sum_{0 \leq \mid \alpha_{1}|+| \alpha_{2}| \leq k_{d}}\left\|\left(\partial^{\alpha_{1}} f\right)\left(\partial^{\alpha_{2}} f\right)\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \quad+\sum_{0 \leq \mid \alpha_{1}|+| \alpha_{2}|+| \alpha_{3}| \leq k_{d}}\left\|\left(\partial^{\alpha_{1}} f\right)\left(\partial^{\alpha_{2}} f\right)\left(\partial^{\alpha_{3}} f\right)\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $f \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)$. To control the quadratic term, we fix multi-indices $\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{2} \in \mathbb{N}_{0}^{d}$ with $0 \leq\left|\alpha_{1}\right|+\left|\alpha_{2}\right| \leq k_{d}$ and $\left|\alpha_{1}\right| \geq\left|\alpha_{2}\right|$. We choose corresponding Hölder exponents

$$
p_{1}=\frac{2 d}{d-2\left(k_{d}+1-\left|\alpha_{1}\right|\right)}=\frac{2 d}{2\left|\alpha_{1}\right|-1}, \quad p_{2}=\frac{2 d}{d-2\left(k_{d}-\left|\alpha_{2}\right|\right)}=\frac{2 d}{2\left|\alpha_{2}\right|+1}
$$

This ensures $\frac{1}{p_{1}}+\frac{1}{p_{2}} \leq \frac{1}{2}$ and Hölder's inequality and Sobolev embedding give

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\left(\partial^{\alpha_{1}} f\right)\left(\partial^{\alpha_{2}} f\right)\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} & \leq\left\|\partial^{\alpha_{1}} f\right\|_{L^{p_{1}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}\left\|\partial^{\alpha_{2}} f\right\|_{L^{p_{2}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \lesssim\|f\|_{H^{k_{d}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}\|f\|_{H^{k_{d}+1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $f \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)$. For the cubic term, we fix multi-indices $\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{2}, \alpha_{3} \in \mathbb{N}_{0}^{d}$ with $0 \leq$ $\left|\alpha_{1}\right|+\left|\alpha_{2}\right|+\left|\alpha_{3}\right| \leq k_{d}$ and $\left|\alpha_{1}\right| \geq\left|\alpha_{2}\right| \geq\left|\alpha_{3}\right|$. We choose corresponding Hölder exponents $p_{1}, p_{2}$ as above and

$$
p_{3}=\frac{2 d}{d-2\left(k_{d}-\left|\alpha_{3}\right|\right)}=\frac{2 d}{2\left|\alpha_{3}\right|+1}
$$

As before, $\frac{1}{p_{1}}+\frac{1}{p_{2}}+\frac{1}{p_{3}} \leq \frac{1}{2}$ and Hölder's inequality and Sobolev embedding yield

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\left(\partial^{\alpha_{1}} f\right)\left(\partial^{\alpha_{2}} f\right)\left(\partial^{\alpha_{3}} f\right)\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} & \leq\left\|\partial^{\alpha_{1}} f\right\|_{L^{p_{1}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}\left\|\partial^{\alpha_{2}} f\right\|_{L^{p_{2}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}\left\|\partial^{\alpha_{3}} f\right\|_{L^{p_{3}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \lesssim\|f\|_{H^{k_{d}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}^{2}\|f\|_{H^{k_{d}+1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $f \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)$. These estimates imply the result for the Yang-Mills nonlinearity. In case $k_{d}=\frac{d}{2}$, the result follows directly from the inequality (4.16) below.

- Wave maps in case $k_{d}=\frac{d}{2}$. We use the representation

$$
N_{\mathrm{WM}}(f)(\xi)=\int_{0}^{1} f(\xi)^{2} F_{\mathrm{WM}}^{\prime}\left(\xi, \psi^{*}(-h(\xi), \xi)+t f(\xi)\right)(1-t) \mathrm{d} t
$$

from [98, Lemma 4.1] and get

$$
\left\|N_{\mathrm{WM}}(f)\right\|_{H^{k_{d}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \lesssim \int_{0}^{1} \sum_{0 \leq|\alpha|+|\beta|+|\gamma| \leq k_{d}}\left\|\left(\partial^{\alpha} f\right)\left(\partial^{\beta} f\right)\left(\partial^{\gamma} F_{\mathrm{WM}}^{\prime \prime}(., C(., ; t))\right)\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \mathrm{d} t
$$

for all $f \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)$, where $C(\xi ; t)=\psi^{*}(-h(\xi), \xi)+t f(\xi)$. We recall the pointwise estimates (4.6) for the wave maps nonlinearity and note that the asserted bound in the lemma follows from estimating terms of the form

$$
\left\||f|^{m} \prod_{i=1}^{\ell}\left|\partial^{\alpha_{i}} f\right|\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}
$$

for $\ell, m \in \mathbb{N}$ and $\alpha_{i} \in \mathbb{N}_{0}^{d}$ with $1 \leq \ell \leq k_{d}, 0 \leq m \leq k_{d}-\ell$ and $0 \leq\left|\alpha_{1}\right|+\ldots+\left|\alpha_{\ell}\right| \leq k_{d}$. By Hölder's inequality for exponents with

$$
\frac{m}{p}+\sum_{i=1}^{\ell} \frac{1}{p_{i}} \leq \frac{1}{2}
$$

we have

$$
\left\||f|^{m} \prod_{i=1}^{\ell}\left|\partial^{\alpha_{i}} f\right|\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \leq\|f\|_{L^{p}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}^{m} \prod_{i=1}^{\ell}\left\|\partial^{\alpha_{i}} f\right\|_{L^{p_{i}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}
$$

We order the multi-indices so that $\left|\alpha_{\ell}\right| \geq \ldots \geq\left|\alpha_{1}\right|$. If $\left|\alpha_{\ell}\right|>1$, set $p_{\ell}=d /\left(\left|\alpha_{\ell}\right|-1\right)$ and $p_{i}=d /\left|\alpha_{i}\right|$ for the remaining indices if $\alpha_{i} \neq 0$ and $p_{i}=p$ if $\alpha_{i}=0$. Then, $p>2$ can be chosen

such that equality is attained in (4.15). If $\left|\alpha_{\ell}\right|=1$, choose $p_{\ell}=p$ and the remaining indices as above. Then, the Sobolev embedding (4.2) yields

$$
\left\||f|^{m} \prod_{i=1}^{\ell}\left|\partial^{\alpha_{i}} f\right|\right|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \lesssim\|f\|_{H^{k_{d}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}^{m+\ell-1}\|f\|_{H^{k_{d}+1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}
$$

for all $f \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)$.
The final statement of the lemma in case $k>\frac{d}{2}$ follows from the estimates (4.12), (4.13), (4.14) in the proof of Lemma 4.1.
4.2. Notion of solution. Lemma 4.1 gives control on the mapping properties of the nonlinearity in Sobolev spaces. In particular, Duhamel's principle can be meaningfully applied to the semigroup from Proposition 3.2 which allows to adopt the notion of solution from [99, p. 184, Definition 1.1].

Definition 4.1. Let $d, k \in \mathbb{N}$ and $R \geq R_{0}$ with

$$
k \geq \frac{d}{2}>2 \text { for wave maps } \quad \text { and } \quad k \geq \frac{d-1}{2}>\frac{5}{2} \text { for Yang-Mills. }
$$

Let
$\mathbf{S}:[0, \infty) \rightarrow \mathfrak{L}\left(\mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)\right)$ be the semigroup from Proposition 3.2,
$\mathbf{L}: \mathfrak{D}(\mathbf{L}) \subset \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \rightarrow \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ be its generator from Definition 3.2,
$\mathbf{N}: \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \rightarrow \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ be the nonlinearity from Lemma 4.1.
Let $\mathbf{f} \in \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$.
A map $\mathbf{u} \in C\left([0, \infty), \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)\right) \cap C^{1}\left((0, \infty), \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)\right)$ which satisfies $\mathbf{u}(\tau) \in \mathfrak{D}(\mathbf{L})$ and

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
\partial_{\tau} \mathbf{u}(\tau) & =\mathbf{L} \mathbf{u}(\tau)+\mathbf{N}(\mathbf{u}(\tau)) \\
\mathbf{u}(0) & =\mathbf{f}
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

for all $\tau>0$, is called a classical solution to the abstract Cauchy problem.
A map $\mathbf{u} \in C\left([0, \infty), \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)\right)$ which satisfies

$$
\mathbf{u}(\tau)=\mathbf{S}(\tau) \mathbf{f}+\int_{0}^{\tau} \mathbf{S}\left(\tau-\tau^{\prime}\right) \mathbf{N}\left(\mathbf{u}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} \tau^{\prime}
$$

for all $\tau>0$, is called a mild solution to the abstract Cauchy problem.
We recall that the abstract Cauchy problem (4.17) is locally well-posed and obeys a blowup alternative.

Proposition 4.1. Let $M>0$. Then, there is a $t_{+} \in(0, \infty]$ such that for all $\mathbf{f} \in \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ with $\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \leq M$ there exists a unique local-in-time mild solution $\mathbf{u} \in C\left(\left[0, t_{+}\right), \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)\right)$ in the sense of Definition 4.1 to the abstract Cauchy problem (4.17). If $t_{+}<\infty$, then

$$
\limsup _{t_{<} \rightarrow t_{+}}\|\mathbf{u}(\tau)\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}=\infty
$$

Proof. See [99, p. 185 f., Theorem 1.4].
We prove that for smooth initial data the mild solution is in fact a jointly smooth classical solution. This crucially uses mapping properties of the linearized flow in Sobolev spaces, which are inherited from our construction of the free wave flow in Theorem B.1.

Proposition 4.2. Suppose $\mathbf{u} \in C\left([0, \infty), \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)\right)$ is a mild solution to the abstract Cauchy problem in the sense of Definition 4.1 for some smooth initial datum $\mathbf{f} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$. Then $\mathbf{u} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{(0, \infty) \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$ and it is the unique classical solution to the abstract Cauchy problem.
Proof. First, consider $k_{d}=\frac{d}{2}$ for wave maps and $\frac{d-1}{2} \leq k_{d} \leq \frac{d}{2}$ for Yang-Mills. Let $\mathbf{u} \in$ $C\left([0, \infty), \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k_{d}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)\right)$ such that

$$
\mathbf{u}(\tau)=\mathbf{S}(\tau) \mathbf{f}+\int_{0}^{\tau} \mathbf{S}\left(\tau-\tau^{\prime}\right) \mathbf{N}\left(\mathbf{u}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} \tau^{\prime}
$$

for all $\tau \geq 0$. By uniqueness, $\mathbf{u}$ coincides with the local mild solution in $C\left(\left[0, t_{+}\right), \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k_{d}+1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)\right)$ from Proposition 4.1 on its maximal interval of existence. To show that this solution is actually a global one, we assume to the contrary that $t_{+}<\infty$. Then, since $\|\mathbf{u}(\tau)\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k_{d}}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}$ is uniformly bounded on $\left[0, t_{+}\right]$, we can exploit the nonlinear estimates from Lemma 4.2 to obtain from the above fixed-point equation

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|\mathbf{u}(\tau)\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k_{d}+1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} & \lesssim\|\mathbf{S}(\tau) \mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k_{d}+1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\int_{0}^{\tau}\left\|\mathbf{S}\left(\tau-\tau^{\prime}\right) \mathbf{N}\left(\mathbf{u}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)\right)\right\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k_{d}+1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \mathrm{d} \tau^{\prime} \\
& \lesssim 1+\int_{0}^{\tau}\left\|\mathbf{u}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)\right\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k_{d}+1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \mathrm{d} \tau^{\prime}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $\tau \in\left[0, t_{+}\right)$. Thus, Grönwall's inequality shows that $\|\mathbf{u}(\tau)\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k_{d}+1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}$ is uniformly bounded on the maximal interval of existence, which contradicts the blowup alternative in Proposition 4.1. Therefore, $\mathbf{u} \in C\left([0, \infty), \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k_{d}+1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)\right)$. Now, for any mild solution in $C\left([0, \infty), \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)\right)$ with $k>\frac{d}{2}$, we conclude from the fixed-point equation together with the restriction property [54, Lemma C.1] satisfied by the semigroups $\mathbf{S}:[0, \infty) \rightarrow \mathfrak{L}\left(\mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)\right)$ from Proposition 3.2 and the second part of Lemma 4.2 that $\mathbf{u}(\tau) \in \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ for all $k>\frac{d}{2}$ and all $\tau \geq 0$. Now, Sobolev embedding yields $\mathbf{u}(\tau) \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$ for all $\tau \geq 0$. To prove that this solution is classical and jointly smooth on $(0, \infty) \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}$, we first use [99, p. 189, Theorem 1.6] to infer that the mild solution is classical in the sense of Definition 4.1. So, the fixed-point equation can be differentiated with respect to $\tau$, which gives

$$
\partial_{\tau} \mathbf{u}(\tau)=\mathbf{S}(\tau) \mathbf{L} \mathbf{f}+\int_{0}^{\tau} \mathbf{S}\left(\tau-\tau^{\prime}\right) \mathbf{L} \mathbf{N}\left(\mathbf{u}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} \tau^{\prime}+\mathbf{N}(\mathbf{u}(\tau))
$$

and so the restriction property [54, Lemma C.1] and smoothness of $\mathbf{u}(\tau)$ give $\partial_{\tau} \mathbf{u}(\tau) \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)$ for all $\tau \geq 0$. By induction, we conclude for any $\ell \in \mathbb{N}$ that $\partial_{\tau}^{\ell} \mathbf{u}(\tau) \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)$. An application of Schwarz's theorem [104, p. 235, Theorem 9.41] yields $\mathbf{u} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{(0, \infty) \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$.
4.3. Stabilized evolution. Our next goal is to prove the existence of global-in-time stable solutions to the abstract Cauchy problem (4.17). For this, we incorporate the decay of the linearized wave flow on the stable subspace into a function space for our main fixed-point argument.
Definition 4.2. Let $\omega>0$ be the growth constant from Proposition 3.6. We define a Banach space $\left(\mathfrak{X}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right),\|\cdot\|_{\mathfrak{X}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}\right)$ by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathfrak{X}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) & \left.=\left\{\mathbf{u} \in C\left([0, \infty), \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)\right) \mid\|\mathbf{u}(\tau)\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \lesssim \mathrm{e}^{-\omega \tau} \text { for all } \tau \geq 0\right\} \\
\|\mathbf{u}\|_{\mathfrak{X}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} & \left.:=\sup _{\tau \in[0, \infty)}\left(\mathrm{e}^{\omega \tau}\|\mathbf{u}(\tau)\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In this setting, the Lyapunov-Perron method provides an approach for suppressing the linear instabilities in the nonlinear evolution by means of a correction term.
Definition 4.3. Let $\mathbf{P}_{1} \in \mathfrak{L}\left(\mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)\right)$ be the spectral projection from Definition 3.3. We define

$$
\mathbf{C}: \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \times \mathfrak{X}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \rightarrow \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right), \quad \mathbf{C}(\mathbf{f}, \mathbf{u})=\mathbf{P}_{1} \mathbf{f}+\mathbf{P}_{1} \int_{0}^{\infty} \mathrm{e}^{-\tau^{\prime}} \mathbf{N}\left(\mathbf{u}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} \tau^{\prime}
$$

Modifying the initial data by subtracting the correction term leads for small data to a well-posed global-in-time nonlinear evolution of exponentially stable solutions.

Proposition 4.3. Let $d, k \in \mathbb{N}$ and $R \geq R_{0}$ be as in Definition 4.1. Then, there are $0<\delta_{0}<1$ and $C_{0}>1$ such that for all $0<\delta \leq \delta_{0}, C \geq C_{0}$ and all $\mathbf{f} \in \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ with $\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \leq \frac{\delta}{C}$ there is a unique $\mathbf{u}_{\mathbf{f}} \in \mathfrak{X}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ with $\left\|\mathbf{u}_{\mathbf{f}}\right\|_{\mathfrak{X}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \leq \delta$ and

$$
\mathbf{u}_{\mathbf{f}}(\tau)=\mathbf{S}(\tau)\left(\mathbf{f}-\mathbf{C}\left(\mathbf{f}, \mathbf{u}_{\mathbf{f}}\right)\right)+\int_{0}^{\tau} \mathbf{S}\left(\tau-\tau^{\prime}\right) \mathbf{N}\left(\mathbf{u}_{\mathbf{f}}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} \tau^{\prime}
$$

for all $\tau \geq 0$. Moreover, we have

$$
\left\|\mathbf{u}_{\mathbf{f}}-\mathbf{u}_{\mathbf{g}}\right\|_{\mathfrak{X}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \lesssim\|\mathbf{f}-\mathbf{g}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}
$$

for all $\mathbf{f}, \mathbf{g} \in \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ with $\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}, \|\mathbf{g}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \leq \frac{\delta}{C}$.
Proof. For now, let $\delta_{0}>0$ and $C_{0}>1$ be arbitrary but fixed and $0<\delta \leq \delta_{0}$ and $C \geq C_{0}$. We set

$$
\mathfrak{B}_{\delta}=\left\{\mathbf{u} \in \mathfrak{X}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \mid\|\mathbf{u}\|_{\mathfrak{X}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \leq \delta\right\}
$$

for a closed ball in our Banach space. For any $\mathbf{f} \in \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ with $\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \leq \frac{\delta}{C}$ and $\mathbf{u} \in \mathfrak{X}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ we define

$$
\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{f}}(\mathbf{u})(\tau)=\mathbf{S}(\tau)(\mathbf{f}-\mathbf{C}(\mathbf{f}, \mathbf{u}))+\int_{0}^{\tau} \mathbf{S}\left(\tau-\tau^{\prime}\right) \mathbf{N}\left(\mathbf{u}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} \tau^{\prime}
$$

Thanks to the correction term, we can conclude from Proposition 3.6 and Lemma 4.1 the estimates

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{f}}(\mathbf{u})(\tau)\right\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} & \lesssim \frac{\delta}{C} \mathrm{e}^{-\omega \tau}+\delta^{2} \mathrm{e}^{-\omega \tau} \\
\left\|\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{f}}(\mathbf{u})(\tau)-\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{f}}(\mathbf{v})(\tau)\right\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} & \lesssim \delta\|\mathbf{u}(\tau)-\mathbf{v}(\tau)\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \mathrm{e}^{-\omega \tau}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $\mathbf{u}, \mathbf{v} \in \mathfrak{X}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ with $\|\mathbf{u}\|_{\mathfrak{X}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}, \|\mathbf{v}\|_{\mathfrak{X}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \leq \delta$. Hence, there are $\delta_{0}>0$ and $C_{0}>1$ such that the map

$$
\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{f}}: \mathfrak{B}_{\delta} \rightarrow \mathfrak{B}_{\delta}, \quad \mathbf{u} \mapsto \mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{f}}(\mathbf{u})
$$

is well-defined and a contraction for any $\mathbf{f} \in \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ with $\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \leq \frac{\delta}{C}$. According to Banach's fixed-point theorem, there is a unique $\mathbf{u}_{\mathbf{f}} \in \mathfrak{B}_{\delta}$ such that $\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{f}}\left(\mathbf{u}_{\mathbf{f}}\right)=\mathbf{u}_{\mathbf{f}}$. By Grönwall's inequality, this solution is unique in $\mathfrak{X}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$. Finally, the above estimates also imply

$$
\left\|\mathbf{u}_{\mathbf{f}}(\tau)-\mathbf{u}_{\mathbf{g}}(\tau)\right\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \lesssim\|\mathbf{f}-\mathbf{g}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \mathrm{e}^{-\omega \tau}
$$

for all $\mathbf{f}, \mathbf{g} \in \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ with $\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}, \|\mathbf{g}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \leq \frac{\delta}{C}$ and all $\tau \geq 0$.
4.4. Data along the initial hypersurface. The initial data in Theorem 2.1 are prescribed at time $t=0$ and have to be transported to data for the abstract Cauchy problem (4.17) along an initial hypersurface at $\tau=0$ in similarity coordinates. We achieve this by adapting our coordinate system in such a way that the initial hypersurface directly picks up the perturbations for the blowup data.
Lemma 4.3. Let $r>0, \varepsilon>0$ and $R \geq r+\varepsilon, T \geq 1-\frac{\varepsilon}{r+\varepsilon}$. Let $h \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ and $\chi_{T}: \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{1, d}$ be as in Definition 2.1 with the additional property $h \equiv-1$ in $\mathbb{B}_{r+\varepsilon}^{d}$. Consider the domain

$$
\Lambda^{1, d}(r)=\left\{(t, x) \in \mathbb{R}^{1, d} \mid 0 \leq t \leq|x|-r\right\}
$$

and the spacelike hypersurface

$$
\Sigma_{T, R}^{1, d}(0)=\chi_{T}\left(\{0\} \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)
$$

Then

$$
\{0\} \times \mathbb{B}_{r}^{d} \subset \Sigma_{T, R}^{1, d}(0) \quad \text { and } \quad \Sigma_{T, R}^{1, d}(0) \backslash\left(\{0\} \times \mathbb{B}_{r}^{d}\right) \subset \Lambda^{1, d}(r)
$$

Proof. Note that $\Sigma_{T, R}^{1, d}(0)=\left\{\left(t_{0}(x), x\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{1, d} \mid x \in \mathbb{B}_{R T}^{d}\right\}$ is the graph of the function given by $t_{0}(x)=T+\operatorname{Th}\left(\frac{x}{T}\right)$. If $|x|<r$, then $|x| / T<r / T \leq r+\varepsilon$ and therefore $h\left(\frac{x}{T}\right)=-1$. So $t_{0}(x)=0$ for all $|x|<r$ which yields the inclusion $\{0\} \times \mathbb{B}_{r}^{d} \subset \Sigma_{T, R}^{1, d}(0)$. Moreover, the assumptions on $h$ imply the inequality

$$
0 \leq t_{0}(x)=T+\operatorname{Th}\left(\frac{x}{T}\right)<T+T\left(\frac{|x|-r}{T}-1\right)=|x|-r
$$

for all $|x| \geq r$, which yields the other inclusion $\Sigma_{T, R}^{1, d}(0) \backslash\left(\{0\} \times \mathbb{B}_{r}^{d}\right) \subset \Lambda_{r}^{1, d}$.
Now, if

$$
\psi(0, \cdot)=\psi_{1}^{*}(0, \cdot)+f \quad \text { and } \quad\left(\partial_{0} \psi\right)(0, \cdot)=\left(\partial_{0} \psi_{1}^{*}\right)(0, \cdot)+g
$$

are data at $t=0$ for the semilinear wave equation (2.1) and the perturbations $f, g$ are supported in $\mathbb{B}_{r}^{d}$, then the corresponding solution $\psi$ has to coincide with $\psi_{1}^{*}$ in $\Lambda_{r}^{1, d}$ by finite speed of propagation. Therefore, the solution $\psi$ is known along the initial hypersurface $\Sigma_{T, R}^{1, d}(0)$ from Lemma 4.3 beforehand. Evaluating the corresponding rescaled evolution variables $u_{1}, u_{2}$ from Eq. (2.8) at $\tau=0$ then yields precisely the correct data for the abstract Cauchy problem, which are provided by the following initial data operator.
Definition 4.4. Let $r>0, \varepsilon>0$ and $R \geq r+\varepsilon$. Let $h \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ be as in Definition 2.1 with $h \equiv-1$ in $\mathbb{B}_{r+\varepsilon}^{d}$. We define the map
$\mathbf{U}:\left(C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right) \cap C_{\mathrm{c}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{B}_{r}^{d}\right)\right)^{2} \times\left[1-\frac{\varepsilon}{r+\varepsilon}, 1+\frac{\varepsilon}{r+\varepsilon}\right] \rightarrow C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}, \quad \mathbf{U}(\boldsymbol{f}, T)=\boldsymbol{f}_{T}+\boldsymbol{\Psi}_{T}^{1}-\boldsymbol{\Psi}_{T}^{T}$,
where

$$
