\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{f}_{T}(\xi)=\left[\begin{array}{c}
T^{s} f(T \xi) \\
T^{s+1} g(T \xi)
\end{array}\right], \quad \boldsymbol{\Psi}_{T}^{1}(\xi) & =\left[\begin{array}{c}
T^{s} \psi_{1}^{*}(T+\operatorname{Th}(\xi), T \xi) \\
T^{s+1}\left(\partial_{0} \psi_{1}^{*}\right)(T+\operatorname{Th}(\xi), T \xi)
\end{array}\right] \\
\boldsymbol{\Psi}_{T}^{T}(\xi) & =\left[\begin{array}{c}
T^{s} \psi_{T}^{*}(T+\operatorname{Th}(\xi), T \xi) \\
T^{s+1}\left(\partial_{0} \psi_{T}^{*}\right)(T+\operatorname{Th}(\xi), T \xi)
\end{array}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

This initial data operator takes the following form.
Lemma 4.4. Recall the symmetry mode $\mathbf{f}_{1}^{*} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$ from Lemma 3.3. Then, there is a map $\mathbf{r} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\left(1-\frac{\varepsilon}{r+\varepsilon}, 1+\frac{\varepsilon}{r+\varepsilon}\right)} \times \overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$ such that

$$
\mathbf{U}(\boldsymbol{f}, T)=\boldsymbol{f}_{T}+(1-T) \mathbf{f}_{1}^{*}+(1-T)^{2} \mathbf{r}(T, \cdot)
$$

for all $\boldsymbol{f} \in\left(C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right) \cap C_{\mathrm{c}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{B}_{r}^{d}\right)\right)^{2}$ and all $T \in\left[1-\frac{\varepsilon}{r+\varepsilon}, 1+\frac{\varepsilon}{r+\varepsilon}\right]$.
Proof. Note with the scaling (F2) and self-similarity of the blowup profile from (F3) that

$$
\boldsymbol{\Psi}_{T}^{T^{\prime}}(\xi):=\left[\begin{array}{c}
T^{s} \psi_{T^{\prime}}^{*}(T+\operatorname{Th}(\xi), T \xi) \\
T^{s+1}\left(\partial_{0} \psi_{T^{\prime}}^{*}\right)(T+\operatorname{Th}(\xi), T \xi)
\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{c}
\psi^{*}\left(\frac{T^{\prime}}{T}-1-h(\xi), \xi\right) \\
-\left(\partial_{0} \psi^{*}\right)\left(\frac{T}{T}-1-h(\xi), \xi\right)
\end{array}\right]
$$

Taylor's theorem gives

$$
\boldsymbol{\Psi}_{T}^{1}(\xi)-\boldsymbol{\Psi}_{T}^{T}(\xi)=(1-T)\left.\partial_{T^{\prime}} \boldsymbol{\Psi}_{T}^{T^{\prime}}(\xi)\right|_{T^{\prime}=T}+(1-T)^{2} \mathbf{r}(T, \xi)
$$

where

$$
\left.\partial_{T^{\prime}} \boldsymbol{\Psi}_{T}^{T^{\prime}}(\xi)\right|_{T^{\prime}=T}=\left[\begin{array}{c}
\left(\partial_{0} \psi^{*}\right)(-h(\xi), \xi) \\
-\left(\partial_{0}^{2} \psi^{*}\right)(-h(\xi), \xi)
\end{array}\right]=\mathbf{f}_{1}^{*}(\xi)
$$

and the integral remainder

$$
\mathbf{r}(T, \xi)=\int_{0}^{1}\left.\partial_{T^{\prime}}^{2} \boldsymbol{\Psi}_{T}^{T^{\prime}}(\xi)\right|_{T^{\prime}=T+z(1-T)}(1-z) \mathrm{d} z
$$

defines a jointly smooth function.

4.5. Stable global wave evolution. The parameter for the blowup time has entered through the initial data operator from Definition 4.4 in the analysis of the stability problem in similarity coordinates. By adjusting this parameter, we can remove the correction term which has stabilized the evolution in Proposition 4.3. This yields the existence of stable solutions to the abstract Cauchy problem (4.17) which evolve from perturbations of the self-similar blowup solution posed at time $t=0$.

Proposition 4.4. Let $d, k \in \mathbb{N}$ and $R>r>0$ be as in Definitions 4.1 and 4.4. Then, there are constants $\delta^{*}>0$ and $C^{*} \geq 1$ such that for all $0<\delta \leq \delta^{*}$ and $C \geq C^{*}$ and all $\boldsymbol{f} \in\left(C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right) \cap C_{\mathrm{c}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}_{r}^{d}\right)\right)^{2}$ with $\|\boldsymbol{f}\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right) \times H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)} \leq \frac{\delta}{C^{2}}$ there exists a $T^{*} \in\left[1-\frac{\delta}{C}, 1+\frac{\delta}{C}\right]$ and a unique $\mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T^{*}} \in C\left([0, \infty), \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)\right)$ with $\left\|\mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T^{*}}(\tau)\right\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} \leq \delta \mathrm{e}^{-\omega \tau}$ and

$$
\mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T^{*}}(\tau)=\mathbf{S}(\tau) \mathbf{U}\left(\boldsymbol{f}, T^{*}\right)+\int_{0}^{\tau} \mathbf{S}\left(\tau-\tau^{\prime}\right) \mathbf{N}\left(\mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T^{*}}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} \tau^{\prime}
$$

for all $\tau \geq 0$. In particular, $\mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T^{*}} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{(0, \infty) \times \mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$ with

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
\partial_{\tau} \mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T^{*}}(\tau, .) & =\mathbf{L u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T^{*}}(\tau, .)+\mathbf{N}\left(\mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T^{*}}(\tau, .)\right) \\
\mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T^{*}}(0, .) & =\mathbf{U}\left(\boldsymbol{f}, T^{*}\right)
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

Proof. Pick $\delta_{0}>0$ and $C_{0} \geq 1$ from Proposition 4.3. For now, let $0<\delta^{*} \leq \delta_{0}$ and $C^{*} \geq C_{0}$ be arbitrary but fixed and let

$$
0<\delta \leq \delta^{*} \quad \text { and } \quad C \geq C^{*}
$$

Let $\boldsymbol{f} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2} \cap C_{\mathrm{c}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}_{r}^{d}\right)^{2}$ with $\|\boldsymbol{f}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} \leq \frac{\delta}{C^{2}}$. If $C^{*} \geq C_{0}$ is large enough, Lemma 4.4 yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|\mathbf{U}(\boldsymbol{f}, T)\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} & \leq\left\|\boldsymbol{f}_{T}\right\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}+|T-1|\left\|\mathbf{f}_{1}^{*}\right\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}+|T-1|^{2}\|\mathbf{r}(T, .)\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \leq \frac{\delta}{C_{0}}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $T \in\left[1-\frac{\delta}{C}, 1+\frac{\delta}{C}\right]$ and so $\mathbf{U}(\boldsymbol{f}, T) \in \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)$ satisfies the assumptions for the initial data in Proposition 4.3. Thus, for any $T \in\left[1-\frac{\delta}{C}, 1+\frac{\delta}{C}\right]$ there is a $\mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T} \in C\left([0, \infty), \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)\right)$ satisfying $\left\|\mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T}(\tau)\right\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} \leq \delta \mathrm{e}^{-\omega \tau}$ and

$$
\mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T}(\tau)=\mathbf{S}(\tau)\left(\mathbf{U}(\boldsymbol{f}, T)-\mathbf{C}\left(\mathbf{U}(\boldsymbol{f}, T), \mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T}\right)\right)+\int_{0}^{\tau} \mathbf{S}\left(\tau-\tau^{\prime}\right) \mathbf{N}\left(\mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} \tau^{\prime}
$$

for all $\tau \geq 0$. Note that this solution depends continuously on the parameter $T \in\left[1-\frac{\delta}{C}, 1+\frac{\delta}{C}\right]$ for the blowup time due to the continuous dependence on the initial data in Proposition 4.3 and Lemma 4.4. In the rest of the proof, we extract such a time parameter along with a solution for which the corresponding correction term vanishes. Since $\mathbf{C}\left(\mathbf{U}(\boldsymbol{f}, T), \mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T}\right) \in \operatorname{ran}\left(\mathbf{P}_{1}\right)$ and $\operatorname{ran}\left(\mathbf{P}_{1}\right)=\left\langle\mathbf{f}_{1}^{*}\right\rangle$ according to Proposition 3.5, it is sufficient to prove that the continuous function

$$
\left[1-\frac{\delta}{C}, 1+\frac{\delta}{C}\right] \rightarrow \mathbb{R}, \quad T \mapsto T+\left(\mathbf{C}\left(\mathbf{U}(\boldsymbol{f}, T), \mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T}\right) \mid \mathbf{g}_{1}^{*}\right)_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}
$$

where we set $\mathbf{g}_{1}^{*}:=\mathbf{f}_{1}^{*} /\left\|\mathbf{f}_{1}^{*}\right\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}^{2}$, has a fixed point. Using the expansion for the initial data operator from Lemma 4.4, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\mathbf{C}\left(\mathbf{U}(\boldsymbol{f}, T), \mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T}\right) \mid \mathbf{g}_{1}^{*}\right)_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \quad=\left(\mathbf{P}_{1} \mathbf{U}(\boldsymbol{f}, T) \mid \mathbf{g}_{1}^{*}\right)_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\left(\mathbf{P}_{1} \int_{0}^{\infty} \mathrm{e}^{-\tau^{\prime}} \mathbf{N}\left(\mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} \tau^{\prime} \mid \mathbf{g}_{1}^{*}\right)_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \quad=T^{s}\left(\mathbf{P}_{1} \boldsymbol{f}(T .) \mid \mathbf{g}_{1}^{*}\right)_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}+(1-T)+(1-T)^{2}\left(\mathbf{P}_{1} \mathbf{r}(T, .) \mid \mathbf{g}_{1}^{*}\right)_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \quad+\left(\mathbf{P}_{1} \int_{0}^{\infty} \mathrm{e}^{-\tau^{\prime}} \mathbf{N}\left(\mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} \tau^{\prime} \mid \mathbf{g}_{1}^{*}\right)_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

Together with the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, Lemma 4.1 and Proposition 4.3, we estimate

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|T+\left(\mathbf{C}(\mathbf{U}(\boldsymbol{f}, T), \mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T})\left|\mathbf{g}_{1}^{*}\right\rangle_{\hbar^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}-1\right| \\
& \quad \lesssim\|\boldsymbol{f}\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right) \times H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)}+|T-1|^{2}+\int_{0}^{\infty} \mathrm{e}^{-\tau^{\prime}}\left\|\mathbf{N}\left(\mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)\right)\right\|_{\hbar^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} \mathrm{d} \tau^{\prime} \\
& \quad \lesssim \frac{\delta}{C^{2}}+\frac{\delta^{2}}{C^{2}}+\delta^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $T \in\left[1-\frac{\delta}{C}, 1+\frac{\delta}{C}\right]$. Thus, we can fix $C^{*} \geq C_{0}$ large enough and $0<\delta^{*} \leq \delta_{0}$ small enough such that the map in (4.18) becomes a continuous self-map for any $0<\delta \leq \delta^{*}$ and $C \geq C^{*}$. Thus, this map has a fixed point $T^{*} \in\left[1-\frac{\delta}{C}, 1+\frac{\delta}{C}\right]$ by a consequence of the intermediate value theorem. Uniqueness of the associated mild solution $\mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T^{*}} \in C\left([0, \infty), S_{\text {rad }}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)\right)$ follows from Grönwall's inequality. Joint smoothness $\mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T^{*}} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{(0, \infty) \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$ of the solution follows from Proposition 4.2.

# 5. Proof of the main results 

Here, we employ similarity coordinates to transform the solution of the abstract Cauchy problem into a solution of the nonlinear stability problem for the corotational wave maps equation and equivariant Yang-Mills equation in spacetime regions beyond light cones.
5.1. Proof of Theorem 2.1. In the final step of our construction, we extend the solution in the image region of similarity coordinates by the solution outside of this region via finite speed of propagation. To ensure that the resulting map is smooth and solves the Cauchy problem, we recall the following version of finite speed of propagation for semilinear wave equations, also see Figure 2 for an illustration.
Lemma 5.1. Let $\chi_{T}: \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{1, d}$ be similarity coordinates as in Definition 2.1. Let $R \geq R_{0}$, where $R_{0}>0$ is determined in Lemma A. 5 and consider the spacetime regions

$$
\mathrm{X}_{T, R}^{1, d}=\chi_{T}\left((0, \infty) \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right), \quad \Sigma_{T, R}^{1, d}(\tau)=\chi_{T}\left(\{\tau\} \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)
$$

For fixed $0<\rho_{0}<R$ set $\left(t_{0}, r_{0}\right)=\left(T+T \widetilde{h}\left(\rho_{0}\right), T \rho_{0}\right) \in \Sigma_{T, R}^{1, d}(0)$ and define the domain

$$
\Lambda^{1, d}\left(t_{0}, r_{0}\right)=\left\{(t, x) \in \mathbb{R}^{1, d}| | t-t_{0} \mid+r_{0}<|x|\right\}
$$

Assume that $\psi^{\mathrm{I}}, \psi^{\mathbb{I}} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathrm{X}}_{T, R}^{1, d}\right)$ are solutions to the semilinear wave equation

$$
(\square \psi)(t, x)+F(x, \psi(t, x))=0 \quad \text { in } \mathrm{X}_{T, R}^{1, d}
$$

with

$$
\left.\left(\psi^{\mathrm{I}}, \partial_{0} \psi^{\mathrm{I}}\right)\right|_{\Sigma_{T, R}^{1, d}(0) \cap \Lambda^{1, d}\left(t_{0}, r_{0}\right)}=\left.\left(\psi^{\mathbb{I}}, \partial_{0} \psi^{\mathbb{I}}\right)\right|_{\Sigma_{T, R}^{1, d}(0) \cap \Lambda^{1, d}\left(t_{0}, r_{0}\right)}
$$

Then $\psi^{\mathrm{I}}=\psi^{\mathbb{I}}$ in $\mathrm{X}_{T, R}^{1, d} \cap \Lambda^{1, d}\left(t_{0}, r_{0}\right)$.
Proof. The assumptions on the similarity coordinates and Lemmas A. 3 and A. 4 imply that $\mathrm{X}_{T, R}^{1, d} \cap \Lambda^{1, d}\left(t_{0}, r_{0}\right)$ is nonempty and foliated by the spacelike hypersurfaces

$$
\Sigma(\tau):=\Sigma_{T, R}^{1, d}(\tau) \cap \Lambda^{1, d}\left(t_{0}, r_{0}\right)=\chi_{T}\left(\{\tau\} \times\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d} \backslash \overline{\mathbb{B}_{\rho}^{d}}\right)\right)
$$

where $\rho_{0} \leq \rho(\tau) \leq R$ is defined implicitly through the equation

$$
\begin{aligned}
r(\tau)=r_{0}+t(\tau)-t_{0} \quad \text { where } \quad & t(\tau)=T+T \mathrm{e}^{-\tau} \widetilde{h}(\rho(\tau)) \\
& r(\tau)=T \mathrm{e}^{-\tau} \rho(\tau)
\end{aligned}
$$

that is,

$$
\rho(\tau)=\mathrm{e}^{\tau}\left(\rho_{0}-\widetilde{h}\left(\rho_{0}\right)\right)+\widetilde{h}(\rho(\tau))
$$

We define the integral along $\Sigma(\tau)$ as in Eq. (2.13). We recall the unit normal vector field of $\Sigma(\tau)$ from (2.12) and the energy-momentum tensor associated to $\psi$ from (2.14) and define an energy

$$
E_{\Sigma}[\psi](\tau):=\int_{\Sigma(\tau)} \mathrm{T}_{0 \mu} N^{\mu}=\left(T \mathrm{e}^{-\tau}\right)^{d-2 s-2} \frac{1}{2} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d} \backslash \overline{\mathbb{R}_{\rho}^{d}(\tau)}}\left(\left|\partial_{\xi} u_{1}\right|^{2}+\left|u_{2}\right|^{2} w\right)
$$

and

$$
u_{1}(\tau, \xi)=\left(T \mathrm{e}^{-\tau}\right)^{s}\left(\psi \circ \chi_{T}\right)(\tau, \xi), \quad u_{2}(\tau, \xi)=\left(T \mathrm{e}^{-\tau}\right)^{s+1}\left(\left(\partial_{0} \psi\right) \circ \chi_{T}\right)(\tau, \xi)
$$

A computation as in Eq. (2.16) and the Leibniz integral rule lead to the identity

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} \tau} E_{\Sigma}[\psi](\tau)=-\left(T \mathrm{e}^{-\tau}\right)^{d-s} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d} \backslash \overline{\mathbb{R}_{\rho}^{d}(\tau)}}\left(\square \psi \circ \chi_{T}\right)(\tau, \cdot)\left(c u_{2}\right) \\
& \quad+\frac{\left(T \mathrm{e}^{-\tau}\right)^{d-2 s-2}}{R} \int_{\partial \mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}}\left(-\frac{|\xi|^{2}}{2}\left(\left|\partial_{\xi} u_{1}\right|^{2}+\left|u_{2}\right|^{2} w\right)-\xi^{i}\left(\partial_{i} h\right) c\left|u_{2}\right|^{2}+\xi^{i}\left(\partial_{i} u_{1}\right)\left(c u_{2}\right)\right) \\
& \quad-\frac{\left(T \mathrm{e}^{-\tau}\right)^{d-2 s-2}}{\rho(\tau)} \int_{\partial \mathbb{R}_{\rho}^{d}(\tau)}\left(-\frac{|\xi|^{2}}{2}\left(\left|\partial_{\xi} u_{1}\right|^{2}+\left|u_{2}\right|^{2} w\right)-\xi^{i}\left(\partial_{i} h\right) c\left|u_{2}\right|^{2}+\xi^{i}\left(\partial_{i} u_{1}\right)\left(c u_{2}\right)\right) \\
& \quad-\left(T \mathrm{e}^{-\tau}\right)^{d-2 s-2} \int_{\partial \mathbb{R}_{\rho}^{d}(\tau)} \frac{\dot{\rho}(\tau)}{2}\left(\left|\partial_{\xi} u_{1}\right|^{2}+\left|u_{2}\right|^{2} w\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We find for the first boundary integral

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\partial \mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}}\left(-\frac{|\xi|^{2}}{2}\left(\left|\partial_{\xi} u_{1}\right|^{2}+\left|u_{2}\right|^{2} w\right)-\xi^{i}\left(\partial_{i} h\right) c\left|u_{2}\right|^{2}+\xi^{i}\left(\partial_{i} u_{1}\right)\left(c u_{2}\right)\right) \\
& \quad \leq \int_{\partial \mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}}\left(-\frac{|\xi|^{2}}{2} w-\xi^{i}\left(\partial_{i} h\right) c+\frac{1}{2} c^{2}\right)\left|u_{2}\right|^{2} \\
& \quad=\frac{\widetilde{h}(R)^{2}-R^{2}}{2} \int_{\partial \mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}}\left|u_{2}\right|^{2} \leq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

by Lemma A. 5 and since $R \geq R_{0}$. To estimate the remaining boundary integrals, we first compute via implicit differentiation

$$
\dot{\rho}(\tau)=\frac{\rho(\tau)-\widetilde{h}(\rho(\tau))}{1-\widetilde{h}^{\prime}(\rho(\tau))}, \quad \text { thus } \quad \rho(\tau)-\dot{\rho}(\tau)=-\frac{\widetilde{c}(\rho(\tau))}{1-\widetilde{h}^{\prime}(\rho(\tau))} \leq \widetilde{h}(0)<0
$$

So we can estimate

$$
\left|\xi^{i}\left(\partial_{i} u_{1}\right)\left(c u_{2}\right)\right| \leq \frac{\rho(\tau) \dot{\rho}(\tau)-\rho(\tau)^{2}}{2}\left|\partial_{\xi} u_{1}\right|^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \frac{\rho(\tau) c^{2}}{\dot{\rho}(\tau)-\rho(\tau)}\left|u_{2}\right|^{2}
$$

for $|\xi|=\rho(\tau)$ and get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1}{\rho(\tau)} \int_{\partial \mathbb{R}_{\rho}^{d}(\tau)}\left(\frac{\rho(\tau)^{2}-\rho(\tau) \dot{\rho}(\tau)}{2}\left(\left|\partial_{\xi} u_{1}\right|^{2}+\left|u_{2}\right|^{2} w\right)+\xi^{i}\left(\partial_{i} h\right) c\left|u_{2}\right|^{2}-\xi^{i}\left(\partial_{i} u_{1}\right)\left(c u_{2}\right)\right) \\
& \quad \leq \int_{\partial \mathbb{R}_{\rho}^{d}(\tau)}\left(\frac{\rho(\tau)-\dot{\rho}(\tau)}{2} w+\widetilde{h}^{\prime} c+\frac{1}{2} \frac{c^{2}}{\dot{\rho}(\tau)-\rho(\tau)}\right)\left|u_{2}\right|^{2}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

This implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} \tau} E_{\Sigma}[\psi](\tau) & \leq-\left(T \mathrm{e}^{-\tau}\right)^{d-s} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d} \backslash \overline{\mathbb{R}_{\rho}^{d}(\tau)}}\left(\square \psi \circ \chi_{T}\right)(\tau, \cdot)\left(c u_{2}\right) \\
& \leq E_{\Sigma}[\psi](\tau)+\frac{1}{2}\left(T \mathrm{e}^{-\tau}\right)^{d-2 s-2}\left\|\left(T \mathrm{e}^{-\tau}\right)^{s+2} \sqrt{\frac{c^{2}}{\widetilde{w}}}\left(\square \psi \circ \chi_{T}\right)(\tau, \cdot)\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d} \backslash \overline{\mathbb{R}_{\rho}^{d}(\tau)}\right)}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $\psi \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathrm{X}}_{T, R}^{1, d}\right)$. Furthermore, we compute

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} \tau} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d} \backslash \overline{\mathbb{R}_{\rho}^{d}(\tau)}}|u_{1}|^{2}=\int_{\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d} \backslash \overline{\mathbb{R}_{\rho}^{d}(\tau)}} \frac{1}{2} \partial_{\tau}\left|u_{1}\right|^{2}-\frac{\dot{\rho}(\tau)}{2} \int_{\partial \mathbb{R}_{\rho}^{d}}|u_{1}|^{2} \\
& \quad=\frac{1}{2}(d-2 s) \int_{\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d} \backslash \overline{\mathbb{R}_{\rho}^{d}(\tau)}}|u_{1}|^{2}+\int_{\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d} \backslash \overline{\mathbb{R}_{\rho}^{d}(\tau)}}\left(c u_{1} u_{2}\right)-\frac{R}{2} \int_{\partial \mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}}|u_{1}|^{2}+\frac{\rho(\tau)-\dot{\rho}(\tau)}{2} \int_{\partial \mathbb{R}_{\rho}^{d}(\tau)}|u_{1}|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

This yields for the total energy

$$
E[\psi](\tau):=\frac{1}{2} \int_{\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d} \backslash \overline{\mathbb{R}_{\rho}^{d}(\tau)}}\left(\left|u_{1}\right|^{2}+\left|\partial_{\xi} u_{1}\right|^{2}+\left|u_{2}\right|^{2} w\right)
$$

the estimate

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} \tau} E[\psi](\tau) \lesssim E[\psi](\tau)+\left\|\left(T \mathrm{e}^{-\tau}\right)^{s+2}\left(\square \psi \circ \chi_{T}\right)(\tau, \cdot)\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d} \backslash \overline{\mathbb{R}_{\rho}^{d}(\tau)}\right)}^{2}
$$

for all $\psi \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathrm{X}}_{T, R}^{1, d}\right)$ and all $0 \leq \tau \leq \rho^{-1}(R)$. Now, we apply the energy estimate (5.1) to the difference of the solutions $\psi^{\mathrm{I}}, \psi^{\mathrm{II}}$ to the semilinear wave equation. Since $F \in C^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathbb{R}\right)$ is locally Lipschitz continuous in the second argument, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\left(T \mathrm{e}^{-\tau}\right)^{s+2}\left(\square\left(\psi^{\mathrm{I}}-\psi^{\mathrm{II}}\right) \circ \chi_{T}\right)(\tau, \cdot)\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d} \backslash \overline{\mathbb{R}_{\rho}^{d}(\tau)}\right)}^{2} & =\left\|F\left(\cdot, u_{1}^{\mathrm{I}}(\tau, \cdot)\right)-F\left(\cdot, u_{1}^{\mathrm{II}}(\tau, \cdot)\right)\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d} \backslash \overline{\mathbb{R}_{\rho}^{d}(\tau)}\right)} \\
& \lesssim E\left[\psi^{\mathrm{I}}-\psi^{\mathrm{II}}\right](\tau)
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $0 \leq \tau \leq \rho^{-1}(R)$. Grönwall's inequality implies $E\left[\psi^{\mathrm{I}}-\psi^{\mathrm{II}}\right](\tau)=0$ from which we conclude the assertion of the lemma.

We employ a fixed height function $h \in C_{\text {rad }}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ as in Definition 1.1 and are set to translate our nonlinear stability theory back to the classical setting.

Proof of Theorem 2.1. Pick $\delta^{*}>0$ and $C^{*} \geq 1$ from Proposition 4.4 and let $0<\delta \leq \delta^{*}$ and $C \geq C^{*}$ be arbitrary but fixed. Then, for any data $(f, g):=\boldsymbol{f} \in C_{\text {rad }}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$ with $\operatorname{supp}(f, g) \subset \mathbb{B}_{r}^{d}$ and $\|(f, g)\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right) \times H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)} \leq \delta / C^{2}$ there exist a blowup time $T^{*} \in\left[1-\frac{\delta}{C}, 1+\frac{\delta}{C}\right]$ and a unique solution

$$
\mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T^{*}} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{(0, \infty) \times \mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2} \quad \text { with } \quad\left\|\mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T^{*}}(\tau)\right\|_{\mathbb{R}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} \leq \delta \mathrm{e}^{-\omega \tau}
$$

to the equation

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
\partial_{\tau} \mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T^{*}}(\tau, \cdot) & =\mathbf{L} \mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T^{*}}(\tau, \cdot)+\mathbf{N}\left(\mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T^{*}}(\tau, \cdot)\right) \\
\mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T^{*}}(0, \cdot) & =\mathbf{U}\left(\boldsymbol{f}, T^{*}\right)
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

for all $\tau \geq 0$, where the initial data $\mathbf{U}\left(\boldsymbol{f}, T^{*}\right)$ are given in Definition 4.4. Fix similarity coordinates $\chi_{T^{*}}: \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{1, d}$ for the given height function and recall from Remarks 1.1 to 1.3 the spacetime regions

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Omega_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(\kappa)=\left\{(t, x) \in \mathbb{R}^{1, d} \mid 0<t<T^{*}+\kappa|x|\right\} \\
& \mathrm{X}_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(\kappa)=\left\{(t, x) \in \mathbb{R}^{1, d} \mid T^{*}+T^{*} h\left(\frac{x}{T^{*}}\right)<t<T^{*}+\kappa|x|\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

also see Figure 1. With this, we define

$$
u \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathrm{X}}_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(\kappa)\right) \quad \text { through } \quad\left(u \circ \chi_{T^{*}}\right)(\tau, \xi)=\left(\frac{\mathrm{e}^{\tau}}{T^{*}}\right)^{s}\left[\mathbf{u}_{\boldsymbol{f}, T^{*}}\right]_{1}(\tau, \xi)
$$

and

$$
\psi \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathrm{X}}_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(\kappa)\right) \quad \text { by } \quad \psi=\psi_{T^{*}}^{*}+u
$$

Note that $u(t, \cdot)$ and $\psi(t, \cdot)$ are smooth and radially symmetric. Lemma 2.1 immediately gives

$$
\square \psi+F(\cdot, \psi)=\square u+\mathcal{V}_{T^{*}} u+\mathcal{N}_{T^{*}}(u)=0 \quad \text { in } \mathrm{X}_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(\kappa)
$$

By construction of the initial data for the abstract Cauchy problem, the evaluation of $\psi, \partial_{0} \psi$ along the initial hypersurface

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Sigma_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(0) & =\chi_{T^{*}}\left(\{0\} \times \overline{\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}}\right) \\
& =\left\{\left(t_{0}(x), x\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{1, d} \mid x \in \overline{\mathbb{B}_{T^{*} R}^{d}}\right\}, \quad \text { where } \quad t_{0}(x)=T^{*}+T^{*} h\left(\frac{x}{T^{*}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi\left(t_{0}(x), x\right) & =\left(\psi \circ \chi_{T^{*}}\right)\left(0, \frac{x}{T^{*}}\right) \\
& =\left(\psi_{T^{*}}^{*} \circ \chi_{T^{*}}\right)\left(0, \frac{x}{T^{*}}\right)+\left(T^{*}\right)^{-s}\left[\mathbf{u}_{f, T^{*}}\right]_{1}\left(0, \frac{x}{T^{*}}\right) \\
& =f(x)+\psi_{1}^{*}\left(t_{0}(x), x\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
(\partial_{0} \psi)\left(t_{0}(x), x\right) & =\left(\left(\partial_{0} \psi\right) \circ \chi_{T^{*}}\right)\left(0, \frac{x}{T^{*}}\right) \\
& =\left(\left(\partial_{0} \psi_{T^{*}}^{*}\right) \circ \chi_{T^{*}}\right)\left(0, \frac{x}{T^{*}}\right)+\left(T^{*}\right)^{-s-1}\left[\mathbf{u}_{f, T^{*}}\right]_{2}\left(0, \frac{x}{T^{*}}\right) \\
& =g(x)+\left(\partial_{0} \psi_{1}^{*}\right)\left(t_{0}(x), x\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\operatorname{supp}(f, g) \subset \mathbb{B}_{r}^{d}$ and $h \equiv-1$ in $\mathbb{B}_{r+c}^{d}$, we have that $\psi, \partial_{0} \psi$ coincides with $\psi_{1}^{*}, \partial_{0} \psi_{1}^{*}$ on $\Sigma_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(0) \cap \Lambda_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(r)$, respectively, where

$$
\Lambda_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(r)=\left\{(t, x) \in \Omega_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(\kappa) \mid 0<t<|x|-r\right\}
$$

Finite speed of propagation in the version of Lemma 5.1 implies that $\psi$ coincides with $\psi_{1}^{*}$ also in the region $\mathrm{X}_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(\kappa) \cap \Lambda_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(r)$. With this, let us extend the solution (5.2) to

$$
\psi: \Omega_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(\kappa) \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \quad \text { by } \quad \psi:= \begin{cases}\psi_{T^{*}}^{*}+u & \text { in } \mathrm{X}_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(\kappa) \\ \psi_{1}^{*} & \text { in } \Omega_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(\kappa) \backslash \mathrm{X}_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(\kappa)\end{cases}
$$

We check that $\psi$ is smooth in the whole domain $\Omega_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(\kappa)$ by proving that $\psi$ defines a smooth map in an open neighbourhood of $\Sigma_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(0) \backslash\left(\{0\} \times \mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$, also see Figure 2. By design of the similarity coordinates,

$$
\Lambda_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(r)=\left(\mathrm{X}_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(\kappa) \cap \Lambda_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(r)\right) \cup\left(\Omega_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(\kappa) \backslash \mathrm{X}_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(\kappa)\right)
$$

is a relatively open region in $\Omega_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(\kappa)$ which contains $\Sigma_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(0) \backslash\left(\{0\} \times \mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ and from above we infer that $\psi$ and $\psi_{1}^{*}$ coincide in $\Lambda_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(r)$. It follows that $\psi \in C^{\infty}\left(\Omega_{T^{*}}^{1, d}(\kappa)\right)$. As $t_{0}(x)=0$ for $|x|<r$, Eqs. (5.3) and (5.4) show that $\psi$ satisfies the initial data for the Cauchy problem at $t=0$ as well. Hence $\psi$ is the unique solution to the Cauchy problem in the theorem. Finally, we verify the stability estimate. Since

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\psi_{T^{*}}^{*} \circ \chi_{T^{*}}\right)(\tau, \xi) & =\left(\frac{\mathrm{e}^{\tau}}{T^{*}}\right)^{s} \psi^{*}(-h(\xi), \xi) \\
\left(\partial_{0} \psi_{T^{*}}^{*} \circ \chi_{T^{*}}\right)(\tau, \xi) & =-\left(\frac{\mathrm{e}^{\tau}}{T^{*}}\right)^{s+1} \partial_{0} \psi^{*}(-h(\xi), \xi)
\end{aligned}
$$

the stability estimate follows directly from

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\left\|\left(\psi-\psi_{T^{*}}^{*}\right) \circ \chi_{T^{*}}(\tau, \cdot)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}}{\left\|\psi_{T^{*}}^{*} \circ \chi_{T^{*}}(\tau, \cdot)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}} & =\frac{\left\|\left[\mathbf{u}_{f, T^{*}}\right]_{1}(\tau, \cdot)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}}{\left\|\psi^{*}(-h(\cdot), \cdot)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}} \lesssim \delta \mathrm{e}^{-\omega \tau} \\
\frac{\left\|\left(\partial_{0} \psi-\partial_{0} \psi_{T^{*}}^{*}\right) \circ \chi_{T^{*}}(\tau, \cdot)\right\|_{H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}}{\left\|\left(\partial_{0} \psi_{T^{*}}^{*}\right) \circ \chi_{T^{*}}(\tau, \cdot)\right\|_{H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}} & =\frac{\left\|\left[\mathbf{u}_{f, T^{*}}\right]_{2}(\tau, \cdot)\right\|_{H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}}{\left\|\left(\partial_{0} \psi^{*}\right)(-h(\cdot), \cdot)\right\|_{H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}} \lesssim \delta \mathrm{e}^{-\omega \tau}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $\tau \geq 0$. If $k>\frac{d}{2}$, we get additionally from Sobolev embedding

$$
\sup _{\left(t^{\prime}, x^{\prime}\right) \in \Sigma_{T^{*}, R}^{1, d}(\tau)} \frac{\left|\psi\left(t^{\prime}, x^{\prime}\right)-\psi_{T^{*}}^{*}\left(t^{\prime}, x^{\prime}\right)\right|}{\left|\psi_{T^{*}}^{*}\left(t^{\prime}, x^{\prime}\right)\right|} \lesssim\left(T^{*} \mathrm{e}^{-\tau}\right)^{s}\left\|\left(\psi-\psi_{T^{*}}^{*}\right) \circ \chi_{T^{*}}(\tau, \cdot)\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} \lesssim \delta \mathrm{e}^{-\omega \tau}
$$

5.2. Proof of Theorems 1.1 and 1.2. Before we conclude the stability theorem for the corotational wave maps equation, we prove a radial lemma which relates the Sobolev norm of a corotational wave map to the Sobolev norm of its profile.
Lemma 5.2. Let $n, k \in \mathbb{N}$ with $n \geq 3$ and $k \geq \frac{n}{2}+1$. Let

$$
U_{1}^{*}[0]:=\left(U_{1}^{*}(0, \ldots), \partial_{0} U_{1}^{*}(0, \ldots)\right): \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow \mathrm{TS}^{n} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \times \mathbb{R}^{n+1}
$$

be the corotational initial data of the wave map (1.9) with profile

$$
\widetilde{\psi}_{1}^{*}[0]:=\left(\widetilde{\psi}_{1}^{*}(0, \mid . \mid), \partial_{0} \widetilde{\psi}_{1}^{*}(0, \mid . \mid)\right): \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}
$$

given in Eq. (1.13). Let $r>0$ and $0<\varepsilon_{r} \leq \frac{2(n-2)}{(n-2)+r^{2}}$. Then, there is a continuous function $C_{n, k, r, \varepsilon_{r}}:[0, \infty) \rightarrow(0, \infty)$ such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|\left(\widetilde{f}(|.|), \widetilde{g}(|.|)\right)-\widetilde{\psi}_{1}^{*}[0]\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n+2}\right) \times H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n+2}\right)} \\
& \quad \leq C_{n, k, r, \varepsilon_{r}}\left(\left\|\left(F, G\right)-U_{1}^{*}[0]\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right) \times H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)}\right)\left\|\left(F, G\right)-U_{1}^{*}[0]\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right) \times H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all smooth corotational data $(F, G): \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow \mathrm{TS}^{n} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \times \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ given by

$$
F(x)=\binom{|x|^{-1} \sin (|x| \widetilde{f}(|x|)) x}{\cos (|x| \widetilde{f}(|x|))}, \quad G(x)=\binom{\cos (|x| \widetilde{f}(|x|)) \widetilde{g}(|x|) x}{-|x| \sin (|x| \widetilde{f}(|x|)) \widetilde{g}(|x|)}
$$

with $\widetilde{f}, \widetilde{g} \in C_{\mathrm{ev}}^{\infty}([0, \infty))$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
(F, G) & =U_{1}^{*}[0] & & \text { in } \mathbb{R}^{n} \backslash \mathbb{B}_{r}^{n} \\
F^{n+1} & \geq-1+\varepsilon_{r} & & \text { in } \overline{\mathbb{B}_{r}^{n}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. First, note that

$$
F^{i}(x)=\operatorname{si}(|\widetilde{f}(|x|) x|) \widetilde{f}(|x|) x^{i} \quad \text { and } \quad F^{n+1}(x)=\cos (|\widetilde{f}(|x|) x|)
$$

in terms of the analytic sinus cardinalis function given by $\operatorname{si}(\rho)=\sin (\rho) / \rho$ with $\operatorname{si}(0)=1$. Since $F^{n+1}>-1$, we have $0 \leq|\widetilde{f}(|x|) x|<\pi$ for all $|x| \leq r$ by continuity. Thus, the identity

$|\widetilde{f}(|x|) x|=\arccos \left(F^{n+1}(x)\right)$ holds, implying with Eq. (5.5)

$$
\widetilde{f}(|x|) x^{i}=\varphi\left(F^{n+1}(x)\right) F^{i}(x)
$$

for $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$, where

$$
\varphi:(-1,1) \rightarrow \mathbb{R}, \quad z \mapsto \frac{\arccos (z)}{\sqrt{1-z^{2}}}
$$

For $z \in(0,1)$, we note that

$$
\varphi(z)=\frac{\arccos (z)}{\sqrt{1-z^{2}}}=\frac{\arcsin \left(\sqrt{1-z^{2}}\right)}{\sqrt{1-z^{2}}}=\int_{0}^{1} \frac{1}{\sqrt{1+\zeta^{2}\left(z^{2}-1\right)}} \mathrm{d} \zeta
$$

and get that $\varphi$ has an analytic continuation beyond $z=1$. Therefore, all derivatives of $\varphi$ are bounded near $z=1$. Moreover, the identity

$$
\widetilde{g}(|x|) x^{i}=F^{n+1}(x) G^{i}(x)-F^{i}(x) G^{n+1}(x)
$$

holds. Now, we conclude with [97, Theorem 1.3]

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \|\widetilde{f}(|.|)-\widetilde{\psi}_{1}^{*}(0,|.|)\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n+2}\right)} \simeq \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|(.)^{i}(\widetilde{f}(|.|)-\widetilde{\psi}_{1}^{*}(0,|.|))\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)} \\
& \quad \lesssim \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\varphi\left(F^{n+1}\right)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)}\left\|F^{i}-U_{1}^{* i}(0,.)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)}+\left\|\varphi\left(F^{n+1}\right)-\varphi\left(U_{1}^{* n+1}(0,.)\right)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \|\widetilde{g}(|.|)-\partial_{0} \widetilde{\psi}_{1}^{*}(0,|.|)\|_{H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n+2}\right)} \simeq \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|(.)^{i}(\widetilde{g}(|.|)-\partial_{0} \widetilde{\psi}_{1}^{*}(0,|.|))\right\|_{H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)} \\
& \quad \lesssim \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\left\|F^{n+1}\left(G^{i}-\partial_{0} U_{1}^{* i}(0,.)\right)\right\|_{H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)}+\left\|F^{i}\left(G^{n+1}-\partial_{0} U_{1}^{* n+1}(0,.)\right)\right\|_{H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)} \\
& \quad+\left\|\left(F^{n+1}-U_{1}^{* n+1}(0,.)\right) \partial_{0} U_{1}^{* i}(0,.)\right\|_{H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)}+\left\|\left(F^{i}-U_{1}^{* i}(0,.)\right) \partial_{0} U_{1}^{* n+1}(0,.)\right\|_{H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all corotational $(F, G): \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow \mathrm{TS}^{n} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \times \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ as in the assumption. We remark that the assumption $F^{n+1} \geq-1+\varepsilon_{r}$ ensures a uniform bound for terms of the form $\varphi^{(\ell)} \circ F^{n+1}$ while the upper bound for $\varepsilon_{r}>0$ leaves enough room for $F^{n+1}$ to be arbitrarily close to

$$
U_{1}^{* n+1}(0, x)=\frac{(n-2)-|x|^{2}}{(n-2)+|x|^{2}}=-1+\frac{2(n-2)}{(n-2)+|x|^{2}}
$$

From here, the bounds follow from an application of Hölder's inequality and Sobolev embedding like in the proof of Lemma 4.1.

The proofs of the main theorems are an application of Theorem 2.1.
Proof of Theorem 1.1. First, pick $\delta^{*}>0$ and $C^{*} \geq 1$ from Theorem 2.1. There is a constant $C \geq C^{*}$ such that the function from Lemma 5.2 satisfies $C_{n, k, r, \varepsilon_{r}} \leq C$ on $\left[0, \delta^{*} /\left(C^{*}\right)^{3}\right]$. Put $M:=C^{3}$ and let $0<\delta \leq \delta^{*}$. Let $(F, G): \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow \mathrm{TS}^{n} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \times \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ with $f, g \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ be data as in the assumption of the theorem. Let $\widetilde{f}, \widetilde{g} \in C_{\mathrm{ex}}^{\infty}([0, \infty))$ be the respective radial profile of $f, g \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$. We define $f_{0}, g_{0} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n+2}\right)$ by

$$
f_{0}(x)=\widetilde{f}(|x|)-\widetilde{\psi}_{1}^{*}(0,|x|) \quad \text { and } \quad g_{0}(x)=\widetilde{g}(|x|)-\partial_{0} \widetilde{\psi}_{1}^{*}(0,|x|)
$$

for $x \in \mathbb{R}^{n+2}$. Then $\operatorname{supp}\left(f_{0}, g_{0}\right) \subset \mathbb{B}_{r}^{n+2}$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\left(f_{0}, g_{0}\right)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n+2}\right) \times H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n+2}\right)} & \leq C\left\|\left(F, G)-\left(U_{1}^{*}(0,.), \partial_{0} U_{1}^{*}(0,.)\right)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right) \times H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)} \\
& \leq C \frac{\delta}{M}=\frac{\delta}{C^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

by Lemma 5.2. We infer from Theorem 2.1 a $T^{\star} \in\left[1-\frac{\delta}{C}, 1+\frac{\delta}{C}\right]$ and a unique solution $\psi \in C^{\infty}\left(\Omega_{T^{\star}}^{1, n+2}(\kappa)\right)$ to

$$
\begin{aligned}
(\square \psi)(t, x)-\frac{n-1}{2} & \frac{\sin (2|x| \psi(t, x))-2|x| \psi(t, x)}{|x|^{3}}=0 \quad \text { in } \Omega_{T^{\star}}^{1, n+2}(\kappa) \\
\psi(0, .) & =\psi_{1}^{\star}(0, .)+f_{0} \quad \text { and } \quad \partial_{0} \psi(0, .)={ }_{\partial_{0}} \psi_{1}^{\star}(0, .)+g_{0} \quad \text { in } \mathbb{R}^{n+2}
\end{aligned}
$$

which is radially symmetric. Let $\widetilde{\psi}$ be the radial profile of $\psi$ and define in $\mathbb{R}^{1, n}$ the smooth corotational map

$$
U: \Omega_{T^{\star}}^{1, n}(\kappa) \rightarrow \mathbb{S}^{n} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}, \quad U(t, x)=\binom{|x|^{-1} \sin (|x| \widetilde{\psi}(t,|x|)) x}{\cos (|x| \widetilde{\psi}(t,|x|))}
$$

We get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\partial^{\mu} \partial_{\mu} U\right)(t, x)+\left\langle\left(\partial^{\mu} U\right)(t, x),\left(\partial_{\mu} U\right)(t, x)\right\rangle U(t, x) \\
& \quad=\left(-\widetilde{\psi}_{t t}+\widetilde{\psi}_{r r}+\frac{n+1}{r} \widetilde{\psi}_{r}-\frac{n-1}{2} \frac{\sin (2 r \widetilde{\psi})-2 r \widetilde{\psi}}{r^{3}}\right)\binom{\cos (|x| \widetilde{\psi}(t,|x|)) x}{-|x| \sin (|x| \widetilde{\psi}(t,|x|))} \\
& \quad=0
\end{aligned}
$$

as well as $U(0,)=F$ and $\partial_{0} U(0,)=G$ in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$, where we abbreviate $r=|x|$ and

$$
\widetilde{\psi} \equiv \widetilde{\psi}(t, r), \quad \widetilde{\psi}_{r} \equiv \partial_{r} \widetilde{\psi}(t, r), \quad \widetilde{\psi}_{r r} \equiv \partial_{r}^{2} \widetilde{\psi}(t, r), \quad \widetilde{\psi}_{t t} \equiv \partial_{t}^{2} \widetilde{\psi}(t, r)
$$

for $(t, x) \in \mathbb{R}^{1, n}$. Finally, to show the stability estimate for this wave map, we set

$$
\widetilde{u}_{1}(\tau, \rho)=\left(T^{\star} \mathrm{e}^{-\tau}\right)\left(\widetilde{\psi}-\widetilde{\psi}_{T^{\star}}^{\star}\right) \circ\left(T^{\star}+T^{\star} \mathrm{e}^{-\tau} \widetilde{h}(\rho), T^{\star} \mathrm{e}^{-\tau} \rho\right)
$$

for $(\tau, \rho) \in[0, \infty) \times[0, R]$. Note that the stability estimate in Theorem 2.1 asserts

$$
\left\|\widetilde{u}_{1}(\tau, \mid.\mid)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{n+2}\right)} \lesssim \delta \mathrm{e}^{-\omega \tau}
$$

for all $\tau \geq 0$. In terms of this function, an application of the fundamental theorem of calculus implies the identities

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(U^{i}-U_{T^{\star}}^{\star}\right) \circ \chi_{T^{\star}}(\tau, \xi) & =\xi^{i} \widetilde{u}_{1}(\tau,|\xi|) \int_{0}^{1} \cos (|\cdot|) \circ\left(\widetilde{\psi}^{\star}(-\widetilde{h}(|\xi|),|\xi|) \xi+z \widetilde{u}_{1}(\tau,|\xi|) \xi\right) \mathrm{d} z \\
\left(U^{n+1}-U_{T^{\star}}^{\star}\right) \circ \chi_{T^{\star}}(\tau, \xi) & =\xi^{i} \widetilde{u}_{1}(\tau,|\xi|) \int_{0}^{1} \partial_{i} \cos (|\cdot|) \circ\left(\widetilde{\psi}^{\star}(-\widetilde{h}(|\xi|),|\xi|) \xi+z \widetilde{u}_{1}(\tau,|\xi|) \xi\right) \mathrm{d} z
\end{aligned}
$$

for $(\tau, \xi) \in[0, \infty) \times \overline{\mathbb{R}_{R}^{n}}$. As $H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{n}\right)$ is a Sobolev algebra, we get with [97, Theorem 1.3]

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\left(U-U_{T^{\star}}^{\star}\right) \circ \chi_{T^{\star}}(\tau, \cdot)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{n}\right)} & =\sum_{i=1}^{n+1}\left\|\left(U^{i}-U_{T^{\star}}^{\star}\right) \circ \chi_{T^{\star}}(\tau, \cdot)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{n}\right)} \\
& \lesssim \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|(\cdot)^{i} \widetilde{u}_{1}(\tau, \mid.\mid)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{n}\right)} \\
& \simeq\left\|\widetilde{u}_{1}(\tau, \mid.\mid)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{n+2}\right)} \\
& \lesssim \delta \mathrm{e}^{-\omega \tau}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $\tau \geq 0$.
Proof of Theorem 1.2. There are smooth even functions $\widetilde{f}, \widetilde{g} \in C_{\mathrm{ev}}^{\infty}([0, \infty))$ such that the initial data in the theorem are given by

$$
a_{\mu}{ }^{i j}(x)=\widetilde{f}\left(|x|\right)\left(x^{i} \delta_{\mu}{ }^{j}-x^{j} \delta_{\mu}{ }^{i}\right), \quad b_{\mu}{ }^{i j}(x)=\widetilde{g}(|x|)\left(x^{i} \delta_{\mu}{ }^{j}-x^{j} \delta_{\mu}{ }^{i}\right)
$$

in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$. Then [97, Theorem 1.3] yields

$$
\left\|(a, b)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right) \times H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)} \simeq\left\|(\widetilde{f}(|\cdot|), \widetilde{g}(|\cdot|))\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n+2}\right) \times H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n+2}\right)}
$$

According to Theorem 2.1, let $\psi \in C^{\infty}\left(\Omega_{T^{*}}^{1, n+2}(\kappa)\right)$ be the unique solution to the Cauchy problem

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \quad(\square \psi)(t, x)+(n-2)\left(3 \psi(t, x)^{2}-|x|^{2} \psi(t, x)^{3}\right)=0 \quad \text { in } \Omega_{T^{*}}^{1, n+2}(\kappa) \\
& \psi(0, .)=\psi_{1}^{*}(0, .)+\widetilde{f}(|.|) \quad \text { and } \quad \partial_{0} \psi(0, .)=\partial_{0} \psi_{1}^{*}(0, .)+\widetilde{g}(|.|) \quad \text { in } \mathbb{R}^{n+2}
\end{aligned}
$$

The solution $\psi$ is radially symmetric with radial profile $\widetilde{\psi}$ and we set

$$
\begin{aligned}
& A_{\mu}: \Omega_{T^{*}}^{1, n}(\kappa) \rightarrow \mathfrak{s o}(n), \quad A_{\mu}{ }^{i j}(t, x)=\widetilde{\psi}(t,|x|)\left(x^{i} \delta_{\mu}{ }^{j}-x^{j} \delta_{\mu}{ }^{i}\right), \\
& F_{\mu \nu}: \Omega_{T^{*}}^{1, n}(\kappa) \rightarrow \mathfrak{s o}(n), \quad F_{\mu \nu}=\partial_{\mu} A_{\nu}-\partial_{\nu} A_{\mu}+\left[A_{\mu}, A_{\nu}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

for $\mu, \nu=0,1, \ldots, n$. It follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\partial^{\mu} F_{\mu 0}{ }^{i j}+\left[A^{\mu}, F_{\mu 0}\right]^{i j} & =0 \\
\partial^{\mu} F_{\mu \ell}{ }^{i j}+\left[A^{\mu}, F_{\mu \ell}\right]^{i j} & =-\left(-\widetilde{\psi}_{t t}+\widetilde{\psi}_{r r}+\frac{n+1}{r} \widetilde{\psi}_{r}+(n-2)\left(3 \widetilde{\psi}^{2}-r^{2} \widetilde{\psi}^{3}\right)\right)\left(x^{i} \delta_{\ell}^{j}-x^{j} \delta_{\ell}^{i}\right) \\
& =0
\end{aligned}
$$

as well as $A_{\mu}(0,)=A_{1 \mu}^{*}(0,)=a_{\mu}$ and $\partial_{0} A_{\mu}(0,)==\partial_{0} A_{1 \mu}^{*}(0,)+b_{\mu}$. Hence $A_{\mu}$ is a smooth Yang-Mills connection. To infer the stability estimate, we compute

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(A_{\mu}{ }^{i j}-A_{T^{*}}{ }_{\mu}{ }^{i j}\right) \circ \chi_{T^{*}}(\tau, \xi) & =T^{*} \mathrm{e}^{-\tau}\left(\psi-\psi_{T^{*}}^{*}\right) \circ \chi_{T^{*}}(\tau, \xi)\left(\xi^{i} \delta_{\mu}{ }^{j}-\xi^{j} \delta_{\mu}{ }^{i}\right) \\
& =\frac{\mathrm{e}^{\tau}}{T^{*}} \widetilde{u}_{1}(\tau,|\xi|)\left(\xi^{i} \delta_{\mu}{ }^{j}-\xi^{j} \delta_{\mu}{ }^{i}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\widetilde{u}_{1}(\tau, \rho)=\left(T^{*} \mathrm{e}^{-\tau}\right)^{2}\left(\widetilde{\psi}-\widetilde{\psi}_{T^{*}}^{*}\right) \circ\left(T^{*}+T^{*} \mathrm{e}^{-\tau} \widetilde{h}(\rho), T^{*} \mathrm{e}^{-\tau} \rho\right)
$$

for $(\tau, \rho) \in[0, \infty) \times[0, R]$. This gives with the definition of corotational Sobolev norms and [97, Theorem 1.3]

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\left\|\left(A-A_{T^{*}}^{*}\right) \circ \chi_{T^{*}}(\tau, .)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{n}\right)}}{\left\|A_{T^{*}}^{*} \circ \chi_{T^{*}}(\tau, .)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{n}\right)}} & \simeq \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|(.)^{i} \widetilde{u}_{1}(\tau,|.)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{n}\right)} \\
& \simeq\left\|\widetilde{u}_{1}(\tau,|.)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{n+2}\right)} \\
& \lesssim \delta \mathrm{e}^{-\omega \tau}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $\tau \geq 0$.

# Appendix A. Similarity Coordinates 

In this section, we study coordinate systems on Minkowski spacetime $\mathbb{R}^{1, d}$ that are adapted to self-similar solutions of nonlinear wave equations. This property can be formalized quite generally by defining that a map $\chi: \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{1, d}$ is a similarity variable if there exists a function $\lambda: \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ such that

$$
\chi(\tau, \xi)=\lambda(\tau, \xi) \chi(0, \xi)
$$

for all $(\tau, \xi) \in \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d}$. If $\tau$ is interpreted as a time variable and $\xi$ is interpreted as a space variable, this expresses that moving forward along the new time coordinate while the new space coordinate is kept fix, occurs via scaling of an initial reference point. Instead of studying similarity variables in the above generality, we will choose exponential time

$$
\lambda(\tau, \xi)=\mathrm{e}^{-\tau}
$$

for the scaling factor, which becomes convenient for the transformation of differential operators later on. Also, we require compatibility with the wave evolution, that is, hypersurfaces of constant coordinate time shall be spacelike. Since spacelike hypersurfaces in Minkowski spacetime are the image of a graph, we focus on similarity variables of the following form.

Definition A.1. Let $h \in C^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$. We define graphical similarity variables by

$$
\chi: \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{1, d}, \quad \chi(\tau, \xi)=\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\tau} h(\xi), \mathrm{e}^{-\tau} \xi\right)
$$

We remark that by a spacetime translation, graphical similarity variables may be centred around any given event in spacetime. When similarity variables define a coordinate system on their image, we call them similarity coordinates. The function $h$ is referred to as a height function. One of the simplest examples of a height function is given by

$$
h(\xi)=-1
$$

yielding standard similarity coordinates. It is even possible to cover the whole complement of a future light cone with similarity coordinates. This is demonstrated in [2] with hyperboloidal similarity coordinates and a height function of the form

$$
h(\xi)=\alpha \sqrt{1+\alpha^{-2}|\xi|^{2}}-\alpha-\beta
$$

for some $\alpha \geq 1, \beta>0$. The examples in Eqs. (A.1) and (A.2) already bear the characterising properties of height functions in order to yield similarity coordinates on the complement of a cone, which we discuss next.
A.1. Geometry of graphical similarity coordinates. We impose a convexity condition on the height function in Definition A. 1 and introduce an auxiliary function to determine the geometry of graphical similarity variables.

Lemma A.1. Let $h \in C^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ with $h(0)<0$ and with positive semidefinite Hessian $\left(\partial^{2} h\right)(\xi)$ for all $\xi \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. Consider the smooth map $F \in C^{\infty}\left((0, \infty) \times \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ given by

$$
F(\alpha, \beta, \xi)=\alpha h\left(\alpha^{-1} \xi\right)-\beta
$$

Then, for each $(\beta, \xi) \in \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d}$ the map $F(., \beta, \xi):(0, \infty) \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is strictly monotonously decreasing and the scaling relation

$$
F(\alpha, \lambda \beta, \lambda \xi)=\lambda F\left(\lambda^{-1} \alpha, \beta, \xi\right)
$$

holds for all $\lambda>0$.
Proof. First, consider the smooth function $c \in C^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ given by

$$
c(\xi)=\xi^{i}\left(\partial_{i} h\right)(\xi)-h(\xi)
$$

Let $z \geq 0$. Then

$$
\partial_{z} c(z \xi)=z \xi^{i} \xi^{j}\left(\partial_{i} \partial_{j} h\right)(z \xi) \geq 0 \quad \text { implies } \quad c(\xi) \geq c(0)=-h(0)>0
$$

for all $\xi \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. We find

$$
\partial_{\alpha} F(\alpha, \beta, \xi)=-c\left(\alpha^{-1} \xi\right) \leq h(0)<0
$$

so $F(., \beta, \xi)$ is strictly monotonously decreasing. The scaling relation follows from

$$
F(\alpha, \lambda \beta, \lambda \xi)=\alpha h\left(\alpha^{-1} \lambda \xi\right)-\lambda \beta=\lambda\left(\left(\lambda^{-1} \alpha\right) h\left(\left(\lambda^{-1} \alpha\right)^{-1} \xi\right)-\beta\right)=\lambda F\left(\lambda^{-1} \alpha, \beta, \xi\right)
$$

If the height function satisfies the assumptions of Lemma A.1, then graphical similarity variables provide a coordinate system on their image.

Lemma A.2. Let $h \in C^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ with $h(0)<0$ and positive semidefinite Hessian $\left(\partial^{2} h\right)(\xi)$ for all $\xi \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. Then, the image $\mathrm{X}^{1, d} \subset \mathbb{R}^{1, d}$ of similarity variables $\chi: \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{1, d}$ is open and

$$
\chi: \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathrm{X}^{1, d}, \quad \chi(\tau, \xi)=\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\tau} h(\xi), \mathrm{e}^{-\tau} \xi\right)
$$

is a diffeomorphism with inverse

$$
\chi^{-1}: \mathrm{X}^{1, d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d}, \quad \chi^{-1}(t, x)=\left(-\log h^{+}(t, x), h^{+}(t, x)^{-1} x\right)
$$

for a positive function $h^{+} \in C^{\infty}\left(\mathrm{X}^{1, d}\right)$. Moreover, if $(t, x) \in \mathrm{X}^{1, d}$, then for any $\lambda>0$ also $(\lambda t, \lambda x) \in \mathrm{X}^{1, d}$ and

$$
h^{+}(\lambda t, \lambda x)=\lambda h^{+}(t, x)
$$

Proof. According to the inverse function theorem, it suffices to show that $\chi$ is an injective local diffeomorphism. The assumptions on $h$ yield with Taylor's theorem

$$
h(\xi)-\xi^{i}(\partial_{i} h)(\xi)=h(0)-\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{1} \xi^{i} \xi^{j}\left(\partial_{i} \partial_{j} h\right)((1-z) \xi)(1-z) \mathrm{d} z \leq h(0)<0
$$

and hence the Jacobian determinant

$$
\operatorname{det}(\partial \chi)(\tau, \xi)=\mathrm{e}^{-(d+1) \tau}\left(\xi^{i}\left(\partial_{i} h\right)(\xi)-h(\xi)\right)
$$

vanishes nowhere. So $\chi$ is a local diffeomorphism. To show that $\chi$ is injective, suppose that $\left(\tau_{1}, \xi_{1}\right),\left(\tau_{2}, \xi_{2}\right) \in \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d}$ with $\chi\left(\tau_{1}, \xi_{1}\right)=\chi\left(\tau_{2}, \xi_{2}\right)$. This gives

$$
\mathrm{e}^{-\tau_{1}} h\left(\xi_{1}\right)=\mathrm{e}^{-\tau_{2}} h\left(\xi_{2}\right), \quad \mathrm{e}^{-\tau_{1}} \xi_{1}=\mathrm{e}^{-\tau_{2}} \xi_{2}
$$

which implies

$$
h\left(\xi_{1}\right)=\mathrm{e}^{\tau_{1}-\tau_{2}} h\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\left(\tau_{1}-\tau_{2}\right)} \xi_{1}\right) \quad \text { or equivalently } \quad F\left(1,0, \xi_{1}\right)=F\left(\mathrm{e}^{\tau_{1}-\tau_{2}}, 0, \xi_{1}\right)
$$

in terms of the function $F$ from Lemma A.1. Strict monotonicity of $F$ in the first argument yields $\tau_{1}=\tau_{2}$ and so $\chi$ is injective. Next, let $(\tau, \xi) \in \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and set $(t, x)=\chi(\tau, \xi)$. That is,

$$
t=\mathrm{e}^{-\tau} h(\xi), \quad x=\mathrm{e}^{-\tau} \xi
$$

which implies

$$
\mathrm{e}^{-\tau} h\left(\mathrm{e}^{\tau} x\right)-t=0
$$

In terms of the function $F$ from Lemma A.1, this condition means that $F(., t, x)$ has a unique zero $\alpha=h^{+}(t, x)>0$ which satisfies

$$
\tau=-\log h^{+}(t, x), \quad \xi=\frac{1}{h^{+}(t, x)} x
$$

Finally, note that $(t, x)=\chi(\tau, \xi)$ gives $(\lambda t, \lambda x)=\chi(\tau-\log \lambda, \xi)$. Then $h^{+}(\lambda t, \lambda x)$ is the unique zero of $F(., \lambda t, \lambda x)$ and the scaling condition in Lemma A. 1 yields

$$
0=F\left(h^{+}(\lambda t, \lambda x), \lambda t, \lambda x\right)=\lambda F\left(\lambda^{-1} h^{+}(\lambda t, \lambda x), t, x\right)
$$

so by uniqueness $\lambda^{-1} h^{+}(\lambda t, \lambda x)=h^{+}(t, x)$.
Some geometric quantities of Minkowski spacetime are computed in similarity coordinates in [34, Appendix A]. Next, let us also study the time slices of graphical similarity variables.

Lemma A.3. Let $h \in C^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ with $|(\partial h)(\xi)|<1$ for all $\xi \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. Then, for all $\tau \in \mathbb{R}$ the level set

$$
\Sigma^{1, d}(\tau)=\chi\left(\{\tau\} \times \mathbb{R}^{d}\right)
$$

is a smooth spacelike hypersurface in $\mathbb{R}^{1, d}$. The matrix of the first fundamental form of $\Sigma^{1, d}(\tau)$ and its inverse matrix have components

$$
\gamma(\tau)_{i j}=\mathrm{e}^{-2 \tau}\left(\delta_{i j}-\left(\partial_{i} h\right)\left(\partial_{j} h\right)\right), \quad \gamma(\tau)^{i j}=\mathrm{e}^{2 \tau}\left(\delta^{i j}+\frac{\left(\partial^{i} h\right)\left(\partial^{j} h\right)}{1-|\partial h|^{2}}\right)
$$

respectively, and metric determinant

$$
\operatorname{det} \gamma(\tau)=\mathrm{e}^{-2 d \tau}\left(1-|\partial h|^{2}\right)
$$

Moreover, for all $\tau \in \mathbb{R}$,

$$
\nu(\tau)=\frac{(1, \partial h)}{\sqrt{1-|\partial h|^{2}}} \in C^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}, \mathbb{R}^{1, d}\right)
$$

defines the components of a future-directed timelike unit normal vector field for $\Sigma^{1, d}(\tau)$.

Proof. For each $\tau \in \mathbb{R}$, the smooth map

$$
\chi(\tau, \cdot): \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{1, d}, \quad \xi \mapsto\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\tau} h(\xi), \mathrm{e}^{-\tau} \xi\right)
$$

defines a chart for $\Sigma^{1, d}(\tau)$. Hence, $\Sigma^{1, d}(\tau)$ is a $d$-dimensional smooth submanifold of $\mathbb{R}^{1, d}$. The components of the pullback of the Minkowski metric $\eta$ on $\mathbb{R}^{1, d}$ under $\Sigma^{1, d}(\tau)$ are given by

$$
\gamma(\tau)_{i j}=\eta\left(\partial_{i} \chi(\tau, \cdot), \partial_{j} \chi(\tau, \cdot)\right)=\mathrm{e}^{-2 \tau}\left(\delta_{i j}-\left(\partial_{i} h\right)\left(\partial_{j} h\right)\right)
$$

If $(\partial h)(\xi)=0$, this matrix is a multiple of the identity matrix. If $(\partial h)(\xi) \neq 0$, the matrix has the $(d-1)$-fold eigenvalue $\mathrm{e}^{-2 \tau}$ with eigenvectors orthogonal to $(\partial h)(\xi) \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and the simple eigenvalue $\mathrm{e}^{-2 \tau}\left(1-|(\partial h)(\xi)|^{2}\right)$ with eigenvector $(\partial h)(\xi) \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. Since $|(\partial h)(\xi)|<1$, the matrix is positive definite and thus $\Sigma^{1, d}(\tau)$ is a smooth spacelike hypersurface. The product of these eigenvalues gives the formula for the metric determinant. The inverse of the matrix $\gamma(\tau)$ can be computed from a Neumann series. Finally, we have

$$
\eta\left(\partial_{i} \chi(\tau, \cdot), \nu(\tau)\right)=0, \quad \eta(\nu(\tau), \nu(\tau))=-1
$$

for $i=1, \ldots, d$.
It follows that the image of similarity coordinates is foliated by its time slices. This foliation also covers future lightlike infinity in the following sense.
Lemma A.4. Let $h \in C^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ such that

$$
h(0)<0, \quad|(\partial h)(\xi)|<1, \quad\left(\partial^{2} h\right)(\xi) \text { is positive semidefinite, }
$$

for all $\xi \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. Let $\tau \neq \tau^{\prime}$. Then $\Sigma^{1, d}(\tau)$ is not asymptotic to $\Sigma^{1, d}\left(\tau^{\prime}\right)$.
Proof. Note that for fixed $\tau \in \mathbb{R}$, each level set

$$
\Sigma^{1, d}(\tau)=\left\{\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\tau} h\left(\mathrm{e}^{\tau} \xi\right), \xi\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{1, d} \mid \xi \in \mathbb{R}^{d}\right\}
$$

from Lemma A. 3 is the graph of the function $\xi \mapsto \mathrm{e}^{-\tau} h\left(\mathrm{e}^{\tau} \xi\right)=F\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\tau}, 0, \xi\right)$, where $F$ is defined in Lemma A.1. We show that none of these graphs are asymptotic to each other. As in the proof of Lemma A.1, we compute

$$
\partial_{\tau} F\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\tau}, 0, \xi\right)=\xi^{i}\left(\partial_{i} h\right)\left(\mathrm{e}^{\tau} \xi\right)-h\left(\mathrm{e}^{\tau} \xi\right) \geq-\mathrm{e}^{-\tau} h(0)
$$

for all $(\tau, \xi) \in \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and conclude for $\tau \neq \tau^{\prime}$ that

$$
F\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\tau}, 0, \xi\right)-F\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\tau^{\prime}}, 0, \xi\right) \geq-h(0)\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\tau^{\prime}}-\mathrm{e}^{-\tau}\right)>0
$$

for all $\xi \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$.
A.2. Radially symmetric height functions. So far, we have formulated conditions for graphical similarity variables to yield a coordinate system on their image. Here, we describe the image in case the height function is radially symmetric. We begin with locating the backward light cone of the origin in similarity coordinates.
Lemma A.5. Let $h \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ with $h(0)<0$ and $|(\partial h)(\xi)|<1$ for all $\xi \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and with radial profile $\widetilde{h} \in C_{\mathrm{ev}}^{\infty}([0, \infty))$. Then, the function

$$
[0, \infty) \rightarrow \mathbb{R}, \quad \rho \mapsto \widetilde{h}(\rho)^{2}-\rho^{2}
$$

is strictly monotonously decreasing and has a unique simple zero $R_{0}>0$.
Proof. The assumptions imply $0 \leq \widetilde{h}^{\prime}(\rho)<1$ and $\widetilde{h}(\rho)<\rho$. This gives $\widetilde{h}(\rho) \widetilde{h}^{\prime}(\rho)-\rho<0$ for all $\rho>0$ and so $\rho \mapsto \widetilde{h}(\rho)^{2}-\rho^{2}$ is strictly monotonously decreasing. Since $\widetilde{h}^{\prime}(\rho)-1<0$ and $\widetilde{h}(0)<0$, we have $\widetilde{h}(\rho)-\rho<0$ for all $\rho \geq 0$. Because $\widetilde{h}(0)+\rho<\widetilde{h}(\rho)+\rho<2 \rho$ and $\widetilde{h}^{\prime}(\rho)+1>1$, there is a unique $R_{0}>0$ such that $\widetilde{h}\left(R_{0}\right)+R_{0}=0$. This is the unique zero of $\widetilde{h}^{2}(\rho)-\rho^{2}=(\widetilde{h}(\rho)+\rho)(\widetilde{h}(\rho)-\rho)$.

The image of similarity coordinates with a radially symmetric height function is the complement of a cone.

Lemma A.6. Let $h \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ such that

$$
h(0)<0, \quad|(\partial h)(\xi)|<1, \quad\left(\partial^{2} h\right)(\xi) \text { is positive semidefinite, }
$$

for all $\xi \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and with radial profile $\widetilde{h} \in C_{\mathrm{ev}}^{\infty}([0, \infty))$. Let $R>0$. Then, graphical similarity coordinates $\chi: \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{1, d}$ have the image regions

$$
\begin{aligned}
\chi\left(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d}\right) & =\left\{(t, x) \in \mathbb{R}^{1, d}|\kappa| x \mid>t\right\} \\
\chi\left(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) & =\left\{(t, x) \in \mathbb{R}^{1, d}\left|\kappa_{R}\right| x \mid>t\right\} \\
\chi\left((0, \infty) \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) & =\left\{(t, x) \in \mathbb{R}^{1, d}\left|\kappa_{R}\right| x \mid>t>\widetilde{h}(|x|)\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\kappa=\lim _{\rho \rightarrow \infty} \widetilde{h}^{\prime}(\rho) \quad \text { and } \quad \kappa_{R}=\frac{\widetilde{h}(R)}{R}
$$

Proof. Lemma A. 2 yields that $\chi: \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{1, d}$ are coordinates on their image. Now, suppose $(t, x) \in \mathbb{R}^{1, d}$ with $(t, x)=\chi(\tau, \xi)$ for some $(\tau, \xi) \in \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d}$. If $x=0$ then $\xi=0$ and $t=\mathrm{e}^{-\tau} \widetilde{h}(0)<0$. If $x \neq 0$, then

$$
\frac{t}{|x|}=\frac{\widetilde{h}(|\xi|)}{|\xi|}
$$

Since the map $(0, \infty) \ni \rho \mapsto \rho^{-1} \widetilde{h}(\rho)$ is strictly monotonously increasing by Lemma A. 1 with

$$
\lim _{\rho \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\widetilde{h}(\rho)}{\rho}=\lim _{\rho \rightarrow \infty} \widetilde{h}^{\prime}(\rho)=: \kappa \in[0,1]
$$

we get $\kappa|x|>t$. If additionally $0<|\xi|<R$ and $\tau>0$ we conclude from strict monotonicity that $\kappa_{R}|x|>t$. On the other hand, fix $(t, x) \in \mathbb{R}^{1, d}$ with $\kappa|x|>t$ and consider the map $\tau \mapsto F\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\tau}, t, x\right)=\mathrm{e}^{-\tau} \widetilde{h}\left(\mathrm{e}^{\tau}|x|\right)-t$. By Lemma A.1, this map is strictly monotonously increasing and we have

$$
\lim _{\tau \rightarrow-\infty} F\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\tau}, t, x\right)=-\infty \quad \text { and } \quad \lim _{\tau \rightarrow \infty} F\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\tau}, t, x\right)=\kappa|x|-t>0
$$

so there exists a unique $\tau \in \mathbb{R}$ with $F\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\tau}, t, x\right)=0$. Then $\tau$ and $\xi:=\mathrm{e}^{\tau} x$ satisfy $\chi(\tau, \xi)=(t, x)$. If we are given $\kappa_{R}|x|>t>\widetilde{h}(|x|)$, then Eq. (A.4) and strict monotonicity imply $\tau>0$ and $|\xi|<R$.

The previous lemma also shows that coordinate cylinders get mapped to complements of cones. On such regions, we consider the transition diffeomorphism between radial similarity coordinates.

Lemma A.7. Let $\chi, \bar{\chi}: \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{1, d}$ be graphical similarity coordinates with respective radially symmetric height functions $h, \bar{h} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ as in Lemma A.6. Let $R, \bar{R}>0$ such that $\chi\left(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)=\bar{\chi}\left(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$. Then, there is a positive function $h_{+} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ such that the transition diffeomorphism $\chi^{-1} \circ \bar{\chi}: \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{B}_{\bar{R}}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}$ is given by

$$
\left(\chi^{-1} \circ \bar{\chi}\right)(\bar{\tau}, \bar{\xi})=\left(\bar{\tau}-\log h_{+}(\bar{\xi}), h_{+}(\bar{\xi})^{-1} \bar{\xi}\right)
$$

Proof. By Lemma A.6, the transition diffeomorphism $\chi^{-1} \circ \bar{\chi}: \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{B}_{\bar{R}}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{B}_{\bar{R}}^{d}$ is well-defined. By Lemma A.2, there is a positive radially symmetric function $h^{+} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ such that

$$
\left(\chi^{-1} \circ \bar{\chi}\right)(\bar{\tau}, \bar{\xi})=\left(\bar{\tau}-\log h^{+}(\bar{h}(\bar{\xi}), \bar{\xi}), h^{+}(\bar{h}(\bar{\xi}), \bar{\xi})^{-1} \bar{\xi}\right)
$$

Now set $h_{+}(\bar{\xi})=h^{+}(\bar{h}(\bar{\xi}), \bar{\xi})>0$. Since $h, \bar{h} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$, also $h_{+} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$.

A.3. Construction of height functions. Similarity coordinates with a radially symmetric height function as in Lemma A. 6 can be concretely implemented in various ways. To give some examples, we first translate positive semidefiniteness of a radial function to nonnegativity of the second derivative of its radial profile.

Lemma A.8. Let $h \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ with radial profile $\widetilde{h} \in C_{\mathrm{vv}}^{\infty}([0, \infty))$. Then, the Hessian matrix $\left(\partial^{2} h\right)(\xi)$ is positive semidefinite for all $\xi \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ if and only if $\widetilde{h}^{\prime \prime}(\rho) \geq 0$ for all $\rho \geq 0$.

Proof. We have for the second partial derivatives of $h$ the identity

$$
\left(\partial_{i} \partial_{j} h\right)(\xi)=(D \widetilde{h})(|\xi|) \delta_{i j}+\left(D^{2} \widetilde{h}\right)(|\xi|) \xi_{i} \xi_{j}
$$

in terms of the operation $(D \widetilde{h})(\rho)=\widetilde{h}^{\prime}(\rho) / \rho$. Now, suppose that $\left(\partial^{2} h\right)(\xi)$ is positive semidefinite for all $\xi \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. Then

$$
0 \leq v^{\top}\left(\partial^{2} h\right)(\xi) v=(D \widetilde{h})(|\xi|)|v|^{2}+\left(D^{2} \widetilde{h}\right)(|\xi|)(\xi \cdot v)^{2}
$$

for all $v, \xi \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$, where $v^{\top}$ denotes the transpose vector. Thus $(D \widetilde{h})(|\xi|) \geq 0$ and $\left(D^{2} \widetilde{h}\right)(|\xi|) \geq 0$ for all $\xi \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$, hence also

$$
\widetilde{h}^{\prime \prime}(\rho)=(D \widetilde{h})(\rho)+\rho^{2}\left(D^{2} \widetilde{h}\right)(\rho) \geq 0
$$

for all $\rho \geq 0$. Conversely, suppose that $\widetilde{h}^{\prime \prime}(\rho) \geq 0$ for all $\rho \geq 0$. Since $\widetilde{h}^{\prime}(0)=0$, it follows that also $\widetilde{h}^{\prime}(\rho) \geq 0$ for all $\rho \geq 0$. Hence $\left(\partial^{2} h\right)(\xi)$ is positive semidefinite for all $\xi \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$.

We end this section with the presentation of an exemplary class of radially symmetric height functions. The associated similarity coordinates have the convenient property to coincide with standard similarity coordinates in a backward light cone, whereas beyond they can be arranged to extend to any possible image according to Lemma A.6.

Lemma A.9. Let $0<\bar{\kappa}<1, \bar{r}>0$ and $0<\varepsilon<\bar{r}$. Then, there is a function $\bar{h} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ with positive semidefinite Hessian $\left(\partial^{2} \bar{h}\right)(\xi)$ and bounded gradient $|(\partial \widetilde{h})(\xi)|<1$ for all $\xi \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ which satisfies

$$
\bar{h}(\xi)= \begin{cases}\bar{\kappa}(|\xi|-\bar{r})-1 & \text { if }|\xi| \geq \bar{r}+\varepsilon \\ -1 & \text { if }|\xi| \leq \bar{r}-\varepsilon\end{cases}
$$

Proof. Let $\phi, \phi_{\varepsilon} \in C^{\infty}(\mathbb{R})$ be given by

$$
\phi(\rho)= \begin{cases}\mathrm{e}^{-\frac{1}{1-\rho^{2}}}, & |\rho|<1 \\ 0, & |\rho| \geq 1\end{cases} \quad \text { and } \quad \phi_{\varepsilon}(\rho)=\frac{\varepsilon^{-1}}{\|\phi\|_{L^{1}(\mathbb{R})}} \phi\left(\varepsilon^{-1} \rho\right)
$$

Let $\mathrm{h} * \phi_{\varepsilon}$ be the convolution of the function $\mathrm{h} \in C(\mathbb{R})$ given by

$$
\mathrm{h}(\rho)=\frac{\bar{\kappa}}{2}(|\rho|-\bar{r}+||\rho|-\bar{r}|)-1
$$

with the function $\phi_{\varepsilon} \in C^{\infty}(\mathbb{R})$. Note that $\mathrm{h} * \phi_{\varepsilon} \in C^{\infty}(\mathbb{R})$ is even and given by

$$
\left(\mathrm{h} * \phi_{\varepsilon}\right)(\rho)= \begin{cases}\mathrm{h}(\rho) & \text { if }|\rho-\bar{r}| \geq \varepsilon \\ \bar{\kappa} \int_{-\varepsilon}^{\rho-\bar{r}}(\rho-z-\bar{r}) \phi_{\varepsilon}(z) \mathrm{d} z-1 & \text { if }|\rho-\bar{r}|<\varepsilon\end{cases}
$$

It follows from Lemma A. 8 that $\bar{h}=\left(\mathrm{h} * \phi_{\varepsilon}\right)(|.|) \in C_{\text {rad }}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ has a positive semidefinite Hessian.

# Appendix B. The free wave flow in similarity coordinates 

In this section, we develop a general functional analytic framework for the wave operator

$$
(\square u)(t, x)=\left(-\partial_{t}^{2}+\Delta_{x}\right) u(t, x)
$$

in similarity coordinates without imposing any symmetry restrictions on the wave flow. First, we give a formulation of the wave flow as a first-order system in similarity coordinates which is encompassed by methods from semigroup theory. Once this is provided, we work out the necessary analytical foundations for an application of the Lumer-Phillips theorem [43, p. 83, Theorem 3.15]. This concerns dissipative estimates in Proposition B.2 and a density property of the range in Proposition B.3. As a result, we establish in Theorem B. 1 the existence and sharp growth bounds for the wave flow in similarity coordinates.
B.1. A first-order formalism. Throughout this section, we employ the following version of similarity coordinates from Appendix A.
Definition B.1. Let $d \in \mathbb{N}$. Let $h \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ such that

$$
h(0)<0, \quad|(\partial h)(\xi)|<1, \quad\left(\partial^{2} h\right)(\xi) \text { is positive semidefinite }
$$

for all $\xi \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. Let $R>0$. We define graphical similarity coordinates

$$
\chi: \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{1, d}, \quad \chi(\tau, \xi)=\left(\mathrm{e}^{-\tau} h(\xi), \mathrm{e}^{-\tau} \xi\right)
$$

in the image region

$$
\mathrm{X}_{R}^{1, d}:=\chi\left((0, \infty) \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)
$$

Graphical similarity coordinates are well-adapted to the wave evolution as we have seen in Lemmas A. 2 to A.4. The image region is explicitly determined in Lemma A.6. We frequently consider the space

$$
C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathrm{X}}_{R}^{1, d}\right):=\left\{u \in C^{\infty}\left(\mathrm{X}_{R}^{1, d}\right) \mid u \circ \chi \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{(0, \infty) \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)\right\}
$$

of smooth functions in the image region whose derivatives of all orders are bounded away from the center of the coordinate system. Now, we introduce the following differential operator.
Definition B.2. Let $d \in \mathbb{N}$ and $R>0$. Let $c, w \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ be given by

$$
c(\xi)=\xi^{i}\left(\partial_{i} h\right)(\xi)-h(\xi) \quad \text { and } \quad w(\xi)=1-\left(\partial^{i} h\right)(\xi)\left(\partial_{i} h\right)(\xi)
$$

For $\mathbf{f} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$, we define

$$
\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f}=\left[\begin{array}{c}
-\xi^{i} \partial_{i} f_{1}+c f_{2} \\
\frac{c}{w} \partial^{i} \partial_{i} f_{1}-\left(1+\frac{c}{w} \partial^{i} \partial_{i} h\right) f_{2}-\left(\xi^{i}+2 \frac{c}{w} \partial^{i} h\right) \partial_{i} f_{2}
\end{array}\right] \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}
$$

This definition is based on the formulation of the wave operator in similarity coordinates as a first-order flow.
Lemma B.1. Let $u \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathrm{X}}_{R}^{1, d}\right)$ and define $\mathbf{u} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{(0, \infty) \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$ with components

$$
u_{1}(\tau, \xi)=(u \circ \chi)(\tau, \xi), \quad u_{2}(\tau, \xi)=\mathrm{e}^{-\tau}\left(\left(\partial_{0} u\right) \circ \chi\right)(\tau, \xi)
$$

Then

$$
\partial_{\tau} \mathbf{u}(\tau, .)=\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{u}(\tau, .)-\left[\begin{array}{c}
0 \\
\mathrm{e}^{-2 \tau} \frac{c}{w}((\square u) \circ \chi)(\tau, .)
\end{array}\right]
$$

Proof. The transformation for partial derivatives of $u \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathrm{X}}_{R}^{1, d}\right)$ reads

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\left(\partial_{0} u\right) \circ \chi\right)(\tau, \xi)=\mathrm{e}^{\tau} \frac{1}{c(\xi)}\left(\partial_{\tau}+\xi^{i} \partial_{\xi^{i}}\right)(u \circ \chi)(\tau, \xi) \\
& \left(\left(\partial_{i} u\right) \circ \chi\right)(\tau, \xi)=\mathrm{e}^{\tau} \partial_{\xi^{i}}(u \circ \chi)(\tau, \xi)-\left(\partial_{i} h\right)(\xi)\left(\left(\partial_{0} u\right) \circ \chi\right)(\tau, \xi)
\end{aligned}
$$

From this we obtain

$$
\partial_{\tau} u_{1}(\tau, \xi)=-\xi^{i} \partial_{\xi^{i}} u_{1}(\tau, \xi)+c(\xi) u_{2}(\tau, \xi)
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
((\square u) \circ \chi)(\tau, \xi)= & \left(\left(-\partial_{0}^{2} u+\partial^{i} \partial_{i} u\right) \circ \chi\right)(\tau, \xi) \\
= & \mathrm{e}^{2 \tau}\left(-\frac{w(\xi)}{c(\xi)} \partial_{\tau} u_{2}(\tau, \xi)-\left(\frac{w(\xi)}{c(\xi)} \xi^{i}+2\left(\partial^{i} h\right)(\xi)\right) \partial_{\xi^{i}} u_{2}(\tau, \xi)\right. \\
& \left.-\left(\frac{w(\xi)}{c(\xi)}+\left(\partial^{i} \partial_{i} h\right)(\xi)\right) u_{2}(\tau, \xi)+\partial_{\xi^{i}} \partial_{\xi_{i}} u_{1}(\tau, \xi)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which yields the asserted relation.
B.2. Commuting differential operators. We implement classical spacetime derivatives as differential operators in the first-order formalism.
Definition B.3. Let $d \in \mathbb{N}$ and $R>0$. Let $c_{\mu} \in C^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ be given by

$$
c_{\mu}=1 \quad \text { for } \mu=0 \quad \text { and } \quad c_{\mu}=-\partial_{\mu} h \quad \text { for } \mu=1, \ldots, d
$$

For $\mu=0,1, \ldots, d$ and $\mathbf{f} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$, we define

$$
\mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{f}=\left[\begin{array}{c}
\delta_{\mu}{ }^{i} \partial_{i} f_{1}+c_{\mu} f_{2} \\
c_{\mu} \partial^{i} \partial_{i} f_{1}-\frac{c_{\mu}}{w}\left(\partial^{i} \partial_{i} h\right) f_{2}+\left(\delta_{\mu}{ }^{i}-2 \frac{c_{\mu}}{w} \partial^{i} h\right) \partial_{i} f_{2}
\end{array}\right] \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}
$$

This relates the evolution variables in the sense of Lemma B. 1 and the spacetime derivatives of the corresponding function as follows.
Lemma B.2. Let $u \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathrm{X}}_{R}^{1, d}\right)$ and define $\mathbf{u}, \mathbf{u}_{\mu} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{(0, \infty) \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$ with components

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl}
u_{1}(\tau, \xi) & =(u \circ \chi)(\tau, \xi), & u_{2}(\tau, \xi) & =\mathrm{e}^{-\tau}\left(\left(\partial_{0} u\right) \circ \chi\right)(\tau, \xi) \\
u_{\mu_{1}}(\tau, \xi)=\left(\left(\partial_{\mu} u\right) \circ \chi\right)(\tau, \xi), & u_{\mu_{2}}(\tau, \xi) & =\mathrm{e}^{-\tau}\left(\left(\partial_{0} \partial_{\mu} u\right) \circ \chi\right)(\tau, \xi)
\end{array}
$$

for $\mu=0,1, \ldots, d$, respectively. Then

$$
\mathbf{u}_{\mu}(\tau, \cdot)=\mathrm{e}^{\tau} \mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{u}(\tau, \cdot)-\left[\begin{array}{c}
0 \\
\mathrm{e}^{-\tau} \frac{c_{\mu}}{w}((\square u) \circ \chi)(\tau, \cdot)
\end{array}\right]
$$

Proof. We have from the transformations (B.1) and (B.2)

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\left(\partial_{\mu} u\right) \circ \chi\right)(\tau, \xi) & =e^{\tau} \delta_{\mu}{ }^{i} \partial_{\xi^{i}}(u \circ \chi)(\tau, \xi)+c_{\mu}(\xi)\left(\left(\partial_{0} u\right) \circ \chi\right)(\tau, \xi) \\
& =e^{\tau}\left(\delta_{\mu}{ }^{i}+\frac{c_{\mu}(\xi)}{c(\xi)} \xi^{i}\right) \partial_{\xi^{i}}(u \circ \chi)(\tau, \xi)+e^{\tau} \frac{c_{\mu}(\xi)}{c(\xi)} \partial_{\tau}(u \circ \chi)(\tau, \xi)
\end{aligned}
$$

This gives

$$
u_{\mu_{1}}(\tau, \xi)=e^{\tau} \delta_{\mu}{ }^{i} \partial_{\xi^{i}} u_{1}(\tau, \xi)+e^{\tau} c_{\mu}(\xi) u_{2}(\tau, \xi)
$$

and together with Lemma B. 1

$$
\begin{aligned}
& u_{\mu_{2}}(\tau, \xi)=e^{-\tau}\left(\left(\partial_{\mu} \partial_{0} u\right) \circ \chi\right)(\tau, \xi) \\
& \quad=\left(\delta_{\mu}{ }^{i}+\frac{c_{\mu}(\xi)}{c(\xi)} \xi^{i}\right) \partial_{\xi^{i}}\left(\left(\partial_{0} u\right) \circ \chi\right)(\tau, \xi)+\frac{c_{\mu}(\xi)}{c(\xi)} \partial_{\tau}\left(\left(\partial_{0} u\right) \circ \chi\right)(\tau, \xi) \\
& \quad=e^{\tau} \frac{c_{\mu}(\xi)}{w(\xi)} \partial_{\xi^{i}} \partial_{\xi_{i}} u_{1}(\tau, \xi)-e^{\tau} \frac{c_{\mu}(\xi)}{w(\xi)}\left(\partial^{i} \partial_{i} h\right)(\xi) u_{2}(\tau, \xi)+e^{\tau}\left(\delta_{\mu}{ }^{i}-2 \frac{c_{\mu}(\xi)}{w(\xi)}\left(\partial^{i} h\right)(\xi)\right) \partial_{\xi^{i}} u_{2}(\tau, \xi) \\
& \quad-e^{-\tau} \frac{c_{\mu}(\xi)}{w(\xi)}((\square u) \circ \chi)(\tau, \xi)
\end{aligned}
$$

which yields the relation.

The differential operators in Definition B. 3 inherit the commutation relations for classical spacetime derivatives. In particular, they commute with the wave evolution operator from Definition B. 2 up to a decay-inducing term.

Lemma B.3. Let $d \in \mathbb{N}$ and $R>0$. Then

$$
\mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f}-\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{f}=-\mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{f} \quad \text { and } \quad \mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{D}_{\nu} \mathbf{f}=\mathbf{D}_{\nu} \mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{f}
$$

for all $\mathbf{f} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$ and all $\mu, \nu=0,1, \ldots, d$.
Proof. Let $u \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{X}}_{R}^{1, d}\right)$ and define the variables $\mathbf{u}, \mathbf{u}_{\mu} \in C^{\infty}(\overline{(0, \infty) \times \overline{\mathbb{R}}_{R}^{d}})^{2}$ as in Lemma B.2. Lemma B. 1 applied to $\partial_{\mu} u \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{X}}_{R}^{1, d}\right)$ yields with Lemma B. 2

$$
\partial_{\tau} \mathbf{u}_{\mu}(\tau, \cdot)=\mathrm{e}^{\tau} \mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{u}(\tau, \cdot)-\mathbf{L}_{\chi}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\tau} \frac{c_{\mu}}{w}((\square u) \circ \chi)(\tau, \cdot)\right]-\left[\mathrm{e}^{-2 \tau} \frac{c}{w}\left((\square \partial_{\mu} u) \circ \chi\right)(\tau, \cdot)\right]
$$

The left-hand side can be computed in a second way by first differentiating the relation in Lemma B. 2 and then using Lemma B.1,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\partial_{\tau} \mathbf{u}_{\mu}(\tau, \cdot)= & \mathrm{e}^{\tau} \mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{u}(\tau, \cdot)+\mathrm{e}^{\tau} \mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{u}(\tau, \cdot)-\mathbf{D}_{\mu}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\tau} \frac{c}{w}((\square u) \circ \chi)(\tau, \cdot)\right] \\
& -\partial_{\tau}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\tau} \frac{c_{\mu}}{w}((\square u) \circ \chi)(\tau, \cdot)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Subtracting the latter two identities from each other and using the identities

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \partial_{\xi^{j}} \frac{c(\xi)}{w(\xi)}=\left(\xi^{j}+2 \frac{c(\xi)}{w(\xi)}\left(\partial^{j} h\right)(\xi)\right) \frac{\left(\partial_{i} \partial_{j} h\right)(\xi)}{w(\xi)} \\
& \partial_{\xi^{j}} \frac{c_{\mu}(\xi)}{w(\xi)}=-\left(\delta_{\mu}{ }^{j}-2 \frac{c_{\mu}(\xi)}{w(\xi)}\left(\partial^{j} h\right)(\xi)\right) \frac{\left(\partial_{i} \partial_{j} h\right)(\xi)}{w(\xi)}
\end{aligned}
$$

as well as transformation (B.3) implies

$$
\left(\mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{L}_{\chi}-\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{D}_{\mu}+\mathbf{D}_{\mu}\right) \mathbf{u}(\tau, \cdot)=\mathbf{0}
$$

Furthermore, consider the variable $\mathbf{u}_{\mu \nu} \in C^{\infty}(\overline{(0, \infty) \times \mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}})^{2}$ with components

$$
u_{\mu \nu_{1}}(\tau, \cdot)=\left(\left(\partial_{\mu} \partial_{\nu} u\right) \circ \chi\right)(\tau, \cdot), \quad u_{\mu \nu_{2}}(\tau, \cdot)=\mathrm{e}^{-\tau}\left(\left(\partial_{0} \partial_{\mu} \partial_{\nu} u\right) \circ \chi\right)(\tau, \cdot)
$$

By construction, two applications of Lemma B. 2 yield

$$
\mathbf{u}_{\mu \nu}(\tau, \cdot)=\mathrm{e}^{2 \tau} \mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{D}_{\nu} \mathbf{u}(\tau, \cdot)-\mathbf{D}_{\mu}\left[\frac{0}{w}((\square u) \circ \chi)(\tau, \cdot)\right]-\left[\mathrm{e}^{-\tau} \frac{c_{\mu}}{w}\left((\square \partial_{\nu} u) \circ \chi\right)(\tau, \cdot)\right]
$$

A computation shows

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbf{D}_{\mu}\left[\frac{c_{\nu}}{w}((\square u) \circ \chi)(\tau, \cdot)\right]-\mathbf{D}_{\nu}\left[\frac{0}{w}((\square u) \circ \chi)(\tau, \cdot)\right] \\
& \quad=-\left[\begin{array}{c}
0 \\
\mathrm{e}^{-\tau} \frac{c_{\mu}}{w}\left(\left(\partial_{\nu} \square u\right) \circ \chi\right)(\tau, \cdot)-\mathrm{e}^{-\tau} \frac{c_{\nu}}{w}\left(\left(\partial_{\mu} \square u\right) \circ \chi\right)(\tau, \cdot)\right]
\end{array}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, symmetry of second partial derivatives yields

$$
\left(\mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{D}_{\nu}-\mathbf{D}_{\nu} \mathbf{D}_{\mu}\right) \mathbf{u}(\tau, \cdot)=\mathbf{0}
$$

To conclude, let $\mathbf{f} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$ and choose $u=v \circ \chi^{-1} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{X}}_{R}^{1, d}\right)$ with

$$
v(\tau, \xi)=f_{1}(\xi)+\tau\left(c(\xi) f_{2}(\xi)-\xi^{i} \partial_{\xi^{i}} f_{1}(\xi)\right)
$$

Then $\mathbf{u}(0, \cdot)=\mathbf{f}$ and evaluating Eqs. (B.4) and (B.5) at $\tau=0$ yields the result.

B.3. Inner products. With these preparations at hand, we are ready to furnish Hilbert space structures and prove dissipative estimates for the wave evolution operator from Definition B. 2 in all space dimensions. The energy discussed in Section 2.2 motivates the following choice of sesquilinear forms.

Definition B.4. Let $d \in \mathbb{N}$ and $R>0$. Fix $\varepsilon_{1}>0$. We define for $\mathbf{f}, \mathbf{g} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$

$$
(\mathbf{f} \mid \mathbf{g})_{\mathfrak{C}^{1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}=\int_{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}} \overline{\partial^{t} f_{1}} \partial_{i} g_{1}+\int_{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}} \overline{f_{2}} g_{2} w+\frac{2 \varepsilon_{1}}{R} \int_{\partial \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}} \overline{f_{1}} g_{1}
$$

The induced quadratic form is defined by

$$
\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}=\sqrt{(\mathbf{f} \mid \mathbf{f})_{\mathfrak{C}^{1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}}
$$

The boundary term ensures that this sesquilinear form is positive definite and thus an inner product.

Lemma B.4. Let $d \in \mathbb{N}$ and $R>0$. Fix $\varepsilon_{1}>0$ in Definition B.4. Then

$$
\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \simeq\left\|\left(f_{1}, f_{2}\right)\right\|_{H^{1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \times L^{2}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}
$$

for all $\mathbf{f}=\left(f_{1}, f_{2}\right) \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$.
Proof. We have

$$
\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \simeq\left\|\partial f_{1}\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\left\|f_{1}\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\partial \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\left\|f_{2}\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \simeq\left\|f_{1}\right\|_{H^{1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\left\|f_{2}\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}
$$

for all $\mathbf{f} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$, where the second equivalence follows from the trace lemma [98, Lemma 2.1].
