We utilize the differential operators from Definition B. 3 to extend the inner product in Definition B. 4 to also include derivatives of any given nonnegative integer order.

Definition B.5. Let $d, k \in \mathbb{N}$ and $R>0$. Fix $\varepsilon_{j}>0$ for $1 \leq j<\frac{d}{2}+1$. We define for $\mathbf{f}, \mathbf{g} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$ recursively

$$
(\mathbf{f} \mid \mathbf{g})_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}= \begin{cases}\int_{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}} \overline{\partial^{t} f_{1}} \partial_{i} g_{1}+\int_{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}} \overline{f_{2}} g_{2} w+\frac{2 \varepsilon_{1}}{R} \int_{\partial \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}} \overline{f_{1}} g_{1} & \text { if } k=1 \\ \sum_{\mu=0}^{d}\left(\mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{f} \mid \mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{g}\right)_{\mathfrak{C}^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\frac{2 \varepsilon_{k}}{R} \int_{\partial \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}} \overline{f_{1}} g_{1} & \text { if } 2 \leq k<\frac{d}{2}+1 \\ \sum_{\mu=0}^{d}\left(\mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{f} \mid \mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{g}\right)_{\mathfrak{C}^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}+(\mathbf{f} \mid \mathbf{g})_{\mathfrak{C}^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} & \text { if } \frac{d}{2}+1 \leq k\end{cases}
$$

The induced quadratic form is defined by

$$
\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}=\sqrt{(\mathbf{f} \mid \mathbf{f})_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}} .
$$

These sesquilinear forms are inner products whose induced norms are equivalently characterized as Sobolev norms.

Proposition B.1. Let $d, k \in \mathbb{N}$ and $R>0$. Fix $\varepsilon_{j}>0$ for $1 \leq j<\frac{d}{2}+1$ in Definition B.5. Then the equivalence

$$
\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \simeq\left\|\left(f_{1}, f_{2}\right)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \times H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}
$$

holds for all $\mathbf{f}=\left(f_{1}, f_{2}\right) \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$.

Proof. $\quad$ " $\lesssim$ ": The inequality is valid in the base case $k=1$ by Lemma B.4. We proceed by induction and assume that for an arbitrary but fixed $k \in \mathbb{N}$ the bound

$$
\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \lesssim\left\|\left(f_{1}, f_{2}\right)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \times H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}
$$

holds for all $\mathbf{f} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$. Hence,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|\mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{f}\right\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \lesssim\left\|\mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{f}\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \times H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \lesssim\left\|\partial f_{1}\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\left\|f_{2}\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& +\left\|\partial^{2} f_{1}\right\|_{H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\left\|f_{2}\right\|_{H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\left\|\partial f_{2}\right\|_{H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \lesssim\left\|\left(f_{1}, f_{2}\right)\right\|_{H^{k+1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \times H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $\mathbf{f} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$. With this, the first inequality follows.
" $\gtrsim$ ": Again, the inequality holds if $k=1$ by Lemma B.4. By induction, assume that for an arbitrary but fixed $k \in \mathbb{N}$ the bound

$$
\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \gtrsim\left\|\left(f_{1}, f_{2}\right)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \times H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}
$$

holds for all $\mathbf{f} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$.
Case $1 \leq k<\frac{d}{2}$. We conclude with

$$
\left[\mathbf{D}_{0} \mathbf{f}\right]_{1}=f_{2} \quad \text { and } \quad \partial_{i} \mathbf{f}=\mathbf{D}_{i} \mathbf{f}+\left(\partial_{i} h\right) \mathbf{D}_{0} \mathbf{f}
$$

and the trace lemma [98, Lemma 2.1] for the Sobolev norm the estimate

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\left(f_{1}, f_{2}\right)\right\|_{H^{k+1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \times H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} & \simeq \sum_{i=1}^{d}\left\|\left(\partial_{i} f_{1}, \partial_{i} f_{2}\right)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \times H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\left\|f_{1}\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\partial \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\left\|f_{2}\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \lesssim \sum_{\mu=0}^{d}\left\|\mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{f}\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \times H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\left\|f_{1}\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\partial \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \lesssim \sum_{\mu=0}^{d}\left\|\mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{f}\right\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\left\|f_{1}\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\partial \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \simeq\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k+1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $\mathbf{f} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$.
Case $k \geq \frac{d}{2}$. We conclude with (B.6) as well

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\left(f_{1}, f_{2}\right)\right\|_{H^{k+1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \times H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} & \simeq \sum_{i=1}^{d}\left\|\left(\partial_{i} f_{1}, \partial_{i} f_{2}\right)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \times H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\left\|\left(f_{1}, f_{2}\right)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \times H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \lesssim \sum_{\mu=0}^{d}\left\|\mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{f}\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \times H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\left\|\left(f_{1}, f_{2}\right)\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \times H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \lesssim \sum_{\mu=0}^{d}\left\|\mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{f}\right\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \simeq\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k+1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $\mathbf{f} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$.
This proves the other direction.

B.4. Dissipative estimates. The energy estimate in Section 2.2 for the wave equation in similarity coordinates manifests itself as a dissipative estimate for the wave evolution operator from Definition B.2.

Lemma B.5. Let $d \in \mathbb{N}$ and $R \geq R_{0}$ with $R_{0}>0$ from Lemma A.5. Then

$$
\operatorname{Re}\left(\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f} \mid \mathbf{f}\right)_{\notin^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} \leq\left(\frac{d}{2}-1\right)\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\notin^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}^{2}+\left(-\frac{d}{2}+1+\varepsilon_{1}\right) \frac{2 \varepsilon_{1}}{R} \int_{\partial \mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}}\left|f_{1}\right|^{2}
$$

for all $\mathbf{f} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$.
Proof. We have

$$
\left(\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f} \mid \mathbf{f}\right)_{\notin^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}=\int_{\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}} \overline{\left(\partial^{i}\left[\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f}\right]_{1}\right)}\left(\partial_{i} f_{1}\right)+\int_{\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}} \overline{\left[\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f}\right]_{2}} f_{2} w+\frac{2 \varepsilon_{1}}{R} \int_{\partial \mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}} \overline{\left[\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f}\right]_{1}} f_{1}
$$

with integrands

$$
\begin{aligned}
\overline{\left(\partial^{i}\left[\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f}\right]_{1}\right)}\left(\partial_{i} f_{1}\right) & =-\left|\partial f_{1}\right|^{2}-\overline{\xi^{j}\left(\partial_{i} \partial_{j} f_{1}\right)}\left(\partial^{j} f_{1}\right)-c\left(\partial^{i} \partial_{i} f_{1}\right) \overline{f_{2}}+\partial_{i}\left(c\left(\partial^{i} f_{1}\right) \overline{f_{2}}\right) \\
{\left[\overline{\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f}}\right]_{2} f_{2} w } & =c \overline{\left(\partial^{i} \partial_{i} f_{1}\right)} f_{2}-\left(w+c\left(\partial^{i} \partial_{i} h\right)\right)\left|f_{2}\right|^{2}-\left(\xi^{j} w+2 c\left(\partial^{j} h\right)\right) \overline{\left(\partial_{j} f_{2}\right)} f_{2} \\
{\left[\overline{\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f}}\right]_{1} f_{1}} & =-\overline{\xi^{i}\left(\partial_{i} f_{1}\right)} f_{1}+\overline{c f_{2}} f_{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Integration by parts yields the equation

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Re}\left(\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f} \mid \mathbf{f}\right)_{\notin^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}= & \left(\frac{d}{2}-1\right) \int_{\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}}\left(\left|\partial f_{1}\right|^{2}+\left|f_{2}\right|^{2} w\right) \\
& +\frac{1}{R} \int_{\partial \mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}} \operatorname{Re}\left(\xi^{i}\left(\partial_{i} f_{1}\right) \overline{c f_{2}}-\overline{\xi^{i}\left(\partial_{i} f_{1}\right)} 2 \varepsilon_{1} f_{1}+\overline{c f_{2}} 2 \varepsilon_{1} f_{1}\right) \\
& -\frac{1}{R} \int_{\partial \mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}} \frac{1}{2}\left(\left|\xi\right|^{2}\left|\partial f_{1}\right|^{2}+\left(w|\xi|^{2}+2 c \xi^{i}(\partial_{i} h)\right)\left|f_{2}\right|^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The first boundary term is estimated with the elementary inequality

$$
\operatorname{Re}\left(\xi^{i}\left(\partial_{i} f_{1}\right) \overline{c f_{2}}-\overline{\xi^{i}\left(\partial_{i} f_{1}\right)} 2 \varepsilon_{1} f_{1}+\overline{c f_{2}} 2 \varepsilon_{1} f_{1}\right) \leq \frac{1}{2}\left(\left|\xi\right|^{2}\left|\partial f_{1}\right|^{2}+c^{2}\left|f_{2}\right|^{2}+4 \varepsilon_{1}^{2}\left|f_{1}\right|^{2}\right)
$$

We then use

$$
\begin{aligned}
c(\xi)^{2}-w(\xi)|\xi|^{2}-2 c(\xi) \xi^{i}\left(\partial_{i} h\right)(\xi) & =-\left(\xi^{i}\left(\partial_{i} h\right)(\xi)\right)^{2}+|\xi|^{2}|(\partial h)(\xi)|^{2}+h(\xi)^{2}-|\xi|^{2} \\
& =h(\xi)^{2}-|\xi|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

with $h(\xi)^{2}-|\xi|^{2} \leq 0$ if and only if $|\xi| \geq R_{0}$ and conclude the estimate

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Re}\left(\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f} \mid \mathbf{f}\right)_{\notin^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} & \leq\left(\frac{d}{2}-1\right) \int_{\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}}\left(\left|\partial f_{1}\right|^{2}+\left|f_{2}\right|^{2} w\right)+\frac{2 \varepsilon_{1}^{2}}{R} \int_{\partial \mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}}\left|f_{1}\right|^{2} \\
& =\left(\frac{d}{2}-1\right)\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\notin^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}^{2}+\left(-\frac{d}{2}+1+\varepsilon_{1}\right) \frac{2 \varepsilon_{1}}{R} \int_{\partial \mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}}\left|f_{1}\right|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

The recursive construction of the inner products allows to obtain inductively the desired dissipative estimates.

Proposition B.2. Let $d, k \in \mathbb{N}$ and $R \geq R_{0}$ with $R_{0}>0$ from Lemma A.5. Fix $0<\varepsilon_{1} \leq \frac{1}{2}$ in Definition B. 5 and set

$$
\varepsilon_{k}=\varepsilon_{1} \prod_{i=1}^{k-1} \frac{\left(\frac{d}{2}-i-\varepsilon_{1}\right) \varepsilon_{1}}{R^{2}}>0 \quad \text { for } 2 \leq k<\frac{d}{2}+1
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Re}\left(\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f} \mid \mathbf{f}\right)_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \quad \leq \begin{cases}\left(\frac{d}{2}-k\right)\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}^{2}+\left(-\frac{d}{2}+k+\varepsilon_{1}\right) \frac{2 \varepsilon_{k}}{R} \int_{\partial \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\left|f_{1}\right|^{2} & \text { if } 1 \leq k<\frac{d}{2}+1 \\
\varepsilon_{1}\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}^{2} & \text { if } \frac{d}{2}+1 \leq k\end{cases}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $\mathbf{f} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$.
Proof. The estimate for $k=1$ is proved in Lemma B.5. Now, let us assume by induction that the lemma holds for an arbitrary but fixed integer $k \in \mathbb{N}$.

Case $1 \leq k<\frac{d}{2}$. We find with the commutation relation from Lemma B. 3

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Re}\left(\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f} \mid \mathbf{f}\right)_{\mathfrak{C}^{k+1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}=\sum_{\mu=0}^{d} \operatorname{Re}\left(\mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f} \mid \mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{f}\right)_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\frac{2 \varepsilon_{k+1}}{R} \operatorname{Re} \int_{\partial \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\left[\overline{\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f}]_{1}} f_{1}\right. \\
& \left.=\sum_{\mu=0}^{d} \operatorname{Re}\left(\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{f} \mid \mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{f}\right)_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}-\sum_{\mu=0}^{d}\left\|\mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{f}\right\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}^{2}+\frac{2 \varepsilon_{k+1}}{R} \operatorname{Re} \int_{\partial \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\left[\overline{\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f}]_{1}} f_{1}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

From the assumptions in Definition 1.1 it follows that $h(\xi)<|\xi|$ and so the boundary term is estimated by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Re} \int_{\partial \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\left[\overline{\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f}]_{1}} f_{1}\right. & =\operatorname{Re} \int_{\partial \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\left(-\overline{h\left[\mathbf{D}_{0} \mathbf{f}\right]_{1}} f_{1}-\overline{\xi^{\dagger}\left[\mathbf{D}_{1} \mathbf{f}\right]_{1}} f_{1}\right) \\
& \leq \varepsilon_{1} \int_{\partial \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\left|f_{1}\right|^{2}+\frac{R^{2}}{2 \varepsilon_{1}} \int_{\partial \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}} \sum_{\mu=0}^{d}\left|\left[\mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{f}\right]_{1}\right|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

This implies with the induction hypothesis and the choice of $\varepsilon_{k+1}>0$ from above

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Re}\left(\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f} \mid \mathbf{f}\right)_{\mathfrak{C}^{k+1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} \leq & \left(\frac{d}{2}-k-1\right) \sum_{\mu=0}^{d}\left\|\mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{f}\right\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}^{2}+\varepsilon_{1} \frac{2 \varepsilon_{k+1}}{R} \int_{\partial \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\left|f_{1}\right|^{2} \\
& +\left(\left(-\frac{d}{2}+k+\varepsilon_{1}\right) \frac{2 \varepsilon_{k}}{R}+\frac{R}{\varepsilon_{1}} \varepsilon_{k+1}\right) \int_{\partial \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}} \sum_{\mu=0}^{d}\left|\left[\mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{f}]_{1}\right|^{2}\right. \\
\leq & \left(\frac{d}{2}-k-1\right)\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k+1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}^{2}+\left(-\frac{d}{2}+k+1+\varepsilon_{1}\right) \frac{2 \varepsilon_{k+1}}{R} \int_{\partial \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\left|f_{1}\right|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

So the lemma is proved for all $1 \leq k<\frac{d}{2}+1$.
Case $k \geq \frac{d}{2}$. Note that when $k=\left\lceil\frac{d}{2}\right\rceil \geq \frac{d}{2}$ the induction hypothesis gives

$$
\operatorname{Re}\left(\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f} \mid \mathbf{f}\right)_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} \leq \varepsilon_{1}\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}^{2}
$$

So, by induction and the commutation relation from Lemma B. 3

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Re}\left(\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f} \mid \mathbf{f}\right)_{\mathfrak{C}^{k+1}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} & =\sum_{\mu=0}^{d} \operatorname{Re}\left(\mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f} \mid \mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{f}\right)_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}+\operatorname{Re}\left(\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f} \mid \mathbf{f}\right)_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \leq \varepsilon_{1}\left(\sum_{\mu=0}^{d}\left\|\mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{f}\right\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}^{2}+\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}^{2}\right)-\sum_{\mu=0}^{d}\left\|\mathbf{D}_{\mu} \mathbf{f}\right\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}^{2} \\
& \leq \varepsilon_{1}\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}_{R}^{d}\right)}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

and the estimates are proved.
B.5. Density of the range. Lemma B. 1 shows that a well-posedness theory of the Cauchy problem for the wave equation in similarity coordinates can be established if the differential operator from Definition B. 2 can be realized as the generator of a strongly continuous semigroup. So far, we have shown in Propositions B. 1 and B. 2 that this operator is densely defined and dissipative on a Hilbert space. Thus, the Lumer-Phillips theorem provides a necessary and sufficient condition for a generation theorem. In order to apply it, we further need to prove a density result for the range of this operator. For this, we introduce the Laplace-Beltrami operator in similarity coordinates.

Definition B.6. For a map $v \in C^{\infty}(\overline{(0, \infty) \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}})$, we define the Laplace-Beltrami operator with respect to the Minkowski metric in graphical similarity coordinates from Definition B. 1 by

$$
\left(\square_{\chi} v\right)(\tau, \xi)=\mathrm{e}^{2 \tau}\left(c^{00}(\xi) \partial_{\tau}^{2}+c^{i 0}(\xi) \partial_{\xi^{i}} \partial_{\tau}+c^{i j}(\xi) \partial_{\xi^{i}} \partial_{\xi^{j}}+c^{0}(\xi) \partial_{\tau}+c^{i}(\xi) \partial_{\xi^{i}}\right) v(\tau, \xi)
$$

where the smooth coefficients are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
c^{00}(\xi) & =-\frac{w(\xi)}{c(\xi)^{2}} \\
c^{i 0}(\xi) & =-2\left(\frac{w(\xi)}{c(\xi)^{2}} \xi^{i}+\frac{\left(\partial^{i} h\right)(\xi)}{c(\xi)}\right) \\
c^{i j}(\xi) & =\delta^{i j}-\frac{w(\xi)}{c(\xi)^{2}} \xi^{i} \xi^{j}-\frac{\xi^{i}\left(\partial^{j} h\right)(\xi)+\xi^{j}\left(\partial^{i} h\right)(\xi)}{c(\xi)} \\
c^{0}(\xi) & =-\frac{w(\xi)}{c(\xi)^{2}}-\left(\delta^{i j}-\frac{w(\xi)}{c(\xi)^{2}} \xi^{i} \xi^{j}-\frac{\xi^{i}\left(\partial^{j} h\right)(\xi)+\xi^{j}\left(\partial^{i} h\right)(\xi)}{c(\xi)}\right) \frac{\left(\partial_{i} \partial_{j} h\right)(\xi)}{c(\xi)} \\
c^{i}(\xi) & =-2\left(\frac{w(\xi)}{c(\xi)^{2}} \xi^{i}+\frac{\left(\partial^{i} h\right)(\xi)}{c(\xi)}\right)-\left(\delta^{j k}-\frac{w(\xi)}{c(\xi)^{2}} \xi^{j} \xi^{k}-\frac{\xi^{j}\left(\partial^{k} h\right)(\xi)+\xi^{k}\left(\partial^{j} h\right)(\xi)}{c(\xi)}\right) \frac{\left(\partial_{j} \partial_{k} h\right)(\xi)}{c(\xi)} \xi^{i}
\end{aligned}
$$

Recall that if $u \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathrm{X}}_{R}^{1, d}\right)$ and $v \in C^{\infty}(\overline{(0, \infty) \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}})$ are related via $v=u \circ \chi$, then the classical wave operator is related to the Laplace-Beltrami operator via

$$
(\square u) \circ \chi=\square_{\chi} v
$$

The following lemma links the respective condition from the Lumer-Phillips theorem to the existence of mode solutions of an inhomogeneous wave equation in similarity coordinates.
Lemma B.6. Let $\lambda \in \mathbb{C}$. Let $\mathbf{F} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$ and define $F \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)$ by

$$
\begin{aligned}
F(\xi)= & \left(-((\lambda+1) \frac{w(\xi)}{c(\xi)^{2}}+\left(\delta^{i j}-\frac{w(\xi)}{c(\xi)^{2}} \xi^{i} \xi^{j}-2 \frac{\left(\partial^{i} h\right)(\xi) \xi^{j}}{c(\xi)}\right) \frac{\left(\partial_{i} \partial_{j} h\right)(\xi)}{c(\xi)}\right) F_{1}(\xi) \\
& -\left(\frac{w(\xi)}{c(\xi)^{2}} \xi^{i}+\frac{\left(\partial^{i} h\right)(\xi)}{c(\xi)}\right)\left(\partial_{i} F_{1}\right)(\xi)-\frac{w(\xi)}{c(\xi)} F_{2}(\xi)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $f \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)$ and define $\mathbf{f} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$ by

$$
\mathbf{f}=\left[\begin{array}{cc}
f & \\
\lambda & \\
c & f
\end{array}\right]
$$

Then

$$
\lambda \mathbf{f}-\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f}-\mathbf{F}=-\left.\left[\begin{array}{c}
0 \\
c \\
w
\end{array}\left(\square_{\chi} v(\tau, \cdot)-G(\tau, \cdot)\right)\right]\right|_{\tau=0}
$$

where $v, G \in C^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R} \times \overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)$ are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
v_{\lambda}(\tau, \xi) & =\mathrm{e}^{\lambda \tau} f(\xi) \\
G_{\lambda}(\tau, \xi) & =\mathrm{e}^{(\lambda+2) \tau} F(\xi)
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. Let $\mathbf{v} \in C^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R} \times \overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$ be given by

$$
\mathbf{v}(\tau, \xi):=\mathrm{e}^{\lambda \tau} \mathbf{f}(\xi)=\left[\begin{array}{c}
v_{\lambda}(\tau, \xi) \\
\frac{1}{c(\xi)}\left(\partial_{\tau}+\xi^{i} \partial_{\xi^{i}}\right) v_{\lambda}(\tau, \xi)-\frac{1}{c(\xi)} \mathrm{e}^{\lambda \tau} F_{1}(\xi)
\end{array}\right]
$$

Using Lemma B. 1 and relation (B.7), we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lambda \mathbf{f}-\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f}-\mathbf{F} & =\left.\left(\partial_{\tau} \mathbf{v}(\tau, \cdot)-\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{v}(\tau, \cdot)\right)\right|_{\tau=0}-\mathbf{F} \\
& =-\left.\left[\frac{c}{n}\left(\square_{\chi} v_{\lambda}(\tau, \cdot)-G_{\lambda}(\tau, \cdot)\right)\right]\right|_{\tau=0}
\end{aligned}
$$

Solutions to the wave equation of the form (B.9) are called mode solutions and they are invariant under transition diffeomorphisms between graphical similarity coordinates.
Lemma B.7. Let $\chi, \bar{\chi}: \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{1, d}$ be graphical similarity coordinates and $R, \bar{R}>0$ such that $\chi\left(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)=\bar{\chi}\left(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$. Let $\lambda \in \mathbb{C}$ and let $f, F \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)$ and $\bar{f}, \bar{F} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)$ be related via the transition diffeomorphism $\chi^{-1} \circ \bar{\chi}$ from Lemma A.7, that is

$$
\bar{f}(\bar{\xi})=h_{+}(\bar{\xi})^{-\lambda} f\left(h_{+}(\bar{\xi})^{-1} \bar{\xi}\right), \quad \bar{F}(\bar{\xi})=h_{+}(\bar{\xi})^{-\lambda+2} F\left(h_{+}(\bar{\xi})^{-1} \bar{\xi}\right)
$$

Set

$$
G(\tau, \xi)=\mathrm{e}^{(\lambda+2) \tau} F(\xi), \quad \bar{G}(\bar{\tau}, \bar{\xi})=\mathrm{e}^{(\lambda+2) \bar{\tau}} \bar{F}(\bar{\xi})
$$

Then

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
\square_{\chi} v & =G, & & \\
v(\tau, \xi) & =\mathrm{e}^{\lambda \tau} f(\xi), & & \text { if and only if } \\
\left(\bar{v}(\bar{\tau}, \bar{\xi})=\mathrm{e}^{\lambda \bar{\tau}} \bar{f}(\bar{\xi})\right.
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

Proof. Note that $v, G \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{(0, \infty) \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)$ and $\bar{v}, \bar{G} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{(0, \infty) \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)$ are related via

$$
v \circ\left(\chi^{-1} \circ \bar{\chi}\right)=\bar{v} \quad \text { and } \quad G \circ \chi^{-1} \circ \bar{\chi}=\bar{G}
$$

Hence

$$
\left(\square_{\chi} v-G\right) \circ\left(\chi^{-1} \circ \bar{\chi}\right)=\square_{\bar{\chi}} \bar{v}-\bar{G}
$$

Our final result for the operator from Definition B. 2 verifies the assumptions in the LumerPhillips theorem.
Proposition B.3. Let $d \in \mathbb{N}$ and $R \geq R_{0}$ with $R_{0}>0$ from Lemma A.5. For all $\mathbf{F} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$ there is a unique $\mathbf{f} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$ such that

$$
\left(\frac{d}{2} \mathbf{f}-\mathbf{L}_{\chi}\right) \mathbf{f}=\mathbf{F}
$$

If $\mathbf{F} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$, then also $\mathbf{f} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$.
Proof. Throughout this proof, set $\lambda=\frac{d}{2}$. Let $\mathbf{F} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$ be arbitrary but fixed and define $F \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)$ as in Eq. (B.8). We define for $n \in \mathbb{N}$ the spherical harmonics approximation

$$
F_{n}(\xi)=\sum_{\ell=0}^{n} \sum_{m \in \Omega_{d, \ell}} F_{\ell, m}(|\xi|) Y_{\ell, m}\left(\frac{\xi}{|\xi|}\right), \quad F_{\ell, m}(\rho)=\int_{\partial \mathbb{B}^{d}} \overline{Y_{\ell, m}} F(\rho .)
$$

We recall from [35, Lemma A.2] that $F_{n} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)$ and

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\frac{c}{n}\left(F_{n}-F\right)\right\|_{H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}=0
$$

for any $k \in \mathbb{N}$. Next, fix similarity coordinates $\bar{\chi}: \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{1, d}$ with a height function $\bar{h}(|.|) \in C_{\text {rad }}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ with $\bar{h}(\rho)=-1$ for $\rho \in[0,1]$ and with the same image as $\chi: \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{1, d}$, see Lemmas A. 6 and A.9. As a matter of transparency, we use overbared variables for the

analysis in this coordinate system. Let $\bar{F}_{n} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)$ be related to $F_{n} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)$ via Eq. (B.11), i.e.

$$
\bar{F}_{n}(\bar{\xi})=\sum_{\ell=0}^{n} \sum_{m \in \Omega_{d, \ell}} \bar{F}_{\ell, m}(|\bar{\xi}|) Y_{\ell, m}\left(\frac{\bar{\xi}}{|\xi|}\right), \quad \bar{F}_{\ell, m}(\bar{\rho})=\widetilde{h}_{+}(\bar{\rho})^{-\lambda+2} F_{\ell, m}\left(\widetilde{h}_{+}(\bar{\rho})^{-1} \bar{\rho}\right)
$$

Furthermore, define $G_{n} \in C^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R} \times \overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right), \bar{G}_{n} \in C^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R} \times \overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)$ according to Eq. (B.12) and consider the problem

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
\square_{\bar{\xi}} \bar{v}_{n} & =\bar{G}_{n} \\
\bar{v}_{n}(\bar{\tau}, \bar{\xi}) & =\mathrm{e}^{\lambda \bar{\tau}} \bar{f}_{n}(\bar{\xi})
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

for solutions of the form

$$
\bar{f}_{n}(\bar{\xi})=\sum_{\ell=0}^{n} \sum_{m \in \Omega_{d, \ell}} f_{\ell, m}(|\bar{\xi}|) Y_{\ell, m}\left(\frac{\bar{\xi}}{|\xi|}\right)
$$

Inserting the expansion (B.15) in problem (B.14) yields for $(\bar{\tau}, \bar{\rho}) \in \mathbb{R} \times(0, \bar{R})$ and $\omega \in \partial \mathbb{B}^{d}$ the identity

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\square_{\bar{\xi}} \bar{v}_{n}-\bar{G}_{n}\right)(\bar{\tau}, \bar{\rho} \omega)=\mathrm{e}^{(\lambda+2) \bar{\tau}}\left(\left(\bar{c}^{i j} \partial_{i} \partial_{j}+\left(\lambda \bar{c}^{i 0}+\bar{c}^{i}\right) \partial_{i}+\lambda\left(\lambda \bar{c}^{i 0}+\bar{c}^{0}\right)\right) \bar{f}_{n}-\bar{F}_{n}\right)(\bar{\rho} \omega) \\
& =\sum_{\ell=0}^{n} \sum_{m \in \Omega_{d, \ell}} \mathrm{e}^{(\lambda+2) \bar{\tau}}\left(\bar{a}_{2}(\bar{\rho}) \bar{f}_{\ell, m}^{\prime \prime}(\bar{\rho})+\bar{a}_{1}(\bar{\rho} ; d, \lambda) \bar{f}_{\ell, m}^{\prime}(\bar{\rho})+\bar{a}_{0}(\bar{\rho} ; d, \lambda, \ell) \bar{f}_{\ell, m}(\bar{\rho})-\bar{F}_{\ell, m}(\bar{\rho})\right) Y_{\ell, m}(\omega)
\end{aligned}
$$

with coefficients given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{a}_{2}(\bar{\rho})= & -\frac{\bar{\rho}^{2}-\bar{h}(\bar{\rho})^{2}}{\left(\bar{\rho} \bar{h}^{\prime}(\bar{\rho})-\bar{h}(\bar{\rho})\right)^{2}} \\
\bar{a}_{1}(\bar{\rho} ; d, \lambda)= & 2\left(\frac{d-3}{2}-\lambda\right) \frac{\bar{\rho}-\bar{h}(\bar{\rho}) \bar{h}^{\prime}(\bar{\rho})}{\left(\bar{\rho} \bar{h}^{\prime}(\bar{\rho})-\bar{h}(\bar{\rho})\right)^{2}}-\left(\frac{d-1}{\bar{\rho}}-\frac{\bar{\rho} \bar{h}^{\prime \prime}(\bar{\rho})}{\bar{\rho} \bar{h}^{\prime}(\bar{\rho})-\bar{h}(\bar{\rho})}\right) \frac{\bar{\rho}^{2}-\bar{h}(\bar{\rho})^{2}}{\left(\bar{\rho} \bar{h}^{\prime}(\bar{\rho})-\bar{h}(\bar{\rho})\right)^{2}} \\
\bar{a}_{0}(\bar{\rho} ; d, \lambda, \ell)= & -\lambda(\lambda+1) \frac{1-\bar{h}^{\prime}(\bar{\rho})^{2}}{\left(\bar{\rho} \bar{h}^{\prime}(\bar{\rho})-\bar{h}(\bar{\rho})\right)^{2}}-\frac{\ell(\ell+d-2)}{\bar{\rho}^{2}} \\
& -\lambda\left(\frac{d-1}{\bar{\rho} \bar{h}^{\prime}(\bar{\rho})-\bar{h}(\bar{\rho})}-\frac{\bar{h}^{\prime \prime}(\bar{\rho})}{\bar{\rho} \bar{h}^{\prime}(\bar{\rho})-\bar{h}(\bar{\rho})} \frac{\bar{\rho}^{2}-\bar{h}(\bar{\rho})^{2}}{\left(\bar{\rho} \bar{h}^{\prime}(\bar{\rho})-\bar{h}(\bar{\rho})\right)^{2}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows that (B.14) holds if and only if for $\ell \in\{0, \ldots, n\}, m \in \Omega_{d, \ell}$ there are functions $\bar{f}_{\ell, m} \in C^{\infty}([0, \bar{R}])$ such that

$$
\bar{a}_{2}(\bar{\rho}) \bar{f}_{\ell, m}^{\prime \prime}(\bar{\rho})+\bar{a}_{1}(\bar{\rho} ; d, \lambda) \bar{f}_{\ell, m}^{\prime}(\bar{\rho})+\bar{a}_{0}(\bar{\rho} ; d, \lambda, \ell) \bar{f}_{\ell, m}(\bar{\rho})=\bar{F}_{\ell, m}(\bar{\rho}) \quad \text { in }(0, \bar{R})
$$

Now, the analysis of the differential equation is reduced to the one carried out in [98, Proof of Lemma 2.6]. Indeed, since $\bar{h} \equiv-1$ in $[0,1]$, Eq. (B.16) reduces in $(0,1)$ precisely to [98, Eq. (2.8)], which has for $\lambda=\frac{d}{2}$ a smooth solution given in [98, Eq. (2.13)]. Since Eq. (B.16) has no real-valued singular points when $\bar{\rho}>1$, each solution in $[0,1]$ can be extended to a smooth solution $\bar{f}_{\ell, m} \in C^{\infty}([0, \bar{R}])$. Solutions in case $\ell=0$ are smooth and even, so if $\mathbf{F}$ is radially symmetric, also the mode solution to problem (B.14) is radially symmetric. By Lemma B.7, we have thus obtained for each $n \in \mathbb{N}$ a solution $f_{n} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)$ to

$$
\begin{cases}\square_{\bar{\chi}} v_{n} & =G_{n} \\ v_{n}(\tau, \xi) & =\mathrm{e}^{\lambda \tau} f_{n}(\xi)\end{cases}
$$

With this, put

$$
\mathbf{f}_{n}=\left[\begin{array}{c}
f_{n} \\
\lambda \\
c
\end{array}\right] \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}, \quad \mathbf{F}_{n}:=\left(\begin{array}{c}
d \\
2 \\
\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{L}_{\chi}
\end{array}\right) \mathbf{f}_{n} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}
$$

By construction and Lemma B.6,

$$
\mathbf{F}_{n}-\mathbf{F}=-\left[\begin{array}{c}
0 \\
c \\
w
\end{array}\left(\square_{\chi} v_{n}(\tau, .)-G(\tau, .)\right)\right] \left\lvert\, \begin{array}{c}
0 \\
\tau=0
\end{array}=\left[\begin{array}{c}
0 \\
c \\
w
\end{array}\left(F_{n}-F\right)\right.\right.
$$

so Eq. (B.13) yields

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\mathbf{F}_{n}-\mathbf{F}\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \times H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}=0 \quad \text { for any } k \in \mathbb{N}
$$

Now, consider for any $k>\frac{d}{2}$ and for fixed $\varepsilon_{1}=\varepsilon>0$ the inner product $(. \mid) . .\right)_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}$ from Definition B.5. Proposition B. 2 yields the dissipativity estimate

$$
\left\|\left(\alpha \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{L}_{\chi}\right) \mathbf{f}\right\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \geq(\alpha-\varepsilon)\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}
$$

for all $\alpha>\varepsilon$ and all $\mathbf{f} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$. This implies for $\alpha=\lambda=\frac{d}{2}$ the inequality

$$
\left\|\mathbf{f}_{n}-\mathbf{f}_{m}\right\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \leq \frac{1}{\lambda-\varepsilon}\left\|\mathbf{F}_{n}-\mathbf{F}_{m}\right\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}
$$

for any $m, n \in \mathbb{N}$. Since $\|\cdot\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \simeq\|\cdot\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \times H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}$ by Proposition B.1, we get from this, Eq. (B.17) and Sobolev embedding that there exists an $\mathbf{f} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$ with

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\mathbf{f}_{n}-\mathbf{f}\right\|_{H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \times H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}=0 \quad \text { for any } k \in \mathbb{N}
$$

Finally, we follow the proof of [43, p. 82 f., Proposition 3.14] to show that $\mathbf{g}:=\lambda \mathbf{f}-\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f}-\mathbf{F}$ equals $\mathbf{0}$. Eqs. (B.17) to (B.19) yield

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|\mathbf{g}\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} & =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left\|(\alpha-\varepsilon)\left(\mathbf{f}_{n}-\mathbf{f}\right)+\mathbf{g}\right\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& \leq \frac{1}{\alpha-\varepsilon} \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\alpha(\alpha-\varepsilon)\left(\mathbf{f}_{n}-\mathbf{f}\right)+\alpha \mathbf{g}-(\alpha-\varepsilon) \mathbf{L}_{\chi}\left(\mathbf{f}_{n}-\mathbf{f}\right)-\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{g}\right\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \\
& =\frac{1}{\alpha-\varepsilon}\left\|\varepsilon \mathbf{g}-\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{g}\right\|_{\mathfrak{C}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $\alpha>\varepsilon$, so we conclude $\mathbf{g}=\mathbf{0}$ as $\alpha \rightarrow \infty$. Uniqueness of the smooth solution follows from Eq. (B.18).
B.6. The generation theorem. We collect the results from the previous subsections and prove well-posedness of the free wave flow in similarity coordinates for all space dimensions. We emphasize once more that no symmetry assumptions are imposed on the function spaces and data. Nevertheless, the flow in radial symmetry is readily concluded from restriction properties of the general case.
Theorem B.1. Let $d, k \in \mathbb{N}$. Let $h \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ such that

$$
h(0)<0, \quad|(\partial h)(\xi)|<1, \quad\left(\partial^{2} h\right)(\xi) \text { is positive semidefinite }
$$

for all $\xi \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. Let $R_{0}>0$ be determined as in Lemma A. 5 and fix $R \geq R_{0}$. We define on

$$
\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right):=H^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \times H^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)
$$

the operator $\mathbf{L}_{\chi}: \mathfrak{D}\left(\mathbf{L}_{\chi}\right) \subset \mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \rightarrow \mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ by

$$
\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f}=\left[\begin{array}{c}
-\xi^{i} \partial_{i} f_{1}+c f_{2} \\
c \\
w
\end{array}\right]_{\mathfrak{D}^{i} \partial i} \partial^{i} \partial_{i} f_{1}-\left(1+\frac{c}{w} \partial^{i} \partial_{i} h\right) f_{2}-\left(\xi^{i}+2 \frac{c}{w} \partial^{i} h\right) \partial_{i} f_{2} \quad \mathfrak{D}\left(\mathbf{L}_{\chi}\right)=C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}
$$

where the coefficients $c, w \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ are given by

$$
c(\xi)=\xi^{i}(\partial_{i} h)(\xi)-h(\xi), \quad w(\xi)=1-\left(\partial^{i} h\right)(\xi)(\partial_{i} h)(\xi)
$$

Then, this operator is closable and its closure $\overline{\mathbf{L}_{\chi}}: \mathfrak{D}\left(\overline{\mathbf{L}_{\chi}}\right) \subset \mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \rightarrow \mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ is the generator of a strongly continuous semigroup $\mathbf{S}_{\chi}:[0, \infty) \rightarrow \mathfrak{L}\left(\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)\right)$ with the following properties.
(1) For any $0<\varepsilon<\frac{1}{2}$ there is a constant $M_{d, k, R, h, \varepsilon} \geq 1$ such that the growth estimate

$$
\left\|\mathbf{S}_{\chi}(\tau) \mathbf{f}\right\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \leq M_{d, k, R, h, \varepsilon} \mathrm{e}^{\omega_{d, k, \varepsilon} \tau}\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}, \quad \omega_{d, k, \varepsilon}=\max \left\{\frac{d}{2}-k, \varepsilon\right\}
$$

holds for all $\mathbf{f} \in \mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ and all $\tau \geq 0$.
(2) The radial subspace $\mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right):=H_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \times H_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k-1}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ is an invariant closed subspace of $\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ for the semigroup $\mathbf{S}_{\chi}$, that is

$$
\mathbf{S}_{\chi}(\tau) \mathbf{f} \in \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)
$$

for all $\mathbf{f} \in \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ and all $\tau \geq 0$. Furthermore, the operator $\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \upharpoonright: \mathfrak{D}\left(\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \upharpoonright) \subset$ $\mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \rightarrow \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ given by

$$
\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \upharpoonright \mathbf{f}=\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f}, \quad \mathfrak{D}\left(\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \upharpoonright)=\left.C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty} \overline{\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right.}\right)^{2}
$$

is well-defined and closable with closure $\overline{\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \upharpoonright}: \mathfrak{D}\left(\overline{\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \upharpoonright}\right) \subset \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right) \rightarrow \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ given by

$$
\overline{\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \upharpoonright \mathbf{f}}=\overline{\mathbf{L}_{\chi}} \mathbf{f}, \quad \mathfrak{D}\left(\overline{\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \upharpoonright}\right)=\mathfrak{D}\left(\overline{\mathbf{L}_{\chi}}\right) \cap \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)
$$

which is the generator of the subspace semigroup $\mathbf{S}_{\chi} \upharpoonright:[0, \infty) \rightarrow \mathfrak{L}\left(\mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)\right)$ given by

$$
\mathbf{S}_{\chi} \upharpoonright(\tau) \mathbf{f}=\mathbf{S}_{\chi}(\tau) \mathbf{f}
$$

for all $\mathbf{f} \in \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ and all $\tau \geq 0$.
(3) Consider the spacelike hypersurface $\Sigma_{R}^{1, d}(0):=\chi\left(\{0\} \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$. Let $f, g \in C^{\infty}\left(\Sigma_{R}^{1, d}(0)\right)$ such that $\mathbf{f}:=(f, g) \circ \chi(0, .) \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$. Then $\mathbf{u}:=\mathbf{S}_{\chi}(.) \mathbf{f} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{(0, \infty) \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}$ and $u:=u_{1} \circ \chi^{-1} \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathrm{X}}_{R}^{1, d}\right)$ is the unique solution to the Cauchy problem

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
\square u & =0 \quad \text { in } \mathrm{X}_{R}^{1, d} \\
\left.u\right|_{\Sigma_{R}^{1, d}(0)} & =f \\
\left.\left(\partial_{0} u\right)\right|_{\Sigma_{R}^{1, d}(0)} & =g
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

Proof. (1) By Proposition B.1, the sesquilinear form $(\cdot \mid \cdot)_{\mathfrak{E}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}$ from Definition B. 5 uniquely extends to an inner product on $\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ whose induced norm is equivalent to the classical Sobolev norm. Proposition B. 2 yields for $\varepsilon_{1}=\varepsilon>0$ the dissipative estimate

$$
\left(\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{f} \mid \mathbf{f}\right)_{\mathfrak{E}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)} \leq \omega_{d, k, \varepsilon}\|\mathbf{f}\|_{\mathfrak{E}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)}^{2}
$$

for all $\mathbf{f} \in \mathfrak{D}\left(\mathbf{L}_{\chi}\right)$. Consequently, the operator $\mathbf{L}_{\chi}$ is linear, densely defined and dissipative, hence closable in $\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$. Proposition B. 3 shows for $\lambda=\frac{d}{2}$ that $\lambda \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{L}_{\chi}$ has range $C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$, which is dense in $\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$. Now, we conclude from the Lumer-Phillips theorem [43, p. 83, Theorem 3.15] that the closure $\overline{\mathbf{L}_{\chi}}$ generates a contraction semigroup with the asserted properties.
(2) By Proposition B.3, we have for $\lambda=\frac{d}{2}$ that $\mathbf{R}_{\mathbf{L}_{\chi}}(\lambda) \mathbf{f} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$ for all $\mathbf{f} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$. This statement extends to all $\lambda>\frac{d}{2}$ via a Neumann series argument, see [43, p. 82, 3.14 Proposition]. Now, The Post-Widder inversion formula [43, p. 223, 5.5 Corollary] gives

$$
\mathbf{S}(\tau) \mathbf{f}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(\frac{n}{\tau} \mathbf{R}_{\overline{\mathbf{L}_{\chi}}}\left(\frac{n}{\tau}\right)\right)^{n} \mathbf{f} \in \mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)
$$

for all $\mathbf{f} \in C_{\mathrm{rad}}^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$. By density and boundedness this extends to $\mathfrak{H}_{\mathrm{rad}}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$.

(3) The semigroup is established in the spaces $\mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ for all $k \in \mathbb{N}$. So [54, Theorem C.1] gives $\mathbf{u}(\tau) \in \mathfrak{H}^{k}\left(\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)$ for all $k \in \mathbb{N}$. Hence $\mathbf{u}(\tau) \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$ for all $\tau \geq 0$ by Sobolev embedding. Using [43, p. 50, 1.3 Lemma], we have

$$
\partial_{\tau} \mathbf{u}(\tau)=\overline{\mathbf{L}_{\chi}} \mathbf{u}(\tau)=\mathbf{L}_{\chi} \mathbf{u}(\tau) \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}}\right)^{2}
$$

for all $\tau \geq 0$. By induction, $\partial_{\tau}^{\ell} \mathbf{u}(\tau)=\mathbf{L}_{\chi}^{\ell} \mathbf{u}(\tau) \in C^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathbb{B}}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$ for all $\ell \in \mathbb{N}$. Schwarz's theorem [104, p. 235, Theorem 9.41] implies $\mathbf{u} \in C^{\infty}\left((0, \infty) \times \mathbb{B}_{R}^{d}\right)^{2}$. Finally, the transition lemma B. 1 yields that $u$ solves the Cauchy problem.

abstract:
We consider corotational wave maps from Minkowski spacetime into the sphere
and the equivariant Yang-Mills equation for all energy-supercritical
dimensions. Both models have explicit self-similar finite time blowup
solutions, which continue to exist even past the singularity. We prove the
nonlinear asymptotic stability of these solutions in spacetime regions that
approach the future light cone of the singularity. For this, we develop a
general functional analytic framework in adapted similarity coordinates that
allows to evolve the stable wave flow near a self-similar blowup solution in
such spacetime regions.
